At the time the proposed budget is transmitted to members of the City Council by the City Manager or his/her designee, a copy of the proposed budget shall be made available for public inspection in the Office of the City Clerk during regular office hours. 
(Code 1978, § 3-1007; Code 1990, § 3-1-8) 
State Law reference— Public notice required when budget placed for public inspection, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-5(e). 
Sec. 3-1-9. - Public hearing. 
No earlier than seven days after the proposed budget is transmitted to members of the City Council and no later than seven days prior to the time that the budget is adopted by the City Council, a public hearing shall be held to give the public the opportunity to comment upon the proposed budget. Notice of the public hearing shall be given in a newspaper of general circulation in the Municipality no more than 20 days and no less than seven days in advance of the hearing. 
(Code 1990, § 3-1-9) 
Sec. 3-1-10. - Budget adoption; amendments. 
The adoption of the budget shall be accomplished by the approval of a budget ordinance which specifies the anticipated revenues by appropriate categories and appropriated expenditures for each department and each nondepartmental expense and for each fund covered by the budget. Amendments to the budget shall be approved by resolution. 
(Code 1978, § 3-1009; Code 1990, § 3-1-10) 
Sec. 3-1-11. - Increases; transfers. 
Any increase in appropriation to a department budget or in a nondepartment expense category, whether accomplished through a change in anticipated revenues (supplemental appropriations ordinance) or through a transfer of appropriations among departments or nondepartmental expenses (amendment of appropriations ordinance), shall also require an amendment to the budget ordinance. 
(Code 1990, § 3-1-11) 
Sec. 3-1-12. - Sinking fund transfer. 
No appropriation transfer shall be made from a sinking fund or debt retirement fund until all the legal obligations and requirements of such fund have been satisfied. 
(Code 1978, § 3-1011; Code 1990, § 3-1-12) 
Sec. 3-1-13. - Anticipated revenues. 
The City Manager or his/her designee shall present the statement of anticipated revenues on the basis of the ordinary and reasonable revenues which can be expected for the fiscal year. Property tax revenue estimates shall be based upon the anticipated tax digest, less a stated discount for delinquent taxes based on a consideration of the taxes which were delinquent at the close of the three prior fiscal years, plus a stated amount of delinquent taxes, including penalties and interest, to be collected in the fiscal year based on consideration of the actual experience in the collection of delinquent taxes in the three prior fiscal years. 
(Code 1978, § 3-1012; Code 1990, § 3-1-13) 
Sec. 3-1-14. - Appropriations to lapse. 
All appropriations which are not obligated, encumbered or expended at the end of the fiscal year shall lapse and shall become a part of the unencumbered surplus which may be appropriated for the next fiscal year, provided that appropriations for capital improvements shall not lapse until the completion of the improvements for which the appropriation was originally made. 
(Code 1990, § 3-1-14) 
Sec. 3-1-15. - Funds. 
The following funds may be established and may be used as necessary to provide for the proper accounting of all financial activities of this Municipality: 
(1)  The general fund to account for the general governmental operations and all financial transactions not properly accounted for in another fund; 
(2)  Special revenue funds to account for the proceeds of special revenue sources other than special assessments, or to finance specified activities as required by law or administrative regulation; 
(3)  Debt service funds to account for the payment of interest and principal on long term debt other than special assessment and revenue bonds; 
(4)  Capital projects funds to account for the receipt and disbursement of monies including bond funds used for the acquisition of capital facilities other than those financed by special assessment and enterprise funds; 
(5)  Enterprise (utility) funds to account for the financing of services to the general public where all or most of the costs involved are paid in the form of charges by users of such services; 
(6)  Trust and agency funds to account for assets held by a government unit as trustee or agent for individuals, private organizations, and other government units; 
(7)  Intergovernmental service funds to account for the financing of special activities and services performed by a designated organization unit within a governmental jurisdiction for their organization units within the same governmental jurisdiction; and 
(8)  Special assessment funds to account for special assessments levied to finance public improvements or services deemed to benefit the properties against which the assessments are levied. 
(Code 1978, § 3-1014; Code 1990, § 3-1-15) 
Sec. 3-1-16. - Accounts. 
(a)  A complete self-balancing group of accounts shall be established and maintained for each fund used. This group of accounts shall include all general ledger accounts and subsidiary records necessary to reflect compliance with legal provisions and to set forth the financial position and the results of financial operations of the fund. 
(b)  Additional accounts, as follows, shall be maintained: 
(1)  A general fixed asset group of accounts for the purpose of accounting for those assets which are of tangible nature, have a life longer than one fiscal year, and have a significant value or have a value greater than $2,000.00. Fixed assets shall be recorded at original cost, shall not be depreciated and shall be removed from the account when disposed of. 
(2)  A general long term debt account for the purpose of accounting for long term debt which is supported by general revenues and for recording and fairly representing the liability for long term debt at any time from date of issuance until the debt is retired. 
(Code 1978, § 3-1015; Code 1990, § 3-1-16) 
Sec. 3-1-17. - Method of accounting. 
To the extent possible, the modified accrual basis of accounting shall be used so that expenditures, other than accrued interest on long term debt, are recorded at the time liabilities are incurred and revenues are recorded when cash is received, except for material or available revenues which shall be accrued to reflect properly the taxes levied and the revenues earned. All receipts and disbursements shall be posted promptly and at least on a monthly basis. To the extent possible, all interfund transfers shall be cleared by the end of the fiscal year. 
(Code 1978, § 3-1017; Code 1990, § 3-1-17) 
Sec. 3-1-18. - Financial reports. 
Financial statements and reports showing the current condition of budgetary and proprietary accounts shall be prepared monthly and presented to the City Council at least quarterly. Not later than six months after the close of the fiscal year, a comprehensive annual financial report covering all funds and financial operations shall be prepared and published. A summary of this report, containing at least a statement of revenues and expenditures as of the close of the preceding fiscal year and the combined balance sheet for all funds and account groups, will be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the Municipality. 
(Code 1978, § 3-1017; Code 1990, § 3-1-18) 
State Law reference— Filing of annual reports with Department of Community Affairs, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-8. 
Sec. 3-1-19. - Audits. 
All the funds, accounts and financial transactions of the City shall be subject to an annual audit by an independent certified public accountant who is to be selected by the City Council. The audit shall be conducted according to the standards set forth in the American Institute of Certified Public Accountant's publication, Audits of State and Local Governmental Units. 
(Code 1978, § 3-1018; Code 1990, § 3-1-19) 
State Law reference— Annual audit requirements, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-7. 
Sec. 3-1-20. - Uncollectible accounts. 
(a)  The City Manager or his/her designee is authorized to write off accounts at the end of each and every fiscal year which are determined to be uncollectible by the City Manager or his/her designee pursuant to the criteria set forth in this section. In addition, the City Manager or his/her designee is authorized to make operating transfers for the purpose of closing out interfund accounts in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. 
(b)  An account for taxes owed to the City is deemed to be uncollectible and may be written off for accounting purposes at the end of each and every fiscal year if: 
(1)  The owner or owners of the property as of January 1 of the year in which the taxes are owed on the property cannot be located; 
(2)  The owner of the property in question is deceased; 
(3)  With regard to real property, the property has been sold and more than four years have elapsed since the tax year in question; 
(4)  With regard to personal property, the property has been sold and more than five years have elapsed since the tax year in question; 
(5)  The person or entity, as the case may be, has filed bankruptcy and the debt has been discharged by the bankruptcy court; 
(6)  The person or entity, as the case may be, has filed any type of action with the court and the debt has been discharged thereto; 
(7)  A fi. fa. has been on the general execution docket for more than seven years. 
(c)  An account for a City service is deemed to be uncollectible and may be written off for accounting purposes at the end of each and every fiscal year if: 
(1)  The customer has ceased to use a City service, and such customer did not leave a forwarding address, or the City Manager or his/her designee has been unable to obtain a forwarding address; 
(2)  The customer is deceased; 
(3)  The customer has filed bankruptcy and the debt has been discharged by the bankruptcy court; or 
(4)  The customer has filed any type of action with the court and the debt has been discharged pursuant thereto. 
(Code 1990, § 3-1-20; Ord. No. 517, 6-2-1992) 
Secs. 3-1-21—3-1-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - PURCHASING AND CONTRACTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Local Government Public Works Construction Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-91-1 et seq. 

Sec. 3-1-30. - Purchasing policy. 
The procurement policy of the City governing the purchase of supplies, equipment, and contractual services, shall be as established by the City Council, from time to time, and is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated herein as if fully set out. 
Secs. 3-1-31—3-1-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - COLLECTION OF DELINQUENT TAXES AND OTHER REVENUES 

Sec. 3-1-51. - Collection of delinquent taxes, fees or other revenue; interest. 
(a)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall issue a fi. fa. on any property, personal or real, for any city tax, fee, penalty, fine, or other revenue, which has not been paid within the time limits set for payment. Upon the issuance of such fi. fa., the City Manager or his/her designee shall so advise the delinquent taxpayer by depositing a written notice in the United States mail, in a properly addressed envelope, with adequate postage thereon. If any City tax, fee, penalty, fine or other revenue due the City has not been paid within the time allowed by law, then the City Manager or his/her designee shall collect the amount due by whatever means the City Manager or his/her designee deems appropriate consistent with State law and the policies and procedures of the City. 
(b)  Any debts due the City as described in Subsection (a) of this section are hereby declared also to be personal debts of the person owning the taxed property or otherwise owing funds to the City and the amount due may be collected plus interest, penalties, costs and attorney's fees from that person as provided generally for the collection of personal debts under general State law. 
(c)  Executions hereunder may be assigned, sold or otherwise transferred with the approval of the Mayor and may be collected after the transfer as provided in this section. 
(d)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall be authorized to conduct a sale for taxes due the City as provided by State law and the policies and procedures of the City. 
(e)  Any license, privilege, or permit granted by the City shall be revoked by the City Manager for the failure to pay any money due the City for taxes, fees, penalties, interests, fines, or other revenue, provided, that any person aggrieved by the order may, within ten days thereof, appeal to the City Council who, after a hearing thereon, may approve, modify the order, or restore the license, privilege, or permit by adopting a motion to that effect by a majority vote of all Council Members present. 
(f)  Unless otherwise provided in this Code, all fi. fas. issued hereunder shall earn interest at the maximum rate allowed by State law in addition to a 15 percent delinquent penalty. 
(Code 1990, § 3-1-51; Ord. No. 541, 9-20-1993) 
State Law reference— Interest on delinquent taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-2-40; penalty and interest, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-23(b). 
Sec. 3-1-52. - Collection of overdue water, garbage and sewer accounts; interest. 
1.  Interest shall be charged at the legal rate of 1.5 percent on all City service accounts which have been due and payable for 30 days or more. Such interest shall be calculated on the amount owed from the date upon which such accounts became due and payable until such accounts are paid. 
2.  Interest charged under the ordinance codified in this section shall be collected according to law. 
(Code 1990, § 3-1-52; Ord. No. 499, 6-4-1991) 
CHAPTER 2. - REVENUE AND TAXATION 
ARTICLE A. - AD VALOREM TAXES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Taxation power of municipal and county governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I(a) and (b)(2); ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.; municipal power of ad valorem taxation to provide for financial assistance to its development authority, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq. 

Sec. 3-2-1. - Tax rate. 
An ad valorem tax upon all real and personal property within the City is hereby set and levied at such rate as established annually by resolution of the City Council. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-1) 
Sec. 3-2-2. - Assessment. 
All property subject to the ad valorem tax shall be assessed at 40 percent of its full fair market value as established by the County for County ad valorem tax purposes. 
(Code 1978, § 3-2002; Code 1990, § 3-2-2) 
State Law reference— Determination of fair market value for county and municipal ad valorem property taxation purposes, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-352. 
Sec. 3-2-3. - Tax due and payable; installments. 
(a)  Ad valorem tax bills are due and payable on a date certain as specified on the bill. 
(b)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall designate a date on which tax bills shall be mailed and shall be responsible for sending the tax bills for all ad valorem taxes other than motor vehicles. 
(c)  In the event of an excess tax payment, such excess tax payment may be applied to any delinquent accounts owned by the taxpayer, or if there are no delinquent accounts, refunded to the taxpayer. 
(d)  Ad valorem tax bills, as adjusted to conform to the County tax digest, shall be payable on a date certain as specified on the bill. In the event of an adjustment by the State Revenue Commissioner, the City shall, after receipt from the County of the adjustment for information, bill for any underpayment or refund any overpayment in the manner set forth herein. 
(Code 1978, § 3-2003; Code 1990, § 3-2-3; Ord. No. 542, 9-20-1993) 
State Law reference— Collection and payment of taxes on tangible property in installments, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-23. 
Sec. 3-2-4. - Refund of taxes and license fees. 
(a)  The City Manager or his/her designee may refund to a taxpayer any and all taxes and license fees which are determined to have been erroneously or illegally assessed and collected from such taxpayer under the laws of the State, under resolution or ordinance of the City or which are determined to have been voluntarily or involuntarily overpaid by the taxpayer. 
(b)  In any case in which it is determined that an erroneous or illegal collection of any tax or license fee has been made by the City or that a taxpayer has voluntarily or involuntarily overpaid any tax or license fee, the taxpayer from whom the tax or license fee was collected may file a claim for a refund with the City at any time within one year or (in the case of taxes) three years after the date of the payment of the tax or license fee to the City. The taxpayer shall make the claim for refund in writing on a form provided by the City; the form shall contain at a minimum the following information: 
(1)  The taxpayer's name; 
(2)  The taxpayer's address; 
(3)  A summary of the statement of the grounds upon which the taxpayer relies; and 
(4)  Whether the taxpayer desires a conference or hearing before the City in connection with any claim for a refund. 
(c)  If the claim is properly submitted, the City Manager or his/her designee shall consider the information contained in the taxpayer's claim for a refund and such other information as is available. The City Manager or his/her designee shall approve or disapprove the taxpayer's claim and shall notify the taxpayer of its action. 
(1)  In the event any claim for refund is approved, the City shall refund such amount within 60 days of the date of the approval of the taxpayer's claim; provided, however, the City Manager or his/her designee may apply such refund to any delinquent accounts owed to the City by the taxpayer. No refund provided for herein shall be assignable. 
(2)  Any taxpayer whose claim for a refund is denied by the City Council or whose claim is neither denied nor approved within one year from the date of the filing of the claim, shall have the right to bring an action for a refund in the Superior Court of the County. 
(3)  No action or proceeding for the recovery of a refund shall be commenced before the expiration of one year from the date of filing the claim for refund unless the City renders a decision on the claim within the one year period. No action or proceeding for the recovery of a refund shall be commenced after the expiration of one year from the date the claim is denied. The one-year period described in this subsection for filing an action for a refund shall be extended for such period as may be agreed upon in writing between the taxpayer and the City Council during the one-year period or any extension of the one-year period. 
(4)  Refunds as provided for herein and approved or allowed shall be paid from the funds of the City to which the tax or license fees were originally paid. Such refunds shall be paid within 60 days of the approval of the taxpayer's claim or within 60 days of the entry of a final decision in any action for a refund. 
(d)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall be responsible for the administration of this section and shall be authorized to make such other rules and regulations and establish such policies as are necessary to implement this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-4; Ord. No. 544, 9-20-1993) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-380. 
Secs. 3-2-5—3-2-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE EXCISE TAXES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Excise tax on malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80; on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-60; on distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-80. 

Sec. 3-2-11. - Levy and computation. 
In addition to all other taxes or license fees imposed upon retail dealers selling any malt beverages, wine or distilled spirits for retail package or by the drink sales in the City, there is hereby levied and imposed upon the following excise taxes: 
(1)  Upon the sale of any malt beverages there is imposed upon the wholesaler an excise tax of $0.05 per 12 ounce container and $6.00 for each container of tap or draft beer of 15½ gallons and in similar proportion for bottles, cans and containers of various sizes as follows: 

 
(2)  Upon the sale of any wine there is imposed upon the retail dealer an excise tax of $0.22 per liter. 
(3)  Upon the sale of any distilled spirits there is imposed upon the retail dealer an excise tax of $0.22 per liter. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-11) 
Sec. 3-2-12. - Reports; payment. 
(a)  Each wholesale dealer selling to any retail dealer in the City to whom the taxes in this article apply, shall file a report with the City Manager or his/her designee by the tenth day of each month, itemizing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of all beverages by size and type of container sold within the City. The report shall show the name and address of each retail dealer with which the wholesaler did business in the City and any other information as may be required by the City Manager or his/her designee for the administration of this article. 
(b)  Each wholesale dealer shall become liable for such taxes levied by this article for the sale of alcoholic beverages to a retail dealer, at the time of delivery of the alcoholic beverages, and shall hold such taxes in trust for the City until the taxes are remitted to the City as herein provided. 
(c)  The report shall be accompanied by remittance to the City of all taxes due under this article for the preceding month. 
(Code 1978, § 3-2012(a)—(c); Code 1990, § 3-2-12; Ord. No. 372, 6-16-1986) 
Sec. 3-2-13. - Records. 
Each wholesale dealer shall keep true and correct records, including invoices, of all sales, shipments or deliveries of beverages to retail dealers in this City. These records shall be preserved for at least one year and shall be made available on request for inspection by any authorized representative of the City. 
(Code 1978, § 3-2012(d); Code 1990, § 3-2-13) 
Sec. 3-2-14. - Violations; penalty; revocation of license. 
(a)  Distilled spirits and wine. The excise tax levied in this article on distilled spirits and wine is hereby levied upon the retailer licensed to do business in the City and it is the intent of this section to so levy this tax but require the payment of the tax at the time of delivery by the wholesaler to retailer, who shall have the responsibility of remitting the tax to the City on behalf of the retailer on or before the tenth day of each calendar month, as hereinbefore required. In the event the tax due hereunder is not paid on or before the tenth day of each calendar month, a ten percent penalty on the gross tax will be levied by the City against each defaulting retailing licensee for whom the tax is not paid on or before the tenth day of the month. 
(b)  Malt beverages. The excise tax levied in this article on malt beverages is hereby levied upon the wholesaler and it is the intent of this section to so levy this tax but require the payment of the tax at the time of delivery by the wholesaler to retailer, who shall have the responsibility of remitting the tax to the City on behalf of the retailer on or before the tenth day of each calendar month, as provided by State law. In the event the tax due hereunder is not paid on or before the tenth day of each calendar month, a ten percent penalty on the gross tax will be levied against the wholesaler. 
(c)  Noncompliance by wholesale dealer. If any wholesale dealer or distributor fails or refuses to make the reports required herein, the City shall notify the dealer or distributor in writing and if the reports are not made and the taxes remitted within five days from the date of the notice, the wholesale dealer or distributor shall be prohibited from making any further deliveries in the City and the retail licensees served and any wholesale dealer or distributor from whom the taxes have not been paid shall be subject to having his license suspended or revoked as herein provided. 
(d)  Unlawful retail sales. It shall be a violation of this article for any person, firm, or corporation to sell at retail within the City any alcoholic beverages on which the taxes herein provided for have not been paid. 
(e)  Unlawful deliveries. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any wholesale dealer or distributor, person, firm or corporation to deliver any alcoholic beverages to any retail dealer in the City without at the time of the delivery collecting any excise taxes due as herein provided for. 
(f)  The City Manager, or any person authorized in writing by him/her, may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any wholesaler, distributor or retailer liable for the taxes imposed by this article, during normal business hours in order to verify the accuracy of any report or to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. 
(g)  Violation and penalties. Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article or who shall assist any retail dealer in alcoholic beverages in the City to evade or avoid the payment of the taxes herein provided for shall be guilty of a violation of this section and on conviction thereof in the Municipal Court shall be fined or sentenced as provided by this Code and any such person so convicted shall also be subject to having any business license of the City issued to the person suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-14) 
Sec. 3-2-15. - Levy of excise tax on distilled spirits by the drink. 
(a)  Levy of tax; rate. There is hereby levied an excise tax against each holder of a license issued by the City for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises, a tax equal to three percent of the charge to the public for such beverages. 
(b)  Computation. The tax is based on the gross revenue for the sale of all such beverages or drinks containing distilled spirits and shall be payable by the license holder. 
(c)  Reports. The tax will be calculated by each license holder for each calendar year and shall be reported monthly on a form provided by the City. All reports shall be submitted to the City by not later than the 20th day of the following month for sales made during the previous month. Payment in full shall accompany such report. The City Manager, or any person authorized in writing by either of such officers may examine the books, records, papers, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any licensee hereunder during normal business hours, in order to verify the accuracy of any report or to ascertain the amount required to be paid under this section. 
(d)  Penalty. Failure to pay the tax when due shall result in the imposition of a ten percent penalty on any and all amounts due and owing and unpaid by the 20th day of each month. Such noncompliance may result in the revocation of the license held by the license holder or the failure to renew such license. 
(e)  Noncompliance. If any license holder of a license for sale of distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises fails or refuses to make the reports required herein, the City shall notify the license holder in writing and if the reports are not made and the taxes are not paid within five days of the date of notice, the license holder shall be prohibited from making any further sales in the City. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-15; Ord. No. 371, 6-16-1986; Ord. No. 380, 8-5-1986) 
Secs. 3-2-16—3-2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - LICENSING AND TAXATION OF TELEPHONE COMPANIES, INSURANCE COMPANIES AND FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Limit on professions tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5. 

Sec. 3-2-21. - Special provisions for telephone companies. 
(a)  For any telephone companies that have retail, end user customers located within the City's municipal corporate boundaries, the City hereby requires due compensation of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues, as defined in Paragraphs (8) and (9) of Subsection (b) of Section 46-5-1 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1(b)(8) and (9)); provided, however, that any company that pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues pursuant to an existing franchise agreement shall continue to pay in accordance with the existing franchise agreement until the expiration of the franchise agreement or December 31, 2012, whichever occurs first, and any company that pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues in accordance with an occupational license tax arrangement shall continue to pay in accordance with such payment schedule until December 31, 2012. 
(b)  Regarding any telephone company that does not have retail, end user customers located within the City's municipal corporate boundaries, the payment by such company to a Municipal Authority in accordance with the rates set by regulations promulgated by the department of transportation for the use of its rights of way shall be considered to be the payment of due compensation. 
(c)  The payments of due compensation shall be paid in quarterly installments, each of which shall be paid directly to the City within 30 calendar days after the last day of each calendar quarter. 
(d)  The City Manager or his/her designee, shall, on behalf of the City, exercise day-to-day administrative duties necessary to fulfill the regulatory authority of the City under O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1 et seq. and shall perform the following duties: 
i.  Review application information submitted by a telephone company to the City and, if an application is incomplete, notify the telegraph or telephone company within 15 business days of the receipt of such application, identifying in such notice all application deficiencies. 
ii.  Report the receipt of a completed application to the Mayor and City Council within 45 calendar days of the receipt of such completed application. 
iii.  Review payments of due compensation submitted by the company to ensure compliance with the provisions of the amended law and this section. 
iv.  Provide a coordination function between a telephone company and all City departments on any matter relating to the amended law and this section. 
v.  Arrange and evaluate, no more than once a year, a comprehensive review of the records of a company that is reasonably related to the calculation and payment of due compensation. 
vi.  Provide to all telegraph and telephone companies located in its rights-of-way written notice of annexations and changes in Municipal corporate boundaries. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-21; Ord. No. 609, 11-4-1997; Ord. No. 796, § 1, 9-2-2009) 
Sec. 3-2-22. - Special provisions for insurance companies. 
(a)  Insurer license fees. There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business in the City in an amount as established by the City Council from time to time, or the maximum amount permitted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8(b)(1). For each separate business location in excess of one not covered by Subsection (b) of this section which is operating on behalf of insurers within the City, there is levied a license fee in an amount as established by the City Council from time to time, or the maximum amount permitted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8(b)(1). For the purposes of this subsection, the term "insurer" means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated by O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. The license fees provided in this subsection shall be exclusive of any license fee provided by Chapter 2 of Title 9. 
(b)  License fees for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. For each separate business location not otherwise subject to a license fee hereunder, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales offers, solicits or takes application for insurance through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance, said insurer shall pay an additional annual fee per location. The amount of the additional annual license fee shall be as established by the City Council, from time to time. The license fees provided in this subsection shall be exclusive of any license fee provided by Chapter 2 of Title 9. 
(c)  Gross premiums tax imposed on life insurers. There is hereby levied an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the State in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. The term "gross direct premiums" as used in this section, means gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by Subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  Gross premiums tax, all other insurers. There is hereby levied an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in subsection of O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5, doing business within the State in an amount equal to 2.5 percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this subsection, means gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this subsection is in addition to the license fees imposed by Subsection (a) of this section. 
(e)  Due date for license fees. License fees imposed by this section shall be due and payable on the first day of each year . 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-22; Ord. No. 609, 11-4-1997; Ord. No. 653, 12-5-2001) 
Sec. 3-2-23. - Financial institutions business license tax. 
(a)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is hereby levied an annual business license tax upon State and national banking associations, Federal savings and loans associations, State building and loan associations a business license tax at the rate of 0.25 percent of the gross receipts of these institutions as defined. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institutions pursuant to this section shall be $1,000.00 per year. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the term "gross receipts" means the total amount of revenue generated from the sources itemized below during the calendar year immediately preceding the date on which the tax imposed by the ordinance is due: 
(1)  Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to banks are as follows: 
a.  Interest and fees on loans, less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold and serviced for others; 
b.  Interest on balances with other depository financial institutions; 
c.  Interest on Federal or correspondent funds sold and securities purchased under agreements of resale; 
d.  Interest on other bonds, notes, and debentures, excluding interest on obligations in the State or its political subdivisions and obligations on the United States; 
e.  Dividends on stocks; 
f.  Income from direct lease financing; 
g.  Income from fiduciary activities; 
h.  Service charges on deposit accounts; 
i.  Other service charges, commissions, and fees; and 
j.  Other income. 
(2)  Items to be included in calculations of gross receipts with respect to savings and loan associations are as follows: 
a.  Interest on mortgage loans less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold in service for others; 
b.  Interest on mortgages, participations, or mortgage-backed securities; 
c.  Interest on real estate sold on contract; 
d.  Discounts on mortgage loans purchased; 
e.  Interest on other loans, excluding interest on obligations of the State or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States; 
f.  Interest and dividends on investments and deposits; 
g.  Loan fees; 
h.  Loan servicing fees; 
i.  Other fees and charges; 
j.  Gross income from office building operations; 
k.  Net income from office building operations; 
l.  Gross income from real estate held for investment; 
m.  Net income from service corporations and subsidiaries; 
n.  Miscellaneous operating income; 
o.  Profit on sale of real estate owned, investment securities, loans, and other assets; and 
p.  Miscellaneous non-operating income. 
(3)  The following items shall be deducted from gross receipts calculated pursuant to Subsection (b)(1) or (2) of this section: 
a.  An amount equal to the amount of interest paid on all liabilities for the period; 
b.  An amount equal to income derived from the authorized activities of any domestic international banking facility operating pursuant to Article 5(a) of Chapter 1 of Title 7 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (O.C.G.A. § 7-1-730 et seq.); 
c.  An amount equal to any income arising from the conduct of a banking business with persons or entities located outside of the United States, its territories or possessions; 
d.  An amount equal to a depository financial institution's gross income which is taxed under the tax laws of a state other than this State; and 
e.  To the extent that any deductions are made pursuant to Subsections (b)(3)b, c, and d of this section, any deductions taken under Subsection(b)(3)a of this section shall be reduced by the same proportion that the deductions in Subsection (b)(3)b through d of this section bear to the gross receipts of the depository financial institution as calculated before making any deductions pursuant to Subsections (b)(3)a through d of this section. 
(c)  Each depository financial institution within the City shall file a return of its gross receipts with the City on March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. Said returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the Commissioner of the Department of Banking and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in Subsection (d) of Section 48-6-93 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d)). The tax levied pursuant to this section shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in that return. 
(d)  The due date of taxes levied by this section shall be April 1 of each year. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-23; Ord. No. 609, 11-4-1997) 
Secs. 3-2-24—3-2-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE D. - EXCISE TAX ON LODGINGS AND ACCOMMODATIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Municipalities authorized to impose, levy, and collect excise tax on hotels, motels, lodgings and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 

Sec. 3-2-51. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings respectively ascribed to them, unless the context indicates a different meaning. 
(1)  Reserved. 
(2)  Certificate of authority means a document issued by the City Manager or his/her designee following registration by a person with the City as an innkeeper, which shall authorize such innkeeper to collect the tax levied and assessed pursuant to this article. 
(3)  Collection allowance means the percentage of the gross taxes due that an innkeeper may retain as a compensation for expenses incurred in collecting, submitting, reporting and paying taxes pursuant to this article. 
(4)  Deficiency means the amount by which the tax remitted by an innkeeper is less than the amount that should have been paid for the same period, as determined by the City Manager or his/her designee, and encompasses both underpayment of tax and nonpayment of tax. 
(5)  Due date means the day of the month designated hereinafter as the day on or before which innkeepers must submit the statements and reports required under this article and remit to the City the taxes due for the immediately preceding month. 
(6)  Gross taxes means the total of taxes due pursuant to this article on the gross rental charges collected by an innkeeper in a given month, prior to deduction of the collection allowance provided for herein. 
(7)  Innkeeper means any person, including but not limited to the owner or proprietor of the premises, lessee, sub-lessee, lender in possession, licensee or any other person or entity, licensed by or required to pay business or occupation taxes to the City for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, campground, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. Said term encompasses every person legally subject to such licensure or business or occupation tax, whether or not such person actually complies with such license or business or occupation tax requirements. 
(8)  Lodging means any room, lodging, or accommodation occupied, intended to be occupied or furnished, or offered to the public for occupancy by one or more occupants, in a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, campground, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished or offered to the public for occupancy for value. 
(9)  Month or monthly period means the calendar months of any year. 
(10)  Net taxes means the total of taxes due pursuant to this article on the gross rental charges collected by an innkeeper in a given month, after deduction of the collection allowance provided for herein. 
(11)  Occupancy means the use or possession or the right to the use or possession of any lodging as defined herein. 
(12)  Occupancy rate means the monthly average of the percentage of total lodging units an innkeeper has available for rental that are actually rented. 
(13)  Occupant means any person or entity that for consideration uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess lodging as defined herein. 
(14)  Person means any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, organization, company, estate, trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate or other group, combination or entity. 
(15)  Promoting tourism, conventions, and trade shows means planning, conducting or participating in programs of information and publicity designed to attract or advertise tourism, conventions, or trade shows. 
(16)  Rental charge means the total consideration received by an innkeeper for the occupancy of a lodging at a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, campground, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value, whether received in money, property, services or credits, exclusive of any local, State, or Federal taxation. 
(17)  Return means the monthly report or form as may be required by the City Manager or his/her designee to be completed by an innkeeper to convey to the City such information as may be necessary or expedient for the administration of this article. 
(18)  Tax or excise tax means the tax imposed by this article. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-51; Ord. No. 706, 5-18-2005) 
Sec. 3-2-52. - Authority; rules and regulations; records and registration required. 
(1)  Authority. The City Manager or his/her designee shall administer and enforce this article for the levy and collection of the tax under this article. 
(2)  Rules and regulations. The City Manager or his/her designee shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article or other laws of the City, the laws or Constitution of the State or the laws or Constitution of the United States for the administration and enforcement of this article and the collection of the tax under this article. 
(3)  Records required; audit authority. In order to aid in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and to collect all the tax imposed, all innkeepers are hereby required to keep a record of all rental charges for lodging and taxes collected thereon. Duly authorized employees or agents of the City, upon exhibition of identification as such, and during the regular business hours of the innkeeper, may examine and copy the books, papers, records, financial reports, computer media, data storage media, equipment and other facilities if necessary of any innkeeper in order to verify the accuracy of any returns submitted and taxes remitted by the innkeeper and to ascertain and determine the amount of tax, penalties and interest required to be paid, if the tax due is different from the amount remitted. 
(4)  Innkeeper registration; certificate of authority. Every person engaged in or about to engage in the operation of a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, campground, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished or offered to the public for occupancy for value in the City shall register with the City Manager or his/her designee as an innkeeper on a form provided by the City Manager. Persons engaged in said business must so register not later than 15 days after first becoming subject to this article, but the failure to register shall not relieve any person from the obligation of collection or remittance of the tax. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or a partner; in the case of ownership by a corporation, by an executive officer or some other person specifically authorized by the corporation to sign the registration. The City Manager or his/her designee shall after the registration issue, without charge, a certificate of authority to each innkeeper to collect the tax from occupants. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an innkeeper. Each certificate of authority shall state the name and location of the business to which it is issued and shall be prominently displayed therein so as to be seen and to come readily to the notice of all occupants and persons seeking occupancy. The certificates of authority shall be nonassignable and nontransferable and shall be returned immediately to the City Manager upon the cessation of business at the location named or upon sale or transfer of the business at that location. 
(5)  Election of cash or accrual basis. As part of the registration with the City Manager or his/her designee as an innkeeper, each innkeeper must make an election as to remittance of tax on a cash basis or accrual basis, as those terms are defined by generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP). Once an election of cash basis or accrual basis is made, an innkeeper may not thereafter change its election without the prior written consent of the City Manager or his/her designee. 
(a)  Any innkeeper reporting on the cash basis of accounting shall include in each return all cash rental charges made during the period covered by the return and all collections made in any period on credit rental charges of prior periods and shall remit the tax on the rental charges at the time of filing the return. 
(b)  Any innkeeper reporting on the accrual basis of accounting shall be allowed a deduction for bad debts on the same basis that bad debts are allowed as a deduction on State income tax returns under the rules and regulations of the Commissioner of the Georgia Department of Revenue. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-52; Ord. No. 706, 5-18-2005) 
Sec. 3-2-53. - Assessment, levy and duty to collect. 
(1)  Levy. Within the corporate limits of the City there is hereby imposed, assessed and levied, and there shall be paid, an excise tax of eight percent of the rental charge for every occupancy of a lodging. 
(2)  Effective date. The tax levied by this article shall be effective on the first day of the second month following its adoption and shall continue until its permissible existence shall expire as provided by law, or until otherwise terminated by the Georgia General Assembly or the City Council. 
(3)  Liability. Said excise tax is imposed upon each occupant who pays or is responsible for the payment of a rental charge for lodging, and such occupant shall be liable for the tax until such tax is remitted to the City. At the time of collecting the rental charge and tax from the occupant and on demand, the innkeeper shall give to the occupant a receipt therefor. Once the tax is paid by the occupant to the innkeeper, the liability of the occupant for the tax shall be extinguished. A receipt from an innkeeper for payment of a rental charge and the tax thereon shall be proof of extinguishment of an occupant's liability for the tax imposed pursuant to this article. 
(4)  Duty to collect and remit. Each innkeeper shall be liable for the tax at the applicable rate on the rental charges actually collected or the amount of taxes collected from its occupants, whichever is greater and shall remit same to the City as hereinafter provided. Any innkeeper who shall neglect, fail or refuse to collect the tax herein provided shall be liable for, and shall pay the tax personally, in addition to any late penalties, interest and judicial fines provided for herein. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-53; Ord. No. 706, 5-18-2005; Ord. No. 768, 5-21-2008) 
Sec. 3-2-54. - Exemptions. 
(1)  Casualty. The tax authorized by this article shall not apply to rental charges made for any lodgings provided to any persons who certify that they are staying in such lodgings as a result of the destruction of their home or residence by fire or other casualty. 
(2)  Occupancy over 30 days. The tax authorized by this article shall apply to rental charges made for any lodgings during the first 30 days of continuous occupancy, and shall not apply to rental charges imposed for any continuous occupancy thereafter. 
(3)  Complimentary rooms. The tax authorized by this article shall not apply to rental charges made for the use of meeting rooms and other such facilities or to any rooms, lodgings or accommodations provided without charge. 
(4)  Official business. The tax authorized by this article shall not apply to rental charges made for any lodgings furnished for a period of one or more days for use by the State or local governmental officials or employees when traveling on official business. Notwithstanding the availability of any other means of identifying a person as a State or local government official or employee, whenever a person pays for any lodgings with a State or local government credit card or debit card, such lodgings shall be deemed to have been furnished for use by a State or local government official or employee traveling on official business for purposes of the exemption provided herein. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-54; Ord. No. 706, 5-18-2005) 
Sec. 3-2-55. - Collection allowance. 
Each innkeeper collecting the tax imposed by this article shall be allowed to retain three percent of the gross taxes due and collected as compensation for expenses incurred in collecting, submitting, reporting and paying the tax if the amount due is not delinquent at the time of payment. Should an innkeeper fail to remit the taxes due hereunder for a particular month on or before the due date, such innkeeper may not deduct and retain the collection allowance, but must remit the full amount of gross taxes for that month to the City. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-55; Ord. No. 706, 5-18-2005) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-52. 
Sec. 3-2-56. - Payment; interest; late charges. 
(1)  Due date. The tax shall become due and payable by the occupant at the time of occupancy. The due date for innkeepers to file returns and remit taxes to the City shall be the 20th day of each month. 
(2)  Return. On or before the 20th day of each month following the first month an innkeeper shall be liable for collection and remittance of the tax, such innkeeper shall transmit to the City Manager or his/her designee for the City, a return in such form as the City Manager or his/her designee may prescribe. Said return shall show the amount of gross rental charges collected by the innkeeper during the immediately preceding month, the amount of gross rental charges exempt from taxation under this article pursuant to Section 3-2-54, the gross taxes collected by authority of this article on said rental charges, the collection allowance, if any, retained by the innkeeper, the amount of net taxes to be remitted to the City, the amount of any penalty or interest due, if any, and the date of remittance to the City. The City Manager or his/her designee may require innkeepers to provide such additional information as he/she may deem necessary or expedient for the administration of this article. 
(3)  Remittance of tax. Along with said return, the innkeeper shall remit to the City Manager or his/her designee on or before the due date, the net taxes due for the immediately preceding month. 
(4)  Allocation of payments. Payments made shall be allocated first to any unpaid penalties, second to any unpaid tax and third to interest. 
(5)  Penalty for return filed after due date. Any return filed with the City Manager or his/her designee after the due date shall subject the innkeeper to a penalty of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, if the failure is for one month or less; and an additional five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, for each additional month or fraction thereof in which such failure shall continue; provided, however, that the aggregate penalty for any single violation shall not exceed 25 percent or $25.00, whichever is greater. 
(6)  Interest on taxes paid after due date. Any tax not remitted to the City Manager or his/her designee on or before the due date shall accrue interest on the unpaid principal amount due, computed at the rate of one percent per month. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-56; Ord. No. 706, 5-18-2005) 
Sec. 3-2-57. - Failure to pay tax in full; failure to make return; collection of arrearages; refund of overpayments. 
(1)  Service of notice to innkeeper. If the City Manager or his/her designee is not satisfied with a return or the amount of tax paid to the City by any innkeeper or if an innkeeper fails to make a return required hereunder, the City Manager or his/her designee shall notify the innkeeper that a determination of deficiency is being undertaken. The notice may be served personally or by United States mail; if by United States mail, the service shall be addressed to the innkeeper at the innkeeper's address as it appears in the records of the City Manager or his/her designee. For service by United States mail of any notice required by this article, the service is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee, or when made by statutory overnight delivery. 
(2)  Time limit for service of notice of intent to determine deficiency. Except for cases involving fraud, intent to evade this article or authorized rules or regulations, or failure to make a return, every notice of intent to make a determination of deficiency shall be served within three years after the due date of the monthly period for which the tax is proposed to be recomputed to determine a deficiency, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. There shall be no limitation upon the time within which notice of intent to make a determination of deficiency must be served for cases involving fraud, intent to evade this article or authorized rules or regulations, or failure to make a return. 
(3)  Response by innkeeper. The innkeeper shall have the right to submit to the City Manager or his/her designee within 30 days of service of the notice of intent to make a determination of deficiency, such documentation in support of the accuracy of its return and the tax remitted therewith as the innkeeper may desire. 
(4)  Determination of tax. 
(a)  Underpayment of tax or irregularity in return. If the City Manager or his/her designee is not satisfied with the return or the amount of tax paid to the City by any innkeeper under this article, the City Manager or his/her designee shall recompute the tax due for each monthly period in question. In recomputing the tax, the City Manager or his/her designee shall make the best and most accurate estimate reasonably practicable based upon the information available to him/her at the time the estimate is made. Said recomputation may be based upon information provided by or obtained from the innkeeper, information contained in previous returns filed by the innkeeper, information regarding occupancy rates contained in the returns for the same period of similarly situated innkeepers, information regarding occupancy rates contained in the returns for the same period of all other innkeepers in the City, taking into account such factors as location, size and other factors as the City Manager or his/her designee may deem appropriate, or some combination of information to arrive at the best and most accurate estimate of tax reasonably practicable. The method and manner of the recomputation shall be within the sole discretion of the City Manager or his/her designee. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the tax due for one or more monthly periods. 
(b)  Failure to make return. If any innkeeper fails to make a return for the tax levied in this article for 30 or more days after the due date of said return, the City Manager or his/her designee shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the innkeeper. The estimate shall be made for the period in respect to which the innkeeper failed to make the return. The City Manager or his/her designee shall make the best and most accurate estimate reasonably practicable based upon the information available to him/her at the time the estimate is made. Said estimate may be based upon information provided by or obtained from the innkeeper, information contained in previous returns filed by the innkeeper, information regarding occupancy rates contained in the returns for the same period of similarly situated innkeepers, information regarding occupancy rates contained in the returns for the same period of all other innkeepers in the City, taking into account such factors as location, size and other factors as the City Manager or his/her designee may deem appropriate, or some combination of information to arrive at the best and most accurate estimate of tax reasonably practicable. The method and manner of the estimate shall be within the sole discretion of the City Manager or his/her designee. Upon the basis of this estimate, the City Manager or his/her designee shall compute and determine the amount of tax required to be paid the City, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty as provided in Section 3-2-56(5). One or more determinations may be made for one or more periods. 
(5)  Interest on deficiency. The unpaid balance of the deficiency, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month or any fraction of a month from the due date for the period in question until the date of payment. 
(6)  Offsetting of overpayments. Whenever the City Manager or his/her designee has made a determination of a deficiency for one or more monthly periods, the City may use overpayments from another or other period(s) to offset such deficiency and any penalties or interest due thereon. 
(7)  Penalty for negligence or disregard for rules and regulations. Should the City Manager or his/her designee determine that any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination has been made is due to negligence or disregard of the provisions of this article or the rules and regulations authorized hereunder, a penalty as provided in Section 3-2-56(5) shall be added thereto. 
(8)  Penalty for fraud or intent to evade. Should the City Manager or his/her designee determine that any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination is made is due to fraud or an intent to evade any section of this article or the rules and regulations authorized hereunder, a penalty of 50 percent of the deficiency will be added thereto. 
(9)  Notice of deficiency, interest and penalty. Should the City Manager or his/her designee make a determination that a deficiency exists, the City Manager or his/her designee shall forthwith notify the innkeeper of the monthly period(s) for which a deficiency was determined, the amount of such deficiency(ies), the date such determination was made, any penalty(ies) or interest applicable to such deficiency(ies) and the date by which the deficiency(ies) and penalty(ies) must be paid. Notice shall be given in the same manner as provided in Subsection (1) of this section for notice of intention to make a determination of deficiency. 
(10)  Innkeeper selling or quitting business. 
(a)  Final return. If any innkeeper liable for any amount under this article sells out his/her business or quits his/her business, he/she shall make a final return and remittance within 15 days after the date of selling or quitting the business. 
(b)  Withholding delinquent tax on sale of business. If any innkeeper liable for any amount under this article transfers or sells its business or quits the business, its successors or assigns shall withhold sufficient amounts from the purchase price to cover the amount required to be paid pursuant to this article until the former owner or operator of the innkeeper produces a receipt from the City Manager or his/her designee showing that the tax and any penalties and interest thereon has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. If the purchaser of a business or innkeeper fails to withhold from the purchase price as required herein such purchaser shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount of the outstanding tax required to be withheld by him to the extent of such purchase price. 
(11)  Collection of deficiency. 
(a)  Security. Whenever an innkeeper shall have failed to substantially comply with the provisions of this article and the City Manager or his/her designee deems it necessary to ensure compliance with this article, the City Manager or his/her designee may require any innkeeper to deposit with the City Manager or his/her designee such security as the City Manager or his/her designee may prescribe. The amount of the security shall be fixed by the City Manager or his/her designee but shall not be greater than twice the innkeeper's estimated average liability for the period for which the innkeeper files returns, determined in such a manner as the City Manager or his/her designee deems proper, or $10,000.00, whichever amount is the lesser. The amount of the security may be increased by the City Manager or his/her designee subject to the limitations provided in this subsection. The City Manager or his/her designee may sell the security at public auction, with the approval of the Mayor and Council, if it becomes necessary to do so in order to recover any tax or any amount required to be collected, interest or penalty due. Notice of the sale may be served upon the innkeeper who deposited the security personally or by mail; if by mail, service shall be given in the same manner as provided in Subsection (1) of this section for notice of intention to make a determination of deficiency and shall be addressed to the innkeeper at the innkeeper's address as it appears in the records of the City Manager or his/her designee. Upon any sale, any surplus above the amounts due shall be returned to the innkeeper who deposited the security. 
(b)  Action for collection. At any time within three years after any tax becomes due and payable and at any time within three years after City Manager or his/her designee shall have determined a deficiency exists, the City Manager or his/her designee may bring an action in the courts of this state, of any other state, or of the United States in the name of the City to collect the amount delinquent, together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(12)  Refunds or credits for overpayment. Whenever any tax or interest has been paid more than once, overpaid, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the City under this article, it may be refunded by the City. If a person or innkeeper determines that he has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the City, he shall have three years from the date of payment to file a claim with the City Manager, in writing, stating the specific ground upon which the claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved by the City, the excess amount paid may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the person or innkeeper by whom it was paid or his administrators, executors or successors in interest as he may direct, or shall be refunded if no amount then remains due and payable. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-57; Ord. No. 706, 5-18-2005) 
Sec. 3-2-58. - Penalty for violation. 
In addition to the interest charges and delinquent penalties specified in this article, any person who: 
(1)  Fails to register as required in this article; 
(2)  Fails to furnish any return or supplemental return required by the City Manager or his/her designee to be made; 
(3)  Renders, makes or verifies a false or fraudulent return or report with intent to defeat or evade the determination of tax due required by this article to be made; 
(4)  Advertises or holds out or states to the public or to any guest, occupant or prospective guest or occupant, directly or indirectly, that the tax or any part thereof levied in this article will be assumed or absorbed by the innkeeper or that it will not be added to the rental charge for a lodging, or that, if added, it or any part thereof will be refunded; or 
(5)  Otherwise violates any provision of this article; 
shall be deemed guilty of an offense pursuant to Section 1-1-8 and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by the Municipal Court for the City in accordance with the limits established by Section 7-103 of the City Charter. Such persons shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which any violation of this article is committed, continued, or permitted by that person and shall be punished accordingly. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-58; Ord. No. 706, 5-18-2005) 
Sec. 3-2-59. - Expenditures; annual report. 
Except as provided in Subsections (1) and (2) of this section, all revenue collected by the City from the tax shall be deposited in the general fund of the City, and the proceeds of the tax may be expended for any purpose for which the City is authorized by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3.8) to spend public funds and shall not be dedicated for any particular purpose. 
(1)  Tourism, conventions and trade shows. 
a.  In each fiscal year during which the tax is collected pursuant to this article, an amount equal to the amount by which the total taxes collected under this article exceed the taxes which would be collected at a rate of four percent for the purpose of: 
1.  Promoting tourism, conventions and trade shows; 
2.  Supporting a facility owned or operated by a State authority for convention and trade show purposes or any other similar or related purposes. 
b.  Amounts expended pursuant to this subsection shall be expended only through a contract or contracts with the State, a Department of State Government, a State Authority, a convention and Visitors Bureau Authority created by local act of the Georgia General Assembly for the City, or a private sector nonprofit organization, or through a contract or contracts with some combination of such entities, except that amounts expended pursuant to this subsection may be so expended in any otherwise lawful manner pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3.8). 
(2)  Nature and wetlands. 
a.  In addition to the amounts required to be expended under Subsection (1) of this section, in each fiscal year during which the tax is collected pursuant to this article, an amount equal to 16 2/3 percent of the total taxes collected at the rate of eight percent for the purpose of constructing, developing, supporting, and operating a nature center, nature park, wetlands education center, or nature museum for educational and recreational purposes or any other similar purposes; 
b.  Amounts which are expended to meet the 16 2/3 percent requirement of this subsection shall not be subject to the provisions of Subsection (1) of this section requiring expenditure through a contract or contracts with certain entities. 
(3)  Annual report. The City Manager or his/her designee shall file with the State Department of Community Affairs an annual report specifying the rate of taxation and amounts collected and expended pursuant to this article in the form and at such times as may be specified by rule of the Department of Community Affairs. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-59; Ord. No. 706, 5-18-2005; Ord. No. 768, 5-21-2008) 
TITLE 4 - LAW ENFORCEMENT 
CHAPTER 1. - POLICE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to provide for police protection, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(1); Georgia Peace Officer Standards and Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq.; municipality's liability for torts of police or other officers, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-3; obstructing law enforcement officer, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-24; giving false names or addresses to officers, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-25; false reports of crime, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-26. 

Sec. 4-1-1. - Chief of Police; powers and duties. 
Under the general direction of the City Manager, the Chief of Police shall direct the administration and operation of all services of the City Police Department including Probation Services, the 911 Center, and Conyer's Security Alert, and shall establish the policies, directives, rules and regulations for the administration and operations of the City Police Department. The policies, directives, rules and regulations shall meet State and national standards, and the Chief shall keep the Police Department nationally accredited and State certified. The Chief of Police shall be responsible for hiring, management and discharging of personnel and labor relations and disciplinary actions of the City Police Department consistent with Departmental rules and regulations and this Code. 
(Code 1990, § 4-1-1; Ord. No. 494, 3-18-1991) 
Sec. 4-1-2. - Patrol powers. 
The officers employed and sworn by the Police Department must be State certified and they have lawful jurisdiction to perform the functions of a law enforcement officer throughout the jurisdiction of the City. 
(Code 1978, § 2-1002; Code 1990, § 4-1-2) 
Secs. 4-1-3—4-1-6. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-1-7. - False alarms. 
(a)  Every establishment or residence within the City limits having an electronic, telephone or mechanical unauthorized intrusion alarm system, including those alarms which are audible or visible on premises, shall be entitled to report a maximum of three false alarms to which the Police Department will respond in the appropriate manner without charge in each month. Any business with multiple buildings on its premises may report a maximum of three false alarms in each month for each building that is wired with a separate alarm system. 
(b)  An administrative fee per false alarm is hereby imposed for the fourth through eighth false alarm received in any month. False alarms received at City Hall in excess of eight per month shall result in an additional fee per false alarm. The amounts of the fees shall be as established by the City Council, from time to time. 
(c)  Whenever four or more alarms in any 30-minute period are received which subsequently turn out to be false alarms, the same shall be conclusive evidence of natural disturbances (such as electrical storms, etc.) City-wide, and no charge shall be imposed by the City nor shall alarms occurring during such period be counted toward the allowance above. 
(d)  Where substantiated by written evidence satisfactory to the Chief of Police from a third party that the false alarm was not caused by the owner/subscriber or the installing alarm company, such a false alarm will not be included in the monthly statistics. 
(e)  A 30-day grace period, during which no alarms will be counted, shall be permitted for each new installation. 
(f)  The investigating Police Officer responding to an alarm shall determine if the alarm is a false alarm. 
(g)  Any person assessed a fee for excessive false alarms under this section may appeal such determination to the City Manager by filing a written notice of appeal within ten days of the date the charges are imposed. Appeal of an adverse decision by the City Manager may be taken to the City Council by filing written notice of appeal within ten days of the manager's decision. The decision of the City Council on any appeal heard by it shall be final. 
(Code 1990, § 4-1-7) 
Sec. 4-1-8. - Workers' compensation for Auxiliary Police Officers. 
All Auxiliary Police Officers who are certified by the Georgia Peace Officer Standards and Training Council, shall be considered City employees for the purpose of providing workers' compensation insurance. 
(Code 1990, § 4-1-8) 
State Law reference— Coverage of volunteer law enforcement personnel authorized, O.C.G.A. § 34-9-1. 
CHAPTER 3. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq.; local governments to provide for emergency management, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27. 

Sec. 4-3-1. - Agency created; purpose. 
The Conyers Defense Emergency Management Agency (hereinafter called the Agency) is hereby created. This Agency (in conjunction with the Rockdale County Emergency Management Agency) is created to organize and train personnel, prepare plans and procedures, and conduct and supervise emergency operations designed to protect lives, minimize damage to property, and provide remedial procedures and any other emergency governmental functions, other than those functions for which the State and Federal governments are responsible, for the protection of life and property in the City in both peacetime and attack-caused emergencies; to provide continuity of local government in emergency and post-emergency periods; to coordinate plans for mutual aid assistance with adjoining local governments; and when directed by the governor or his legal representative, to render aid to other stricken areas in declared emergency periods. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-1; Ord. No. 240A, 12-17-1979) 
Sec. 4-3-2. - Functions of the Agency. 
The Conyers Emergency Management Agency shall provide for the organization, mobilization and direction of the civilian populace and for the protection of public and private property, and provide necessary support to agencies (those agencies required but not available in normal day-to-day operation of the government) to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies, including, but not limited to, energy emergencies, disasters, or the imminent threat thereof, of manmade or natural origin caused by enemy attack, sabotage, acts of domestic or international terrorism, civil disturbance, fire, flood, earthquake, wind, storm, wave action, oil spill or other water contamination requiring emergency action to avert danger or damage, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot or other hostile action, radiological action, or other causes. These functions include, without limitation, warning services, firefighting services, law enforcement services, medical and health services, rescue services, engineering services, communication services, defense from radiological, chemical, biological, and other special weapons to include weapons of mass destruction, welfare services, consequence management functions to include victim services, evacuation services, emergency transportation services, plant and utility protection services, restoration of public utility services, and other functions, where required insofar as can be possible for the protection and well-being of the population of the City and the protection of private and public properties. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-2; Ord. No. 240A, 12-17-1979) 
Sec. 4-3-3. - Existing governmental agencies and auxiliary groups. 
Existing agencies of government shall perform emergency activities related to those which they perform under normal circumstances. Auxiliary groups shall be formed and trained, under the direction and control of the operating department of government which they are designated to support, and nongovernmental groups shall be assigned emergency missions as are necessary to develop their capability to supplement the existing agencies of government in responding to emergencies. The Director of Emergency Management Agency shall coordinate the operations of all such governmental and nongovernmental forces in emergencies, and undertake to make available those unique skills and capabilities not available in existing government organizations. The Director of Emergency Management Agency shall also inform the operating departments of government of those special conditions arising out of a nuclear attack which would call for a modification of departmental operating techniques. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-3; Ord. No. 240A, 12-17-1979) 
Sec. 4-3-4. - Director of Emergency Management Agency. 
The Office of the Director of Emergency Management Agency is hereby created. The Mayor, with the consent of the City Council, shall nominate for appointment by the Governor, a Director, who, upon appointment, shall become an employee of the City Government and Director of the Emergency Management Agency. Upon appointment, the duties of the Director of Emergency Management Agency shall be as follows: 
(1)  To represent the Mayor on all matters pertaining to emergency management and the Emergency Management Agency; 
(2)  To coordinate the development of community-wide emergency preparedness; 
(3)  To develop an emergency and disaster operations plan for effective mobilization of all the resources of the City, both private and public; 
(4)  To prepare and recommend for approval by the City Council mutual aid programs and agreements between other local governments and the City; 
(5)  To prepare and effectuate legal action for continuity of government in the event of emergency; 
(6)  To coordinate and advise government departments in development and implementation of the emergency and disaster operations plan and other required agencies or groups; 
(7)  To procure Federal and State assistance through emergency management channels and through Federal assistance programs in such areas as law enforcement, highway safety, ambulance procurement, or emergency medical services and others. In addition to the above duties, the Director of Emergency Management Agency shall be responsible during an emergency to advise the Mayor in operational situations, public information and privileged information, implementation of the emergency plan, to direct and coordinate the activities of the emergency operation center staff, and to assist the Mayor in ensuring the execution of operations plans and procedures required by the emergency. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-4; Ord. No. 240A, 12-17-1979) 
Sec. 4-3-5. - Organizational structure. 
(a)  The Conyers Emergency Management Agency shall be established around existing City departments and agencies, and organized support forces, as needed to provide for the effective mobilization of all resources of the City, both private and public. 
(b)  Existing government departments, with or without support forces, will be commanded by their regular department executives, who will name for command three successors for emergency operation purposes.
