(c)  Organized support forces of the Emergency Management Agency, which are required by the functions of this Agency (by law and need) will be provided from the populace and will have a Chief Executive, who will name for command three successors for emergency operation purposes. The departments, agencies, organized support forces of emergency management and the Emergency Management Agency will be named, their emergency functions and responsibilities defined in the emergency and disaster operations plan of this City. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-5; Ord. No. 240A, 12-17-1979) 
Sec. 4-3-6. - Personnel. 
All persons, other than officers and employees of the City, performing emergency functions pursuant to this chapter, shall serve with or without compensation. While engaged in such emergency functions, such persons shall have the same immunities as City officers and employees, and shall have full authority, respective to their services, as any officer or employee of the City. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-6; Ord. No. 240A, 12-17-1979) 
Sec. 4-3-7. - Penalties. 
It shall be an offense during an emergency: 
(1)  To willfully obstruct, hinder, or delay any member of emergency management or the Emergency Management Agency or the enforcement of any lawful rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter or in the performance of any duty imposed by any such personnel by virtue of this chapter; 
(2)  To give assistance to the enemy or to imperil the life or property of any inhabitant of this City or to prevent, hinder or delay the defense or protection thereof through the use of any lawful rules or regulations issued pursuant to this chapter; 
(3)  To wear, carry or display without authority any mark or identification specified by emergency management or the Emergency Management Agency. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-7; Ord. No. 240A, 12-17-1979) 
Sec. 4-3-8. - Emergency; special powers. 
(a)  In the event of manmade or natural disaster, mass electrical failure, rioting, actual enemy attack upon the United States or any other emergency which may affect lives and property, the Mayor may declare that a state of emergency exists by written order setting out the circumstances of the emergency, and thereafter the Mayor, or in his/her absence, the Mayor Pro Tem or City Manager, shall have and may exercise for any period as this state of emergency exists or continues, the following emergency powers: 
(1)  To enforce all rules, laws and regulations relating to emergency management and to assume direct operational control over all emergency management resources; 
(2)  To seize, take for temporary use, or condemn any property for the protection of the public; 
(3)  To sell, lend, give or distribute all or any property or supplies among the inhabitants of the City; to maintain a strict accounting of property or supplies distributed and for funds received for the property or supplies; 
(4)  To declare a limited or general curfew as may be needed to restore public order; and 
(5)  To perform and exercise any other functions and duties and take any emergency actions as may be necessary to promote and secure the safety, protection and well-being of the inhabitants of the City. 
(b)  Upon a declaration of an emergency above, the City Council shall immediately be called in to session to perform any duties necessary. 
(c)  The state of emergency and the resulting powers may be ended immediately upon a motion thereon being adopted by the City Council or by an order of the officer declaring the emergency. 
(Code 1978, § 2-3009; Code 1990, § 4-3-8; Ord. No. 802, § 1, 6-16-2010) 
TITLE 5 - PUBLIC WORKS 
CHAPTER 1. - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— City has power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; municipal authority to regulate alleys, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3. 

Sec. 5-1-1. - Removing sand. 
No person shall haul or remove sand from any of the streets or alleys of the City without permission from the City authorities to do so. 
(Code 1978, § 5-2001; Code 1990, § 5-1-1) 
Sec. 5-1-2. - Display of merchandise. 
No person shall use any part of the streets or sidewalks of the City for the display of goods or merchandise; except that the City Council may approve the use of streets and sidewalks by vendors, exhibitors and performers during City-authorized festivals, in accordance with such standards and guidelines as it may establish from time to time. 
(Code 1990, § 5-1-2) 
Sec. 5-1-3. - Obstructions. 
No person shall obstruct, or cause to be obstructed, any of the streets, sidewalks or alleys of the City. 
(Code 1978, § 5-2003; Code 1990, § 5-1-3) 
Sec. 5-1-4. - Street cutting; permit required; fee. 
(a)  No person shall cut into, tear up, or remove, for any purpose, any street or sidewalk paving within the City, without first having filed a written application with the Director of Public Works, and received from the director a written permit for cutting into, tearing up or removing the pavement. 
(b)  The written application shall set forth the location and dimensions of the pavement sought to be removed and for what purpose the cut is to be made. 
(c)  The application shall be accompanied by a fee in sufficient amount to reimburse the City for replacement of the removed pavement and a bond to ensure completion of any work upon the permit holder's failure to do so. 
(d)  The Director of Public Works, upon receipt of the application, fee and bond and is authorized and permitted to issue the applicant a written permit. 
(e)  In lieu of permits for each excavation, any person making multiple cuts or excavations in City streets and sidewalks may secure a blanket permit, accompanied by a blanket bond, to cover all such work in the City. No fee shall be charged for such permits. Prior to making any cut in the pavement under a blanket permit, the permit holder shall notify the Department of Public Works and provide the Department with information as to the size, location and duration of the cut as well as any other information requested by the Department. 
(f)  No person shall cut a larger amount, or remove more pavement than specified in the application, and as set forth in the permit issued by the Clerk, nor cut into, tear up, or remove any other pavement without first having obtained a written permit. 
(g)  The Public Works Department shall supervise and inspect all street cuts authorized by permit hereunder. 
(h)  When any part of any street or sidewalk is torn or dug up for any purpose, the person making that excavation or opening shall have the duty of refilling the excavation or opening so as to restore it to essentially the same condition that existed prior to the excavation or opening. Any person neglecting, refusing or failing to comply with any provisions of this subsection shall be guilty of a violation thereof; and where any neglect, refusal or failure is continued, after notice from the Director of Public Works, every day's continuance thereafter shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation who obtains a permit under this section to do any excavation of any kind which may create or cause a dangerous condition in or near any street or sidewalk without placing and maintaining proper guard rails and signal lights or other warnings at, in or around the work, sufficient to warn the public of any excavation or work, and to protect all persons using reasonable care from injuries on account of the work. 
(Code 1990, § 5-1-4) 
CHAPTER 2. - SOLID WASTE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. 1983, art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq. 

Sec. 5-2-1. - Title and applicability. 
This chapter shall be known as the Conyers Sanitation Ordinance. It shall apply to the preparation, collection, transportation and disposal of all refuse within the corporate limits of the City. It shall prescribe rules and regulations therefor; regulate the private collection of garbage and other refuse; provide for the licensing and regulation of private garbage and refuse collection; waste materials within or through the City; prohibit the deposit of litter on City streets, vacant property or on the property owned or occupied by others, and provide penalties for violation thereof. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-1; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004) 
Sec. 5-2-2. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them by this section, unless the context indicates a different meaning. 
(1)  Approved residential receptacle means a roll cart garbage container provided by the City. 
(2)  Collector means a person, who under agreements, oral or written, with or without compensation, does the work of collecting waste from businesses, institutions or similar locations. The term "collector" does not include an individual collecting or transporting waste from his or her own single-family dwelling unit. 
(3)  Commercial container means a manufactured container suitable for emptying by mechanical equipment and approved by the Director of the Public Works and Transportation Department. 
(a)  All containers must be steel, continuously welded and properly reinforced, or molded plastic and properly reinforced. 
(b)  All lids shall be flanged and reinforced for strength. 
(c)  Pick-up side of container shall be reinforced inside or outside at the point of torque tube contact. 
(d)  Inside reinforcement shall be pressed steel angle. 
(e)  Bottoms shall be reinforced with 1½-inch drain plug installed flush to the bottom. 
(f)  All containers shall be primed and finished with enamel or epoxy paint. 
(g)  Body dimensions as to length and height of container can vary with the size of the container; however: 

 
(4)  Commercial establishment means any hotel, motel, apartment house, roominghouse, business, industry, public or semi-public establishment of any nature or kind whatsoever. 
(5)  Commercial and industrial refuse means waste material from industrial processes, manufacturing canneries, slaughterhouses, packing plants, poultry processing plants, or similar industries, and large quantities of condemned foods. The term "commercial refuse" also includes waste material from the construction, remodeling and repair operations on houses, commercial buildings, multiple dwellings, and other structures such as concrete, bricks, plaster, stone, earth, lumber, roofing materials, gutters, shavings and sawdust. 
(6)  Compactor container means a manufactured commercial container of any size with a self-contained compacting mechanism or an external compactor which is designed to be used in conjunction with a front-loading vehicle other than those used in conjunction with individual home appliances. 
(7)  Garbage means food waste, including waste accumulation of animal or vegetable matter used or intended for use as food, or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables. 
(8)  Hazardous material , as defined in Section 1004(5) of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976 (RCRA), means a solid waste, or combination of solid wastes, which, because of quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics, may: 
1)  Cause or contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious, irreversible, or incapacitating reversible illness; or 
2)  Pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or to the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported or disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
The owner or operator of a facility which treats, stores, manages, or disposes of such materials is required by Section 312 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act (EPCRA) to submit an emergency and hazardous chemical inventory form to the State and to the local Emergency Planning Commission, and is required to submit a MSDS per RCRA. Hazardous materials includes all household hazardous materials in single containerized volumes of five gallons or greater, or uncontainerized improper discharges or deposits of volumes of two or more gallons. 
(9)  Multiple-dwelling unit means a building or portion thereof designed for two or more dwelling units, with the number of families in residence not exceeding the number of dwelling units provided. 
(10)  Owner means any person, firm or corporation owning, leasing, renting, occupying or managing any premises within the jurisdiction of the City. 
(11)  Reserved. 
(12)  Plastic bag means a polyethylene or other heavy-duty plastic bag meeting the National Sanitation Foundation standard of at least 1½ mils and not exceeding a 30-gallon capacity, with securing twist tie. An untied plastic bag shall not be an approved container. 
(13)  Private contractor or commercial sanitation firm means any person, other than a municipality, who collects, removes, salvages or disposes of refuse from one or more public or private premises, other than his or her own, whether or not under written contract, and whether or not for compensation. 
(14)  Putrescible waste means wastes that are capable of being decomposed by microorganisms. Examples of putrescible wastes include, but are not necessarily limited to, kitchen wastes, animal manure, offal, hatchery and poultry processing plant wastes and garbage. 
(15)  Refuse means garbage, rubbish or commercial refuse. 
(16)  Residential dwelling unit means any freestanding structure or shelter or any part thereof used or constructed for use as a residence for one family. 
(17)  Rubbish means waste paper, cartons, boxes, wood, tree branches, yard trimmings, furniture, appliances, metals, cans, glass crockery, dunnage and similar materials. 
(18)  Stationary compactor means an object of a refuse container system which compacts refuse at the site of generation into a pull on detachable container. 
(19)  Yard trimmings means plant material (leaves, grass clippings, branches, brush, flowers, roots, wood waste, etc.); debris commonly thrown away in the course of maintaining yards and gardens, including sod; and biodegradable or compostable waste approved for the yard trimmings programs. It excludes loose soils; food waste; plastics and synthetic fibers; lumber; any wood or tree limbs over four inches in diameter or three feet in length; human or animal excrement; soil contaminated with hazardous materials; and all matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance by a professional contractor. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-2; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004; Ord. No. 714, 11-16-2005) 
Sec. 5-2-3. - Administration and enforcement of chapter; Inspectors. 
(1)  The Director of Public Works and Transportation Department shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. He/she may call upon the Chief of Police and the Director of the County Public Health for assistance in its enforcement. All regulatory actions of the Director shall be subject to review and approval by the City Manager and by the City Council. 
(2)  The City Manager shall have the right to appoint Sanitation Inspectors within the Public Works and Transportation Department who shall have authority, and whose duty it shall be, to make routine inspections of all containers and collection areas and determine the serviceability and condition of the containers and collection areas. These Inspectors, upon determining that a container or area is becoming or has become unserviceable or unsanitary or likely to cause an unsanitary condition, shall issue a notice to the owner of the premises upon which the container or condition exists to inform the person of the unsanitary condition. It shall be the duty of the Inspector to issue a summons directed to the owner to whom the notice has been issued and who has failed to take corrective action within a reasonable time as determined by the Director of Public Works and Transportation Department to appear in the Municipal Court to answer the change of violation of the appropriate section of this chapter. 
(3)  Inspectors appointed by the City Manager shall have the authority to enforce all the provisions of this chapter and shall issue a summons to any violator of any provision of this chapter to appear in the Municipal Court to answer to the charge of violation. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-3; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004; Ord. No. 714, 11-16-2005) 
State Law reference— Municipal power to authorize any of municipality's officers, agents, and employees to serve any process, summons, notice, or order on all persons for municipal violations, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2. 
Sec. 5-2-4. - Preparation and storage of residential refuse for collection; placement of certain refuse for collection prohibited. 
It shall be the duty of the owner of any premises to keep all refuse pending collection and disposal as follows: 
(1)  All garbage shall be free from liquid and placed in watertight paper or plastic bags and the tops secured and placed in an approved refuse receptacle. Receptacles adequate to hold the refuse normally accumulating between scheduled removals shall be provided on each premises. 
(2)  Other household refuse and other nonputrescible waste will be containerized in approved refuse receptacles or in disposable containers such as a box, watertight paper bag or plastic bag. No such refuse, refuse containers, or rubbish shall be placed or piled on the curb in a location or manner as to impede passengers of commercial passenger vehicles from boarding or departing from vehicles at places designated for vehicles to stop or let passengers on or off. 
(3)  Tree branches and heavy brush shall be cut in lengths not exceeding four feet in length completely trimmed, stacked in a compact pile on the curb, or property line in the case of streets where curbing has not been installed, in front of the residence, but such piles shall not extend into the street or be laid upon the sidewalk. Sticks, hedge clippings and small brush shall be gathered together into bundles and tied securely so that each bundle does not exceed four feet in length nor weigh more than 50 pounds. No such container, tree branches or heavy brush shall be placed or piled on the curb in a location or manner as to impede passengers of commercial passenger vehicles from boarding or departing from vehicles at places designated for vehicles to stop or let passengers on or off. The City will not collect logs and limbs over four feet long and will not collect stumps that weigh 50 pounds or more. 
(4)  Leaves, limbs, grass or other trimmings shall be placed in an orderly manner so as not to obstruct the free and normal flow of any drainage system or the safe vision or movement of any system or the safe vision or movement of any pedestrian or vehicular traffic. Such debris shall not be placed in the gutter of any roadway at any time. Shrubbery clippings, vines, briars and other running plants must be separated from all other leaf and limbs placed near the street for collection. Dirt, rocks, grass roots and other plant roots containing soil shall not be collected. 
(5)  Items placed on vacant lots. Leaves or limbs put on vacant lots by owners or violators shall not be collected by the City Public Works and Transportation Department crews. 
(6)  Placement of items by persons other than the owners of the property. Limbs cut and placed near the street for collection by any person other than the owner of the property shall not be collected or hauled by the City Public Works and Transportation Department. Individuals or companies under contract to collect leaves, limbs or removal of trees shall haul and dispose of all such refuse. This requirement also applies to utility or railroad companies which trim vegetation away from wires, equipment or tracks to maintain their right-of-way. Should an owner desire more than one cart, the owner may apply for additional carts by completing a request form at the Department of Customer Service. The owner must pay a minimum deposit of the present cost of a cart, plus an additional yearly sanitation fee. 
(7)  Noncombustible trash, except as provided under Subsection (10) of this section, and liquids will not be collected by the City and shall be disposed of by other means. 
(8)  All refuse receptacles shall be kept clean and free of accumulated waste and shall be treated with an effective insecticide if necessary to prevent nuisance by owner or owners of property. 
(9)  Each owner shall prevent, or otherwise be held responsible for, unsightly accumulations of refuse upon the property occupied by the owner or public thoroughfares adjoining his or her property. 
(10)  Pet litter, disposable diapers and similar waste must be contained in a securely tied plastic bag and placed in a trash container at the curb. 
(11)  It shall be a violation of this chapter to place, or cause to be placed, any hazardous waste, including, without limitation, any acid, explosive material, inflammable liquids, or dangerous or corrosive material of any kind in any refuse can or container for collection. 
(12)  Inoperative or worn out privately used household appliances such as refrigerators, stoves, washing machines, dryers, or discarded furniture will be collected at the curb on an on-call basis to the Public Works and Transportation Department. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-4; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004; Ord. No. 714, 11-16-2005) 
State Law reference— Yard trimmings disposal, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-40.2. 
Sec. 5-2-5. - Preparation and storage of commercial and multiple-dwelling unit refuse for collection. 
(1)  Before a building permit shall be issued for construction of a commercial establishment, condominium or multiple-dwelling, arrangements for storage of refuse and location of containers must be approved by the Director of Public Works and Transportation Department. 
(2)  Commercial containers used. The owners of residential or multiple-dwellings units not located on a publicly owned or maintained street in the City, or of a commercial establishment may be furnished commercial containers at the discretion of the City in sufficient number to adequately contain the garbage and refuse disposal at such location. The type, size, number and location of such location of such commercial containers required shall be subject to the approval of the Public Works and Transportation Department. 
(3)  Commercial containers serviced by the City collection vehicles shall be placed at locations approved by the Public Works and Transportation Department. The City will not collect refuse from commercial establishments, or owners of residential or multiple dwelling units not located on a publicly owned or maintained street in the City unless it is placed in commercial containers, properly located, except where space or other limitations dictate other arrangements which shall be specifically approved by the Director of Public Works and Transportation Department. 
(4)  Where the owners of two or more commercial establishments share the use of containers, it shall be the joint responsibility of the owners to maintain the area surrounding such cans or containers clean and free of accumulations of refuse. 
(5)  The owner or owners of commercial establishments or owners of residential or multiple dwelling units not located on a publicly owned or maintained street in the City serviced by commercial containers shall be responsible for maintaining the area surrounding the commercial containers clean and free of accumulations of refuse. 
(6)  All garbage and rubbish shall be free of liquid and placed in watertight paper or plastic bags with the tops secured prior to placing in commercial containers. 
(7)  Cardboard boxes shall be flattened before being placed in containers. 
(8)  Commercial containers containing the following items will not be emptied until they are removed therefrom: 
a.  Large household or industrial appliances; 
b.  Furniture; 
c.  Tires; 
d.  Wooden pallets; 
e.  Any brush, logs or limbs; 
f.  Bed springs and mattresses; 
g.  Rock, dirt, concrete blocks, sheetrock, lumber or other building materials. 
(9)  Maintenance of container. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or owners to maintain all garbage and trash containers serving his or her property in a clean and sanitary manner, free of obnoxious odors, maggots, insects and rodents, or any other conditions which may render them unhealthy in compliance with State and County health code requirements. 
(10)  The owner or owners of commercial containers shall be responsible for the appearance and serviceability of containers procured by them or placed for their use. 
(11)  The City will continue to empty containers presently in use subject to their serviceability as determined by the Director of Public Works and Transportation Department. All commercial containers put into service after enactment of this chapter shall meet the requirements set forth under Section 5-2-2, and shall have a capacity of not less than two cubic yards nor more than eight cubic yards. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-5; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004; Ord. No. 714, 11-16-2005) 
Sec. 5-2-6. - Collection of refuse generally; conditions for collection by the City. 
(1)  Refuse shall be collected and disposed of by the City or any person or commercial sanitation firm when under contract to the City. 
(2)  The City will collect refuse under the following conditions: 
(a)  Roll cart service will be provided twice each week as further described in Section 5-2-7. 
(b)  Refuse will be collected from residences not entitled to roll cart service and commercial establishments as often as the Director of Public Works and Transportation Department determines is necessary; however, refuse shall not be collected from commercial establishments more than once a day, unless authorized by the Director of Public Works and Transportation Department. 
(c)  Dead animals, other than dogs and house pets, shall not be collected. All dead dogs and house pets will be collected only from curbside and public rights-of-way. Dead house pets shall be in a plastic bag and placed at the curb. They will be collected on an on-call basis to Public Works and Transportation Department. Large dead animals shall be disposed of by the individual concerned. The City has no responsibility to supply service for the removal and disposal of large dead animals. 
(3)  Collection service shall be discontinued where containers are inadequate or have been condemned as unfit by a sanitary inspector, and notice of same has been given to the owner or owners of the premises who has refused to correct the situation then existing. 
(4)  The City shall not be responsible for collecting or hauling discarded building material, dirt or rock from private property; nor shall it be responsible for collecting or hauling trees, bushes, or other vegetation from or generated by commercial tree trimmers, landscapers or building contractors. 
(5)  Appliances such as, but not limited to, air conditioners, stoves, refrigerators, freezers, washers and dryers will be collected upon notice to the City. 
(6)  City collectors will remove properly prepared residential trash from the curbside only. 
(7)  The City will not collect junk autos or discarded parts thereof. These items shall be disposed of by other means by the respective owner concerned. 
(8)  Commercial establishments may be provided roll cart service when the commercial establishment is located on a publicly owned or maintained street in the City. Such provision of service shall be authorized by the Director of Public Works and Transportation Department. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-6; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004; Ord. No. 714, 11-16-2005) 
Sec. 5-2-7. - Roll cart system. 
(1)  Applicability . The provisions of this section apply only to the roll cart system. Except as provided herein, the roll cart system shall be the only approved system for use by owners of residential or multiple-dwelling units located on a publicly owned or maintained streets in the City. 
(2)  Cart property of City . The roll carts shall remain the property of the City and will be assigned to an owner for the health, safety, convenience and general welfare of the owner. 
(3)  Placement of garbage to be collected . The person having authority to control the disposal of garbage in any household shall cause all garbage collected therein to be placed in a roll cart supplied or specified by the City and placed at the curb on scheduled collection days as set forth herein below, except for those persons who are physically unable to do so as determined by a physician and have made application and have been approved for exemption of curb collection by the Public Works and Transportation Department. 
(4)  Weight . The combined weight of a roll cart and its contents shall not exceed 200 pounds, and the roll cart shall not be filled to overflowing. 
(5)  Identification . Where service is provided to multiple-dwelling units, the roll carts shall be marked by the City so as to indicate the owner using the particular roll cart. The roll cart may be identified by putting the street number thereon or the name of the owner. When roll carts are so identified, such roll cart may be used only by the owner whose name or other identification is shown thereon. 
(6)  Lost, stolen or damaged roll carts . Any residential roll cart provided by the City that becomes lost, stolen or damaged shall be replaced by the owner at a rate fixed by the City. Roll carts that are damaged through normal usage shall be repaired or replaced by the City. 
(7)  Location of roll carts . On collection day, roll carts provided to residences by the City as provided in Subsection (1) of this section shall be placed in the area between the sidewalk and curb adjacent to a publicly owned and maintained street in the City, or in an accessible place approved by the Public Works and Transportation Department. Roll carts shall not be placed at curbside before 7:00 p.m. on the day preceding the collection day and shall be removed from the curbside before 7:00 p.m. on the collection day. When roll carts are not in the curbside location on collection days, all roll carts shall be placed within ten feet of the dwelling unit. Exceptions to this requirement may be requested from the Public Works and Transportation Department for a person with physical limitations which prevent placement of the roll carts at the curb, provided such person submits a written request for an exception. 
(8)  Time of collection . The Public Works and Transportation Department shall provide a schedule to each residence receiving garbage collection service from the City that shall indicate the days on which such collection will be made. 
(9)  Garbage . As defined in Section 5-2-2(7). 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-7; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004; Ord. No. 714, 11-16-2005; Ord. No. 893, § 1, 10-3-2012) 
Sec. 5-2-8. - Regulation of private transportation of refuse. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person, including City collectors and sanitary contractors, to haul, convey or cause to be conveyed, any refuse, including discarded building material or discarded furniture, upon or along the public streets or roadways except when the material transported is adequately secured in such a manner as to prevent it from falling, leaking or being blown from transporting vehicles. The operator or owner of the offending vehicle shall be personally responsible for any violation of this section. 
(2)  It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to collect and haul any refuse other than that rising from his or her own accumulation without first obtaining an occupation registration from the City. In lieu of requiring an occupation registration for private refuse collectors, the City may contract with a private person, firm or corporation to provide refuse collection throughout the City. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-8; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004) 
Sec. 5-2-9. - Disposal of refuse. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to dump, or to cause to be dumped, any garbage, refuse, litter, junk, appliances, equipment, cans, bottles, paper, lumber, trees, tree limbs, brush or parts thereof, anywhere in the City without the express approval by resolution of the City Council under such terms and conditions as may be contained therein to protect the health, safety and well-being of the City. 
(2)  The provisions of Subsection (1) of this section do not apply to the dumping on private property with the owner's permission of sand, dirt, broken brick, blocks or broken pavement or other suitable materials for use as fill to raise the elevation of the land, provided the same is not maintained in an unsightly condition and provided the owner of the property on which the material is dumped agrees to level the dumped material with appropriate grading equipment, and to cover it with dirt upon direction of the Department of Planning and Inspection Services and/or the Department of Public Works and Transportation. 
(3)  If any of the material dumped in violation of the provisions of Subsection (1) of this section can be identified as having last belonged to, been in the possession of, sent to or received by, or to have been the property of any person, firm or corporation prior to its being dumped as prohibited herein, then such identification shall be presumed to be prima facie evidence that the owner dumped or caused to be dumped the matter and material in violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-9; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004; Ord. No. 714, 11-16-2005) 
Sec. 5-2-10. - Sanitary fee; assessment and payment. 
(1)  Persons entitled to roll cart system service as further described in Sections 5-2-7 and 5-2-8 shall be required to subscribe to the City's solid waste collection and disposal service. All other persons may make application to the City for service subject to the terms of service set forth in the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
(2)  Persons entitled to roll cart system service as further described in Sections 5-2-7 and 5-2-8 shall pay to the City an annual collection charge in an amount to be determined from time to time by the Mayor and City Council for collection. Those persons entitled to roll cart service and conducting a home occupation in that dwelling unit shall pay to the City an additional annual collection charge in an amount to be determined from time to time by the Mayor and City Council. The collection charge set forth herein shall be billed annually on the tax bill of the record owner of the property as of January 1 of each year. Collection charges shall be prorated as to the date on which collection services began for such newly built residences and shall be billed at the time such collection services begin. 
(3)  Upon application therefor, the annual residential collection charge set forth in Subsection (2) of this section for any owner whose annual income from all sources, including income from other household members, but excluding social security income or income or benefits which are received as retirement, survivors or disability benefits under the Federal Social Security Act or any other public or private retirement, disability or pension system does not exceed $8,000.00 and who is over 62 years of age, totally disabled and owns property shall be determined from time to time by the Mayor and City Council. 
(4)  Commercial container collection charges. A per cubic yard commercial container collection charge shall be determined from time to time by the Mayor and City Council; provided, however that the City Manager, or his or her designee, may negotiate such per cubic yard per collection fee with the owner of a commercial establishment based on the amount of refuse to be collected, hauled and disposed of and the rates of other commercial sanitation haulers operating within the City. Such commercial sanitation charges shall be billed monthly. The term "cubic yard" means the size of the container provided. 
(5)  The owners of commercial establishments may not share commercial containers; provided, however, that the owners of commercial establishments may make a written request to the Public Works and Transportation Department requesting that they be allowed to share dumpster service. The Public Works and Transportation Department may grant such request upon the showing of special circumstances by the requesting parties. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-10; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004; Ord. No. 714, 11-16-2005) 
Sec. 5-2-11. - Litter control. 
No person shall place refuse in any street, alley or other public place, or upon any private property, whether owned by such person or not, within the City, except as prescribed by this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-11; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004) 
Sec. 5-2-12. - Penalties and interest. 
(1)  Any violation of this chapter shall be unlawful and is punishable, upon conviction, as provided in Section 7-103 of the City Charter. Each day in violation shall be a separate offense. 
(2)  Interest shall be charged at the legal rate of 1½ percent on accounts for garbage collection services which have been due and payable for 30 days or more. Such interest shall be calculated on the amount owed from the date upon which such accounts became due and payable until such accounts are paid. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-12; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004) 
Sec. 5-2-13. - Collection of delinquent fees. 
In addition to the other remedies herein provided for the collection of fees charged herein, the City Manager or his/her designee shall be authorized to enforce the collection of such fees in the same manner as authorized by law for the enforcement of the collection and payment of State taxes, fees or assessments. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-13; Ord. No. 629, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 701, 11-3-2004) 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to enforce collection of solid waste fees or assessments in the same manner as authorized by law for the enforcement of the collection and payment of state taxes, fees, or assessments, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-39.3. 
CHAPTER 3. - CEMETERIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Cemetery and Funeral Services Act of 2000, O.C.G.A. § 10-14-1 et seq.; city as trustee of cemetery funds, O.C.G.A. § 36-37-4 et seq. 

Sec. 5-3-1. - Excavations and digging graves. 
The excavation and digging of graves in City-owned cemeteries shall only be done by a licensed contractor with the permission of the Director of Public Works in accordance with regulations of the Department of Public Works. 
(Code 1990, § 5-3-1; Ord. No. 314, 4-18-1983) 
Sec. 5-3-2. - Grave site use and restoration. 
(a)  No interment shall be made in any City cemetery without the use of a vault approved by the Director of Public Works. 
(b)  All closed grave sites shall be compacted, landscaped and reseeded. The type of sod or seeding must be similar to that used in the surrounding area and shall be approved by the Director of Public Works. 
(c)  All excess excavated material shall be removed from the cemetery or prepared and placed in a location within the cemetery approved by the Director of Public Works. 
(d)  All lots finished with gravel topping must be prepared with a plastic barrier of five mils placed over the site prior to placing of the gravel. 
(e)  All constructed grave edging must be approved by department of public works before work begins. All finished work must possess a neat and orderly appearance and be properly positioned on such site in accordance with approved plans. 
(Code 1990, § 5-3-2) 
Sec. 5-3-3. - Night activities prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to be on the grounds of any cemetery within the City during the hours from sundown to sunrise without the express authorization from the City. 
(b)  This provision shall be posted on the grounds of all cemeteries within the City. 
(Code 1990, § 5-3-3; Ord. No. 231, 8-7-1979) 
Sec. 5-3-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 884, § 1, adopted July 18, 2012, repealed § 5-3-4 which pertained to flowers, plantings and decorative installations, and derived from § 5-3-4 of the 1990 Code. 
Sec. 5-3-5. - Decorum. 
Loud conversation in the cemetery shall not be permitted. All workers shall cease operation while in the immediate vicinity of an interment. 
(Code 1990, § 5-3-5) 
Sec. 5-3-6. - Cemetery rules and regulations. 
The "Cemetery Rules and Regulations" of the City, adopted by Ordinance No. 884 on July 18, 2012 is hereby incorporated by reference into this Code and made a part hereof as if fully set forth herein. A current copy of the Cemetery Rules and Regulations shall be maintained on file in the Office of the City Clerk, where they shall be available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 884, § 2, 7-18-2012) 
CHAPTER 4. - TREE PROTECTION 

Sec. 5-4-1. - Definitions. 
The term "street trees" are herein defined as trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues, or ways within the City. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-1) 
Sec. 5-4-2. - Creation and establishment of a City Tree Board. 
There is hereby created and established a City Tree Board for the City which shall consist of five members, citizens and residents of this City, who shall be appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the City Council. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-2) 
Sec. 5-4-3. - Term of office. 
The term of the five persons to be appointed by the Mayor shall be three years. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-3) 
Sec. 5-4-4. - Compensation. 
Members of the Board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-4) 
Sec. 5-4-5. - Duties and responsibilities. 
It shall be the responsibility of the Board to study, investigate, counsel, and develop and/or update annually, and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs, along streets and in other public areas. Such plan will be presented annually to the City Council and upon their acceptance and approval shall constitute the official Comprehensive City Tree Plan. The Board, when requested by the City Council, shall consider, investigate, make finding, report and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-5) 
Sec. 5-4-6. - Operation. 
The Board shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-6) 
Sec. 5-4-7. - Spacing. 
The spacing of street trees may not be closer together than the following: small trees, 30 feet; medium trees, 40 feet; large trees, 50 feet; except in special plantings designed or approved by a landscape architect. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-7) 
Sec. 5-4-8. - Distance from curb and sidewalk. 
The distance trees may be planted from the curbs or curblines and sidewalks shall not be closer than the following: small trees, two feet; medium trees, three feet; large trees, four feet. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-8) 
Sec. 5-4-9. - Distance from street corners and fire hydrants. 
No street tree shall be planted closer than 35 feet from any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet from any fire hydrant. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-9) 
Sec. 5-4-10. - Utilities. 
No street tree may be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-10) 
Sec. 5-4-11. - Public tree care. 
(a)  The City shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, and public grounds, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. 
(b)  The City Tree Board may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of said trees is in accordance with Sections 5-4-7 through 5-4-10. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-11) 
Sec. 5-4-12. - Tree topping. 
It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm, or City Department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this section at the determination of the City Tree Board. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-12) 
Sec. 5-4-13. - Pruning; corner clearance. 
Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the City shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street light or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The City shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-13) 
Sec. 5-4-14. - Removal of dead or diseased trees. 
The City shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the City, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the City. The City Tree Board will notify in writing the owners of such trees. Removal shall be done by said owners at their own expense within 60 days after the date of service of the notice. In the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the City shall have the authority to remove such trees and charge the cost of removal to the owners. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-14) 
Sec. 5-4-15. - Removal of healthy trees. 
Whenever a nondiseased tree of greater than 24 inches in diameter at the base of the tree is voluntarily removed from any property within the City limits, at least one sapling must be placed on the same property. Placement of the new tree must occur within six months of completion of the construction or other project which caused the removal of the original tree. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-15) 
Sec. 5-4-16. - Interference with City Tree Board. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay, or interfere with the City Tree Board, or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees, park trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-16) 
Sec. 5-4-17. - Arborist's license and bond. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating, or removing street or park trees within the City without first procuring a license. The license fee shall be paid annually in advance; provided, however, that no license shall be required of any public service company or City employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public service endeavors. Before any license shall be issued, each applicant shall first file evidence of possession of liability insurance in the minimum amounts of $50,000.00 for bodily injury and $100,000.00 property damage indemnifying the City or any persons injured or damage resulting from the pursuit of such endeavors as herein described. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-17) 
Sec. 5-4-18. - Review by City Council. 
The City Council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts, and decisions of the City Tree Board. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the City Tree Board to the City Council who may hear the matter and make a final decision. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-18) 
Sec. 5-4-19. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be, upon conviction or a plea of guilty, subject to a fine not to exceed $100.00. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-19) 
CHAPTER 5. - SPEED BREAKER DISTRICTS 

Sec. 5-5-1. - Establishment of speed breaker districts. 
(1)  A speed breaker district may be established within the City upon presentation of a petition to the City Manager or his/her designee by 75 percent or more of the property owners within such proposed speed breaker district. The petition requesting a speed breaker district shall contain at a minimum the names, addresses and phone numbers (work and home) of each person signing such petition. The petition shall be in such form as prescribed by the City Manager or his/her designee from time to time. 
(2)  Once a petition has been filed with the City, the Department of Public Works and Transportation will conduct a verification process prior to any evaluation of the appropriateness of a speed breaker district. After the verification process has been completed, the Department of Public Works and Transportation will conduct an evaluation to determine if the street(s) are eligible for speed breakers and if they would function properly. After such evaluation, the Department of Public Works and Transportation shall make a recommendation to the Council as to whether a speed breaker district should be established. 
(Code 1990, § 5-5-1) 
Sec. 5-5-2. - Definition of speed breaker districts. 
A "speed breaker district" is defined as a street, or portion of a street, or a system of streets within the City where speed breakers have been requested and/or installed. 
(Code 1990, § 5-5-2) 
Sec. 5-5-3. - Criteria governing the establishment of speed districts. 
(1)  Speed breakers will only be considered on streets categorized as residential. 
(2)  Speed breakers should only be used with no more than two traveled lanes. 
(3)  Speed breakers should not be placed within severe horizontal or vertical curves. The geometrics of the street must satisfy current residential guidelines. 
(4)  Street grade must be less than eight percent. 
(5)  Speed breakers should generally be installed where minimum safe stopping distance is available. 
(6)  Speed studies may be performed to confirm the existence of a speeding problem and also to ensure that breaker installation will address the problem. 
(7)  Average daily traffic volume should be between 200 to 1,000 vehicles. Placement of breakers outside this range will require special evaluation. 
(8)  Speed breakers should not be installed on a street that carries a significant number (greater than five percent) of long wheelbase vehicles unless a reasonable alternative exists for these vehicles. 
(9)  Speed breakers should not be installed on streets that are used as primary emergency vehicle access unless a reasonable alternative exists for these vehicles. 
(10)  The type of speed breaker to be installed will be a flat-topped speed breaker. 
(11)  The maximum posted speed limit on any street requesting speed breakers will be 35 miles per hour. 
(12)  Adequate signing and marking at each speed breaker location shall be required. 
(Code 1990, § 5-5-3) 
Sec. 5-5-4. - Reassessment of speed breaker districts. 
(1)  The City will reassess the need for a speed breaker district upon presentation of a petition to the City Manager or his/her designee by 75 percent or more of the property owners within such speed breaker district, to determine if any reason exists to remove the speed breakers from the speed breaker district. The petition requesting a reassessment of a speed breaker district shall contain at a minimum the names, addresses and phone numbers (work and home) of each person signing such petition. The petition shall be in such form as prescribed by the City Manager or his/her designee from time to time. 
(2)  Once a petition has been filed with the City, the Department of Public Works and Transportation will conduct a verification process prior to any reassessment of the speed breaker district. After the verification process has been completed, the Department of Public Works and Transportation will conduct an engineering analysis to determine the traffic characteristics along the route and impact to the remaining street system. After an adequate review period of the engineering analysis, the City will make a determination as to whether to remove the speed breaker from the speed breaker district. 
(Code 1990, § 5-5-4) 
Sec. 5-5-5. - Approval by the Council. 
No speed breaker district shall be established or removed without the approval of the Council. 
(Code 1990, § 5-5-5) 
CHAPTER 6. - SIDEWALK INSTALLATIONS 

Sec. 5-6-1. - Sidewalk installations. 
(1)  Upon written request for the installation of a sidewalk made by a property owner located on an existing City street and filed with the City, the City Manager or his/her designee shall conduct an evaluation to determine the appropriateness of the requested sidewalk installation. This evaluation shall include, but may not necessarily be limited to, a consideration of the factors set forth in Section 5-6-3. 
(2)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall provide a written response to the property owner which filed the request for the installation of a sidewalk advising the property owner of the results of the evaluation of the appropriateness of the requested sidewalk installation. 
(3)  If the results of the evaluation regarding the appropriateness of the requested sidewalk installation indicate that the installation of the requested sidewalk may be appropriate, the property owner who filed the request, or any other property owner located on the City street which is the subject of the request, must present a petition to the City Manager or his/her designee which is signed by 100 percent of the property owners located on the involved City street in order for the request for the installation of a sidewalk to be further considered. 
(4)  The petition requesting that a sidewalk be installed shall contain the names, addresses, and telephone numbers (work and home) of each property owner signing such petition. If more than one property owner exists for a particular parcel of property, all owners must sign the petition. The petition shall be in such form as prescribed by the City Manager or his/her designee. 
(5)  The petition requesting that a sidewalk be installed shall contain an acknowledgement that each owner of each parcel of property located on the involved City street is willing to provide, at no cost to the City, an easement in favor of the City if the requested sidewalk will be placed on a portion of the property owner's property that is not part of an existing City right-of-way. 
(6)  Once a petition signed by 100 percent of the property owners located on the involved City street has been filed with the City, the City Manager or his/her designee shall conduct a verification process. The purpose of this process shall be to verify that all parcels of property located on the involved street are represented in said petition, that all property owners of each parcel of property have signed the petition, and that the persons who signed the petition as the property owners are in fact the owners of such property as reflected in the records of the Clerk of Superior Court of the County. 
(Code 1990, § 5-6-1; Ord. No. 652, 11-7-2001) 
Sec. 5-6-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Property owner means the record title holder of the property as reflected in the real estate records of the Clerk of the County Superior Court. 
(2)  Sidewalk installations means the construction of a concrete walkway along an existing street, or portion of an existing street, which is located within the City. 
(Code 1990, § 5-6-2; Ord. No. 652, 11-7-2001) 
Sec. 5-6-3. - Criteria governing the evaluation of a request for the installation of sidewalks. 
In evaluating the appropriateness of a request for the installation of a sidewalk, the following criteria shall be considered by the City Manager or his/her designee: 
(1)  Streets in residential areas of the City shall receive priority consideration for the installation of sidewalks; 
(2)  The willingness of all property owners who are requesting the installation of a sidewalk to provide, at no cost to the City, an easement in favor of the City if the requested sidewalk will be placed on a portion of the property owner's property that is not part of an existing City right-of-way; 
(3)  The slope of the involved City street; 
(4)  The feasibility of the requested sidewalk in light of any existing trees, power poles, and other impediments in the path of the requested sidewalk; 
(5)  The ability to install the requested sidewalk at least two feet from the shoulder of the existing street; 
(6)  The ability to install a sidewalk that is at least four to five feet in width and at least four inches thick; 
(7)  The maximum posted speed limit on the involved City street. Sidewalks shall not be favored on any street where the maximum posted speed limit is in excess of 45 miles per hour; 
(8)  Any applicable budgetary constraints of the City; 
(9)  Such other information as the City Manager or his/her designee deems relevant in evaluating whether a sidewalk should be installed in the requested area. 
(Code 1990, § 5-6-3; Ord. No. 652, 11-7-2001) 
Sec. 5-6-4. - Approval or denial of petition by City Manager; review of City Manager's decision by the City Council. 
(1)  The installation of a sidewalk requested under this chapter shall not be authorized without the approval of the City Manager. The City Manager shall notify the petitioner(s) in writing of the approval or denial of their petition for the installation of a sidewalk. 
(2)  In the event that any petition meeting all of the criteria set forth in Section 5-6-1 is denied by the City Manager, the petitioner(s) may request that the City Council review the petition and the City Manager's denial of same by filing a written request for such a review with the City Manager within 30 days of the date of the denial of the petition by the City Manager. 
(3)  The City Council's decision after any such review shall be final. 
(Code 1990, § 5-6-4; Ord. No. 652, 11-7-2001) 
CHAPTER 7. - LITTER CONTROL[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Litter Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40 et seq. 

ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 5-7-1. - Title. 
This chapter shall be known and may be recited as the Litter Control Ordinance. 
(Code 1990, § 5-7-1; Ord. No. 740, 12-6-2006) 
Sec. 5-7-2. - Applicability. 
This chapter shall apply to all public and private property within the corporate limits of the City. 
(Code 1990, § 5-7-2; Ord. No. 740, 12-6-2006) 
Sec. 5-7-3. - Compatibility with other regulations. 
This chapter is not intended to interfere with, abrogate, or annul any other ordinance, rule or regulation, stature, or other provision of law. The requirements of this chapter should be considered minimum requirements, and where any provision of this chapter imposes restrictions different from those imposed by any other ordinance, rule or regulation, or other provision of law, whichever provisions are more restrictive or impose higher protective standards for human health or the environment shall be considered to take precedence. 
(Code 1990, § 5-7-3; Ord. No. 740, 12-6-2006) 
Sec. 5-7-4. - Definitions. 
When used in this chapter, the following words and phrases have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, unless the context indicates a different meaning: 
(a)  Reserved. 
(b)  Litter means any organic or inorganic waste material, rubbish, refuse, garbage, trash, hulls, peelings, debris, grass, weeds, ashes, sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, metal, plastic, and glass containers, broken glass, dead animals or intentionally or unintentionally discarded materials of every kind and description that are not hazardous waste as such term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-7-51(6). 
(c)  Public or private property means the right-of-way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse or the shores or beaches thereof; any park, playground, building, refuge, or conservation or recreation area; timberlands or forests; and residential, commercial, industrial, or farm properties. 
(Code 1990, § 5-7-4; Ord. No. 740, 12-6-2006) 
Sec. 5-7-5. - Prohibition against littering public or private property or waters. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to dump, deposit, throw or leave or to cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing or leaving of litter on any public or private property in the City or any waters in the City unless: 
(a)  The property is designated by the State or by any of its agencies or political subdivisions for the disposal of such litter, and such person is authorized by the proper public authority to use such property; 
(b)  The litter is placed into a receptacle or container, which is designed for that purpose, that is installed on such property; or 
(c)  The person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, or has first obtained consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession, or unless the act is done under the personal direction of the owner or tenant, all in a manner consistent with the public welfare. 
(Code 1990, § 5-7-5; Ord. No. 740, 12-6-2006) 
Sec. 5-7-6. - Vehicle loads causing litter. 
No person shall operate any motor vehicle with a load on or in such vehicle unless the load on or in such vehicle is adequately secured to prevent the dropping or shifting of materials from such load onto the roadway. A failure to so adequately secure said load shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 5-7-6; Ord. No. 740, 12-6-2006) 
ARTICLE B. - VIOLATIONS, ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 5-7-7. - Violations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this chapter. Any person who has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this chapter may be subject to the enforcement actions outlined in this article or may be restrained by injunction or otherwise sentenced in a manner provided by law. 
(Code 1990, § 5-7-7; Ord. No. 740, 12-6-2006) 
Sec. 5-7-8. - Evidence. 
(a)  Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane, or other conveyance in violation of this chapter, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of the conveyance has violated this chapter. 
(b)  Except as provided in Subsection (a) of this section, whenever any litter which is dumped, deposited, thrown or left on public or private property in violation of this chapter is discovered to contain any article or articles, including but not limited to letters, bills, publications or other writing which display the name of the person thereon in such a manner as to indicate that the article belongs or belonged to such person, it shall be a rebuttable presumption that such person has violated this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 5-7-8; Ord. No. 740, 12-6-2006) 
Sec. 5-7-9. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates this chapter shall be guilty of a violation and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as follows: 
(a)  By a fine of up to $1,000.00 and/or six months imprisonment for each offense; 
(b)  In addition to the fine set out in Subsection (a) of this section, the violator shall reimburse the City for the reasonable cost of removing the litter when the litter is or is ordered removed by the City; 
(c)  (1)  In the sound discretion of the court, the person may be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public right-of-way for a distance not to exceed one mile any litter he or she has deposited and any and all litter deposited thereon by any other person; or 
(2)  In the sound discretion of the court, the person may be directed to pick up and remove any and all litter from any public property, private right-of-way, or with prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that he or she has deposited litter. Pick up and removal shall include any and all litter deposited thereon by any other person as well; and 
(d)  The court may order published in the legal organ the names of persons convicted of violating this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 5-7-9; Ord. No. 740, 12-6-2006) 
Sec. 5-7-10. - Enforcement. 
All City Law Enforcement Personnel and all other employees of the City that are designated by the City Manager are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce compliance with this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 5-7-10; Ord. No. 740, 12-6-2006)

CHAPTER 3. - UTILITY ACCOUNTS 

Sec. 6-3-1. - Interest on overdue accounts. 
(a)  Interest shall be charged at the legal rate of 1½ percent on accounts of water, garbage, sewer, security and landfill customers which have been due and payable for 30 days or more. Such interest shall be calculated on the amount owed from the date upon which such accounts became due and payable until such accounts are paid. 
(b)  Interest charged under this chapter shall be collected according to law. 
(Code 1990, § 6-3-1; Ord. No. 512, 2-17-1992) 
CHAPTER 4. - IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION PROGRAM 

Sec. 6-4-1. - Reserved. 
Sec. 6-4-2. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to comply with 16 CFR 681.2 in order to detect, prevent and mitigate identity theft by identifying and detecting identity theft red flags and by responding to such red flags in a manner that will prevent identity theft. 
(Code 1990, § 6-4-2; Ord. No. 778, 10-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-4-3. - Definitions. 
When used in this article, the following words and phrases have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, unless the context indicates a different meaning: 
(a)  Reserved. 
(b)  Covered account means: 
(i)  An account that a financial institution or creditor offers or maintains, primarily for personal, family, or household purposes, that involves or is designed to permit multiple payments or transactions, such as a credit card account, mortgage loan, automobile loan, margin account, cell phone account, utility account, checking account, or savings account; and 
(ii)  Any other account that the financial institution or creditor offers or maintains for which there is a reasonably foreseeable risk to customers or to the safety and soundness of the financial institution or creditor from identity theft, including financial, operational, compliance, reputation, or litigation risks. 
(c)  Credit means the right granted by a creditor to a debtor to defer payment of debt or to incur debts and defer its payment or to purchase property or services and defer payment therefor. 
(d)  Creditor means any person who regularly extends, renews, or continues credit; any person who regularly arranges for the extension, renewal, or continuation of credit; or any assignee of an original creditor who participates in the decision to extend, renew, or continue credit and includes utility companies and telecommunications companies. 
(e)  Customer means a person that has a covered account with a creditor. 
(f)  Identity theft means a fraud committed or attempted using identifying information of another person without authority. 
(g)  Reserved. 
(h)  Personal identifying information means a person's credit card account information, debit card information, bank account information and driver's license information and for a natural person includes their social security number, mother's birth name, and date of birth. 
(i)  Red flag means a pattern, practice, or specific activity that indicates the possible existence of identity theft. 
(Code 1990, § 6-4-3; Ord. No. 778, 10-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-4-4. - Findings. 
(1)  The City is a creditor pursuant to 16 CFR 681.2 due to its provision or maintenance of covered accounts for which payment is made after certain municipal services have been provided. 
(2)  Covered accounts offered to customers for the provision of municipal services include sanitation services and security services. 
(3)  The process of making payments on a covered account has been identified as potential processes in which identity theft could occur. 
(4)  The City limits access to personal identifying information to those employees responsible for or otherwise involved in accepting payment for use of covered accounts. Information provided to such employees is entered directly into the City's computer system and is not otherwise recorded. 
(5)  The City determines that there is a low risk of identity theft occurring through the use of another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment by a customer to pay such customer's covered account or accounts. 
(Code 1990, § 6-4-4; Ord. No. 778, 10-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-4-5. - Credit card payments. 
(1)  All credit card payments made over the telephone or through the City's website shall be entered directly into the customer's account information in the computer data base. 
(2)  Account statements and receipts for covered accounts shall include only the last four digits of the credit or debit card or the bank account used for payment of the covered account. 
(Code 1990, § 6-4-5; Ord. No. 778, 10-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-4-6. - Sources and types of red flags. 
All employees responsible for or involved in the process of accepting payment for a covered account shall check for red flags as indicators of possible identity theft and such red flags may include: 
(1)  Payment for extra sanitation services or extra security services being made from a financial account of a person other than the person making the request for such services; and 
(2)  Payment for extra sanitation services or extra security services being made from a financial account of a person other than the property owner of record for an owner-occupied property. 
(Code 1990, § 6-4-6; Ord. No. 778, 10-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-4-7. - Prevention and mitigation of identity theft. 
In the event that any City employee responsible for or involved in accepting payment for a covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect to existing covered accounts, such employee shall use his or her discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft. If, in his or her discretion, such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to the Director of Administration. If, in his or her discretion, such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall also convey this information to the Director of Administration, who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the Director of Administration, in his or her discretion, determines that further action is necessary, a City employee shall perform one or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the Director of Administration: 
a.  Contact the property owner or customer of record to verify that they actually requested the additional services; 
b.  Make the following changes to the account if, after contacting the customer, it is apparent that someone other than the customer has accessed the customer's covered account: 
i.  Change any account numbers, passwords, security codes, or other security devices that permit access to an account; or 
ii.  Close the account; 
c.  In the event that someone other than the customer has accessed the customer's account causing additional charges to accrue or accessing personal identifying information, then law enforcement shall be notified; and/or 
d.  Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft. 
(Code 1990, § 6-4-7; Ord. No. 778, 10-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-4-8. - Updating the program. 
The City Council shall annually review and, as deemed necessary by the City Council, update the identity theft prevention program along with any relevant red flags in order to reflect changes in risks to customers or to the safety and soundness of the City and its covered accounts from identity theft. In so doing, the City Council shall consider the following factors and exercise its discretion in amending the program: 
(1)  The City's experiences with identity theft; 
(2)  Updates in methods of identity theft; 
(3)  Updates in customary methods used to detect, prevent, and mitigate identity theft; 
(4)  Updates in the types of accounts that the City offers or maintains; and 
(5)  Updates in service provider arrangements, if applicable. 
(Code 1990, § 6-4-8; Ord. No. 778, 10-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-4-9. - Program administration. 
The Director of Administration is responsible for oversight of the identity theft prevention program and for program implementation. The City Manager is responsible for reviewing reports prepared by staff regarding compliance with red flag requirements and with recommending material changes to the program, as necessary in the opinion of the City Manager, to address changing identity theft risks and to identify new or discontinued types of covered accounts. Any recommended material changes to the program shall be submitted to the City Council for consideration by the Council. 
(1)  The Director of Administration will report to the City Manager at least annually, on compliance with the red flag requirements. The report will address material matters related to the program and evaluate issues such as: 
a.  The effectiveness of the policies and procedures of the City in addressing the risk of identity theft in connection with accepting payments for covered accounts; 
b.  Significant incidents involving identity theft and management's response; and 
c.  Recommendations for material changes to the program. 
(2)  The Director of Administration is responsible for providing training to all employees responsible for or involved in accepting payment for a covered account with respect to the implementation and requirements of the identity theft prevention program. The Director of Administration shall exercise his or her discretion in determining the amount and substance of training necessary. 
(Code 1990, § 6-4-9; Ord. No. 778, 10-15-2008)
