Sign structure means poles, beams, columns, posts, foundations, or other means providing structural support for the sign surface area to which the sign is affixed. 
Sign surface area means the smallest square, rectangle, triangle, circle or combination thereof, which encompasses the entire sign inclusive of any border and trim, but excluding the base, apron, supports, and other structural members. 
Stanchion (or pole) sign means a ground sign that is mounted on a pole or other vertical support such that the bottom of the sign face is more than six feet above the ground and there is no visual obstruction other than the vertical support between the ground and the bottom of the sign face. 
Streamer means any long banner, tinsel or roping which is hung or strung from any structure to another structure or the ground. 
Structure means anything constructed or erected on the ground or attached to something on the ground. 
Temporary sign means a sign of a nonpermanent nature intended to be displayed on a transitory or temporary basis. Portable signs or any sign not permanently embedded in the ground, or not permanently affixed to a building or sign structure that is permanently embedded in the ground, are considered temporary signs. 
Trailer sign means any sign which is mounted on wheels and which may be moved from one location to another. 
Wall sign means a sign applied to or mounted to the wall or surface of a building or structure, the display surface of which does not project more than six inches from the outside wall of such building or structure. 
Window sign means any sign installed flush with the interior or exterior of a window and intended to be viewed from the outside. 
Yard, front , means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building or use, extending the full width of the lot and located between the street line and the front line of the building projected parallel to the street to the side lines of the lot. Corner lots shall be considered to have two front yards. 
Yard, rear, means an open space on the same lot with a principal building or use, unoccupied except by an accessory building or use, extending the full width of the lot and located between the rear line of the lot and the rear line of the building or use projected to the side lines of the lot. 
Yard, side, means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building or use, located between the building or use and the side line of the lot and extending from the rear line of the front yard to the front line of the rear yard. 
Zoning Board of Appeals means the Zoning Board of Appeals and Adjustments of the City of Conyers. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-4; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 714, 11-16-2005; Ord. No. 765, 1-16-2008; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, §§ 2, 3, 9-18-2013; Ord. No. 995, § 1, 10-21-2015) 
Sec. 8-5-5. - General provisions. 
(a)  Except for those signs exempted from the permit requirement by section 8-5-16, it shall be unlawful for any person to post, display, alter the structure or erect a sign without first obtaining a sign permit or temporary sign permit. A change in the copy of a sign or advertising device, provided no change is made to the underlying structure supporting the message, shall not constitute an alteration. 
(b)  It is not the intent of this Ordinance to regulate the content of speech through signage controls. To the extent any court of competent jurisdiction interprets any provision of this section to restrict the content of speech, it is the intent of the City Council that all allowable signs may display a noncommercial message in addition to, or in lieu of, any other message. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-5; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, § 4, 9-18-2013) 
Sec. 8-5-6. - Administration and enforcement. 
(a)  Enforcing officer. The provisions of this chapter shall be administered and enforced by the City Manager or his/her designee. The enforcing officer's duties shall include inspecting signs and issuing permits required by this chapter for signs that meet the requirements of this chapter and are otherwise lawful. Signs that require a permit that will be located in the historic district shall be approved by the historic preservation commission as provided by Section 8-9-41 prior to the issuance of a permit. 
(b)  Inspection authority. The City Manager or his/her designee may inspect signs regulated by this chapter at any time necessary to ensure that such signs conform to this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-6; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011) 
Sec. 8-5-7. - Sign permit application. 
Applications for sign permits shall be submitted by the sign owner or their agent upon official forms furnished by the City. Applications shall be complete and shall include the following: 
(1)  The type of sign, and cost of sign construction. 
(2)  The street address of the property upon which subject sign is to be located. In the absence of a street address, a method of location acceptable to the City shall be used. 
(3)  Sign details, including a scaled elevation of the size and height and of the proposed sign from ground level and adjacent street level. 
(4)  The square foot area per sign and the aggregate square foot area if there is more than one sign face. 
(5)  The name(s) and address(es) of the owner(s) of the real property upon which the sign is to be located. 
(6)  Written consent of the property owner, or his agent, granting permission for the placement and/or maintenance of subject sign. 
(7)  The name, address and phone number of the sign contractor. 
(8)  For ground signs: A site plan drawn to scale, showing the proposed location of all primary and accessory ground sign(s) on subject property. The site plan includes, at a minimum, a closed boundary survey of the property which shows the buildable area of the property, gross acreage, the proposed sign location, street right-of-way lines, public or private easements, driveway locations and parking spaces. For signs 50 square feet or larger and/or for signs 15 feet tall or higher, construction plans shall comply with the requirements as further described in the International Building Code, Chapter 1, and further described in Appendix H, Section H105, of the International Building Code shall be provided. Said plans shall be certified and stamped by a State registered professional engineer. 
(9)  For wall-mounted signs: Two sets of building elevations. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-7; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011) 
Sec. 8-5-8. - Permit approval, denial or revocation. 
(a)  Procedure. 
(1)  An action by the City Manager or his/her designee to approve or deny a sign permit shall be taken within 30 business days of receipt of a complete sign permit application. All applications meeting the standards of this section shall be granted within 30 business days of receipt of a completed application. Any completed sign permit application for which no action has been taken after 30 business days shall be deemed to be approved. 
(2)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall deny permit application(s) for signs that do not comply with the provisions of this article, incomplete applications, and applications containing any false material statements. A violation of any provision of this article will be grounds for terminating a permit granted by the City for the erection of a sign. Should it be determined that a sign permit was issued pursuant to an incomplete application or an application containing a false material statement, or that a permit has been erroneously issued in violation of this article, the City Manager or his/her designee shall revoke the permit. Should the City Manager or his/her designee deny a permit, the reasons for the denial are to be stated in writing and mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address on the permit application, postmarked on or before the 30th business day after the City Manager or his/her designee's receipt of the application, or by hand delivery to the applicant at time of denial. Any application denied and later resubmitted shall be deemed to have been submitted on the date of resubmission, not the date of the original submission. A permit shall not be denied or revoked except for due cause, being the violation of the provisions of this article, or the submission of an incomplete application or an application containing false material statements. 
(b)  Appeal. 
(1)  A person whose permit application has been denied or a permittee whose permit has been revoked may appeal the decision of the City Manager or his/her designee to the Board of Zoning Appeals and Adjustments as provided in Title 8 of the Code of Ordinances. In its review of the City Manager's or his/her designee's action the Board of Zoning Appeals and Adjustments shall review for compliance with the provisions for sign permit application set forth in this chapter. 
(2)  In the event a person whose permit has been denied or revoked is dissatisfied with the decision of the Board of Zoning Appeals and Adjustments, appeal may be made by filing notice with the City Manager or his/her designee within ten days of the date of the decision of the Board of Zoning Appeals and Adjustments. All appeals from the Board of Zoning Appeals and Adjustments shall be heard and decided by the City Council as further provided in the Code of Ordinances. In its review of the Board of Zoning Appeals and Adjustments decision the City Council shall review for compliance with the provisions for sign permit application set forth in Section 8-5-7. 
(c)  Certiorari. In the event a person whose permit has been denied or revoked is dissatisfied with the decision of the City Council, he may petition for writ of certiorari to the superior court of the County as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, § 5, 9-18-2013) 
Sec. 8-5-9. - Variances. 
(a)  Variances from the regulations of this chapter shall be limited to the following hardship situations: 
(1)  Where visibility of a conforming sign from the proposed street and within 50 feet of the proposed sign would be substantially impaired by existing trees, plants, topography, natural features, buildings or structures on the lot; and 
a.  Placement of the sign elsewhere on the lot would not remedy the visual obstruction; 
b.  Such visibility obstruction was not created by the owner of the subject property; and 
c.  The variance proposed would not create a safety hazard to vehicular traffic or pedestrians. 
(b)  Variances shall be limited to the minimum relief necessary to overcome the hardship. No variances shall be granted to allow a greater number of signs than would be allowed if the hardship did not exist. No variance shall transfer to a new owner or occupant of the property. 
(c)  Relief from the application of the provisions of this chapter by use of variances granted by the City shall be granted only upon a finding of hardship as previously defined. Hearing on such variances shall be noticed using this same procedures, time frames and notice requirements as for appeals under this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-23; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, § 6, 9-18-2013; Ord. No. 1028, § 8-17-2016) 
Sec. 8-5-10. - Expiration date. 
A sign location permit shall expire if the sign for which the permit was issued has not been erected, installed and completed within six months after the date of permit issuance; provided, however, that one six-month extension of the permit shall be granted if requested in writing prior to the expiration date of the initial permit. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-8, Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011) 
Sec. 8-5-11. - Sign permit fees. 
A sign permit or temporary sign permit shall not be issued until the appropriate application has been submitted and fees have been paid, as established by the City Council. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-9; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011) 
Sec. 8-5-12. - Nonconforming signs. 
(a)  The lawful use of a permanent sign existing at the time of the adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived may be continued in nonconformance with the requirements of this section, except that the nonconforming sign shall not be enlarged, altered, modified, improved or rebuilt unless such activity results in a sign that conforms in all degrees with this section. A nonconforming sign may be repaired to the extent necessary to maintain it in a safe condition and neat and orderly appearance. A change in the message on the sign shall not constitute an alternation or modification of the sign, so long as no change is made to the structure supporting the message. Specifically change of a static face sign to an LED or other type electronic sign shall not constitute a permissible alteration of a nonconforming use. 
(b)  No structural repair or change in shape, size or design, shall be permitted except to make a nonconforming sign comply with all requirements of this section or to render the sign structurally sound; provided that any sign damaged or destroyed by Act of God may be restored to its pre-damaged condition, but no change in design or materials can be made. Routine maintenance and changing of copy shall be permitted as long as such maintenance or changing of copy does not result in or change the shape, size, height or design of the sign. 
(c)  A nonconforming sign structure may not be replaced by another nonconforming sign structure, except where changed conditions beyond the control of the owner warrant the sign's repair. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-10; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 765, 1-16-2008; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, § 7, 9-18-2013) 
Sec. 8-5-13. - Signs and sign devices prohibited. 
(a)  Except where specifically permitted in particular zoning districts, the following types of signs are prohibited throughout the City: 
(1)  Roof signs. 
(2)  Portable signs. 
(3)  Animated signs. 
(4)  No exposed reflective type bulb, strobe light, incandescent lamp or neon tube lighting shall be used on the exterior surface of any sign so as to expose the face of the bulb, light, lamp or neon tube to any public street or adjacent property, with the exception of one neon sign permitted by subsection 8-5-18(g). The use of a clear covering over such bulb, lamp or neon tube, protecting the light while making it appear to be exposed is likewise prohibited. 
(5)  Signs placed within public rights-of-way, except publicly maintained signs. 
(6)  Signs erected by painting, nailing, fastening or affixing the sign in any manner to any fence, tree, rock, post, curb, utility pole, natural feature, official street sign or marker, traffic control sign or device, or other structure except as may be set forth herein. 
(7)  Any sign placed or erected on property without the permission of the owner. 
(8)  Individual or aggregate window signs exceeding 30 percent of the window area per building elevation. 
(9)  Signs which contain words, pictures, or statements which are obscene, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 16-12-80. 
(10)  Signs which simulate an official traffic control device, warning sign, or regulatory sign or which hide from view any traffic control device, signal or public service sign. 
(11)  Signs which emit or utilize in any manner any sound capable of being detected on any traveled road or highway by a person with normal hearing abilities. 
(12)  Signs which interfere with road or highway visibility or obstruct or otherwise interfere with the safe and orderly movement of traffic or which otherwise pose a hazard to traffic due to structural deficiencies in the structure of such signs. 
(13)  Signs which obstruct any fire escape, any means of egress or ventilation or shall prevent free passage from one part of a roof to any other part thereof, as well as signs attached to any fire escape. 
(14)  Signs which do not conform to applicable building and electrical codes. 
(15)  Signs which are in violation of the rules and regulations of any zoning overlay district presently existing or as may later be enacted. 
(16)  Any sign constructed of nondurable material including, but not limited to, paper, cardboard or flexible plastic that has been displayed for more than 60 days. 
(17)  Signs located on any substandard lot created after the enactment of this chapter, unless the substandard lot is created as the result of governmental action. 
(18)  Any sign that is structurally unsound, or is a hazard to traffic or pedestrians. 
(19)  Dilapidated or neglected signs. A sign (including sign structure) will be dilapidated or neglected if it does not present a neat and orderly appearance, which may be manifested by the following: rust or holes on or in the sign or sign structure; broken, missing, loose or bent parts; faded or flaking paint; nonoperative or partially nonoperative illuminating or mechanical devices or missing letters in sign copy. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-11; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 765, 1-16-2008; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, § 8, 9-18-2013) 
Sec. 8-5-14. - Temporary signs. 
The following types of signs or devices shall be permitted only by issuance of a temporary sign permit allowing the use of this type of sign or device for a period of 30 consecutive days. After the temporary sign has been displayed for 30 consecutive days, it shall be removed for 45 consecutive days before an application for a new temporary sign permit may be submitted. A fee, as established by the City Council by ordinance from time to time, shall be paid for each temporary sign permit. Upon expiration of the temporary sign permit, the permittee shall remove the sign, air or gas filled device, or banner(s) including any temporary supporting structure. A temporary sign may not be affixed in any manner to trees, street or light poles, utility poles, fences, or other sign structures. 
(1)  Air or gas filled devices not exceeding: 
a.  Shall not exceed 20 feet in height and 150 square feet of area. 
b.  Must be set back from all roadways and sidewalks equal to the height of the device plus ten feet. 
c.  No lot shall be permitted to have more than one air or gas filled device. 
(2)  Banners which shall be regulated as follows: 
a.  Each banner shall not exceed 32 square feet for any lot or individual structure. 
b.  Each nonresidential use shall be permitted to have one banner sign at one main entrance, provided that the total aggregate of any such banner sign shall not exceed 32 square feet. 
c.  Each banner must be individually attached to the building façade and shall not extend above the façade or roofline. No banner shall be attached to a light pole, freestanding pole, fence, utility pole or a similar structure. 
d.  Banners must be maintained in good condition. 
(3)  Balloons and streamers shall be maintained in good condition at all times. These devices shall not impede traffic or pedestrian walkways. 
(4)  All temporary signs and devices erected under this section shall be maintained in good condition at all times. These devices must be set back from any roadway or pedestrian walkway equal to the height of the device plus ten feet. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-12; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 765, 1-16-2008; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, § 9, 9-18-2013; Ord. No. 961, § 1, 6-18-2014; Ord. No. 995, §§ 2, 3, 10-21-2015) 
Sec. 8-5-15. - Flags. 
(a)  All flags shall be displayed on purpose-built, professionally fabricated flagpoles, which may be vertical or mast-arm flagpoles. No permit is necessary for the erection of a flagpole. In nonresidential districts, flagpoles shall not exceed the allowed height provided for a structure or building in the applicable zoning district, or 50 feet, whichever is higher. Flagpoles in residential districts shall not exceed 25 feet in height or the height of the primary structure on the lot, whichever is less. 
(b)  The maximum dimensions of any flag shall be proportional to the flagpole height. The hoist side of the flag shall not exceed 20 percent of the vertical height of the flagpole. In addition, flags are subject to the following limitations: 

 
(c)  Each lot or parcel shall be allowed a maximum of three flagpoles. 
(d)  A maximum of two flags shall be allowed per flagpole. 
(e)  Flags not meeting the definition of a flag contained herein shall conform to all applicable ordinances pertaining to signs. 
(f)  A vertical flagpole must be set back from all property boundaries a distance which is at least equal to the height of the flagpole. 
(g)  Flags and flagpoles shall be maintained in good repair, and to the extent applicable shall be in compliance with the building code. Flagpoles with broken halyards shall not be used and flags which are torn or frayed shall not be displayed. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-13; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 765, 1-16-2008; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011) 
Sec. 8-5-16. - Signs exempt from specified provisions of this article. 
The following types of signs are exempt from securing a permit, provided such signs shall comply with all other standards of this section. 
(1)  Two non-illuminated freestanding signs having an aggregate sign area per residential or nonresidential lot of 12 square feet or less. However, each such sign may not exceed six square feet in size or greater than four feet above the grade level of the adjacent street to which the sign is located or three feet above ground level, whichever is greater. No sign shall be located within the public right-of-way and no closer than ten feet to the public right-of-way. Signs shall not be attached to light poles, freestanding poles, utility poles, bollards, or similar structures. 
(2)  Display of address numerals not exceeding six inches for single-family residential uses or 12 inches for all other uses. 
(3)  Any sign not visible from public thoroughfares or any sign within a business, office, mall, or totally enclosed area. 
(4)  Window signs not exceeding 30 percent of the available window space per building elevation. 
(5)  Swinging or projecting signs not exceeding three square feet, or projecting more than four feet and attached under the eave or awning of a building above a business entrance. 
(6)  The display of one exposed neon sign meeting the standards of Section 8-5-18(g). 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-14; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 765, 1-16-2008; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, §§ 10—12, 9-18-2013) 
Sec. 8-5-17. - Maintenance and appearance of signs; removal. 
(a)  All signs shall be maintained in good condition, so as to present a neat and orderly appearance. Neglected or dilapidated signs shall be manifested by the following: faded or flaking paint, rust, non-operative or partially non-operative illumination or mechanical devices, missing letters in sign copy, and damaged, dilapidated or insecure sign structures. 
(b)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall periodically inspect each permanent and temporary conforming and non-conforming sign to ascertain whether the same is secure or insecure, and whether it is in compliance with the requirements of this section or in need of repair. Responsibility for the safety of signs and security of their attachment or erection remains at all times with the sign owner. 
(c)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall cause to be removed any sign that endangers the public safety, such as an abandoned, dangerous or materially, electrically or structurally defective sign or a sign for which no permit has been issued or which is otherwise in violation of this section. The City Manager or his/her designee shall prepare a written notice which shall describe the sign and specify the violation involved and which shall state that if the sign is not removed or the violation is not corrected within 30 calendar days, the sign shall be removed in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(d)  All notices mailed by the City Manager or his/her designee shall be sent by certified mail and first class mail. Any time periods provided in this section shall be deemed to commence on the date of the receipt of the certified mail, or if the first class mail is not returned, after seven business days of mailing. 
(e)  The notice shall be mailed to the owner of the property on which the sign is located, the owner of the sign and the occupant of the property. If any of such persons is unknown or cannot be found, notice shall be mailed to such person's last known address, if any, and posted on the sign or on the premises. 
(f)  Any person having an interest in the sign or the property may appeal the determination of the City Manager or his/her designee ordering removal or compliance by filing a written notice of appeal to the Board of Zoning Appeals and Adjustments within ten calendar days after receipt of notice. The procedure for appeals to the Board of Zoning Appeals shall be as provided in Title 8 of the Code. In the event a person whose sign has been removed or whose sign has been ordered to be in compliance is dissatisfied with the decision of the Board of Zoning Appeals and Adjustments, appeal may be made by filing notice with the City Manager or his/her designee within ten calendar days of the date of the decision of the Board of Zoning Appeals and Adjustments. All appeals from the Board of Zoning Appeals and Adjustments shall be heard and decided by the City Council as further provided in the Code. In the event a person whose sign has been removed or whose sign has been ordered to be in compliance is dissatisfied with the decision of the City Council, he may petition for writ of certiorari to the superior court of Rockdale County as provided by law. 
(g)  Notwithstanding the above, in cases of emergency as provided by subsection (i) below, the City Manager or his/her designee may cause the immediate removal of a dangerous or defective sign without notice. 
(h)  Any sign removed by the City Manager of his/her designee pursuant to the provisions of this section shall become the property of the City and may be disposed of in any manner deemed appropriate by the City. The cost of removal of the sign by the City shall constitute a lien against the property and shall be recoverable in the same manner as City property taxes. The cost of removal shall include any and all incidental expenses incurred by the City in connection with the sign's removal. 
(i)  When it is determined by the City Manager or his/her designee that the sign would cause imminent danger to the public safety and contact cannot be made with a sign owner or building owner, then no written notice shall have to be served. In this emergency situation, the City Manager or his/her designee shall document the imminent danger and attempts to contact the sign owner, and may correct the danger, all costs being charged to the sign owner and property owner. 
(j)  If it shall be necessary for the City Manager or his/her designee to remove a sign pursuant to the provisions of this section, and it should be practicable to sell or salvage any material derived in the removal, he may sell the same at private or public sale at the best price obtainable, and shall keep an account of the proceeds thereof. Such proceeds, if any, shall be used to offset the costs of removal to be charged to the sign owner or property owner. Where the proceeds derived from such a sale are less than the cost of removal, such deficiency shall constitute a lien against the property on which the sign is located, such lien to be collectible in the same manner as City property taxes. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-15; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 765, 1-16-2008; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, § 13, 9-18-2013) 
Sec. 8-5-18. - Illumination of signs. 
(a)  No sign shall give off light which glares, blinds or has any other such adverse effect on traffic or adjacent properties. The light from an illuminated sign shall be established in such a way that adjacent properties and roadways are not adversely affected and that no direct light is cast upon adjacent properties and roadways. No illuminated sign shall be constructed or maintained within 75 feet of the property line of any single-family residential lot. 
(b)  Subject to the allowances of Section 8-5-22, no sign shall have blinking, flashing, or fluctuating lights or other illuminating devices which have a changing light intensity, brightness or color. No sign shall be animated or otherwise simulate movement. 
(c)  Subject to the allowances of Section 8-5-22, no sign shall contain an electronic or computerized message changer. 
(d)  No exposed reflective type bulbs and no strobe light or incandescent lamp shall be used on the exterior surface of any sign so as to expose the face of the bulb, light or lamp to any public right-of-way or adjacent property, provided that the use of LED technology in Oversized Signs and Electronic Signs meeting the standards of this section shall be permitted. 
(e)  Colored lights shall not be used at any location or in any manner so as to be confused with or construed as traffic control devices. Neither direct nor reflected light from primary light sources shall create a hazard to operators of motor vehicles. 
(f)  Signs located within any residential district may only be indirectly illuminated. 
(g)  Each ground floor nonresidential use with an exterior entrance shall be permitted one LED or neon lit sign not to exceed two square feet in sign area and positioned on the interior of a window not more than five feet from the principal pedestrian entrance to the use. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-16; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 765, 1-16-2008; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, §§ 14, 15, 9-18-2013; Ord. No. 961, § 2, 6-18-2014; Ord. No. 995, § 4, 10-21-2015) 
Sec. 8-5-19. - Maximum heights, maximum sizes, setback requirements and number allowance of signs permitted. 
Signs in the City shall be permitted and regulated in accordance with the sign table in this chapter, unless otherwise regulated, prohibited or exempted herein. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-17; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011) 
Sec. 8-5-19A. - Sign table. 

 
1 No sign shall be located closer than 5 feet from the public right-of way. In addition, no portion of the sign shall violate the required 5 feet setback. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-17A; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 765, 1-16-2008; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, § 16, 9-18-2013; Ord. No. 995, § 5, 10-21-2015; Ord. No. 1094, § 1, 9-20-2017) 
Sec. 8-5-20. - Oversized signs. 
Oversized signs shall be permitted subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  Oversized signs may be permitted as an allowed use within nonresidential zoning districts, if located on properties that are adjacent to interstate highways. 
(2)  Oversized signs shall not be placed within 500 feet in any direction of a residential zoning district, church, school, park or cemetery. 
(3)  Oversized signs shall be completely independent of any building or other structure, excluding the sign structure. 
(4)  All portions of oversized signs shall be erected only in the buildable area of the lot as defined in this chapter. 
(5)  No oversized sign shall be located within 500 feet of another oversized sign on the same side of the street as measured along the right-of-way of the street or streets on which these signs are located; and provided further that no oversized sign may be located closer than 500 feet to another oversized sign in any other direction. 
(6)  The maximum size for oversized signs shall be the following: No single face of an oversized sign shall exceed 672 square feet or 14 feet in height or 48 feet in length. The face of an oversized sign shall contain no more than two faces, not to exceed 1,344 square feet collectively. All sign faces shall be directed toward the interstate highway. The maximum height of the entire sign including structure shall extend up to a maximum of 48 feet above the ground level at top of the sign. 
(7)  Multiple message oversized signs are signs which change the message or copy on the sign digitally by means of lights or light-emitting diodes or electronically by movement or rotation of panels or slats shall be permitted on interstate highways under the following conditions: 
a.  Each sign shall remain fixed for at least ten seconds. When a message is changed, it shall be accomplished in three seconds or less; 
b.  No such sign shall be within 5,000 feet of another multiple-message sign on the same side of the interstate highway. Further, no multiple-message sign shall be located closer than 500 feet to another multiple-message sign in any other direction measured in a straight line to the nearest portion of each sign; 
c.  Any such sign shall contain a default design that will freeze the sign in one position if a malfunction occurs; 
d.  Any maximum size limitations shall apply independently to each side of a multiple-message sign; 
e.  Oversized signs utilizing electronic lighting such as LED, LCD or similar lighting may not operate at brightness levels of more than 0.30 foot-candles (under measurement conditions) above ambient light levels as measured 150 feet from the sign. The owner of the sign shall arrange for an annual certification of the light intensity showing compliance with this standard by an independent lighting engineer and provide such certification to the City. 
f.  Multiple-message signs shall not emit or utilize in any manner any sound capable of being detected on the main traveled way by a person with normal hearing; and 
g.  No multiple-message sign shall include any illumination which is flashing, intermittent, scrolling, fading, or moving when the sign is in a fixed position. 
(8)  Oversized signs must be in compliance with the provisions set forth for a sign permit application and the construction standards required therein. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-18; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 765, 1-16-2008; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, §§ 17, 18, 9-18-2013; Ord. No. 995, § 6, 10-21-2015) 
Sec. 8-5-21. - Interior project directional signs. 
Such signs are authorized in all developments or planned subdivisions of land within any nonresidential zoning district subject to the following: 
(1)  May not be located within 100 feet of an entrance to a project. 
(2)  Maximum sign area shall not exceed four square feet. 
(3)  Must not block visibility at any intersection. 
(4)  Maximum sign height shall not exceed four feet. 
(5)  Setback from right-of-way may be zero feet. 
(6)  Two such signs may be located at each internal intersection of private driveways or public streets within the project. 
(7)  The purpose of the sign is to provide more definitive directional information concerning the whereabouts of tenants within the development. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-20; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 765, 1-16-2008; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011) 
Sec. 8-5-22. - Electronic signs. 
(a)  Electronic signs shall be allowed in nonresidential zoning districts. 
(b)  Each electronic message shall remain fixed for at least ten seconds. 
(c)  When a message is changed, it shall be accomplished in three seconds or less. 
(d)  No segmented message may last longer than ten seconds. 
(e)  No traveling message may travel at a rate slower than 16 light columns per second or signs end faster than 32 light columns per second. 
(f)  No electronic sign shall emit or utilize in any manner any sound capable of being detected on the main traveled way by a person with normal hearing. 
(g)  No electronic message sign shall include any illumination which is flashing, intermittent, fading or travelling in a manner other than as permitted by subsections (d) and (e). 
(h)  Electronic signs shall contain a default design that will freeze the sign in one position if a malfunction occurs. 
(i)  No electronic sign shall give off light, which glares, blinds, or has any other adverse effect on traffic or adjacent properties. The light from an illuminated electronic sign shall be established in such a way that adjacent properties and roadways are not adversely affected and that no direct light is cast upon adjacent properties and roadways. Electronic signs utilizing electronic lighting such as LED, LCD or similar lighting may not operate at brightness levels of more than 0.30 foot-candles (under measurement conditions) above ambient light levels as measured 150 feet from the sign. The owner of the sign shall arrange for an original certification of the light intensity showing compliance with this standard by an independent lighting engineer or contractor and provide such certification to the City. Such certification shall be updated by such lighting engineer or contractor with a copy provided to the City every five years. 
(j)  Electronic signs, other than oversized signs oriented toward the interstate highway as provided by section 8-5-20, are limited to 30 percent of the sign face. It is the intent of this provision that ground signs in nonresidential zoning districts are permitted to utilize a portion of their allowable signage for electronic messages, but that 70 percent of such signs retain traditional static faces, not subject to electronic variation. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-21; Ord. No. 765, 1-16-2008; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, §§ 19—21, 9-18-2013) 
Sec. 8-5-23. - Vehicle signs. 
(a)  Placement of signs on vehicles, trailers or non-motorized vehicles that are then parked or placed in such manner as to expand the advertising associated with said business beyond that permitted by Section 8-5-19A is prohibited. For the purpose of this Section it shall be presumed that a vehicle, trailer or non-motorized vehicle was parked in violation of this section when it is parked at a point adjacent to the public right-of-way and more than 50 feet from the business's main building entrance to which it is associated. 
(b)  Any vehicle or common carrier with a sign attached to its operational structure may park in a legal parking space associated with the business, provided the vehicle is used regularly for transportation relating to the activity advertised and displays a valid current license plate. In the case of shopping centers and buildings housing more than one tenant that share a parking area, such vehicle shall be parked as far as possible away from the public right-of-way and in near proximity (within 50 feet) to the business's main building entrance. 
(c)  Permissible vehicle signs include signs that are applied directly to the vehicle with paint, magnets, decals and vinyl wrap. Banners, A-frame, temporary fixtures and signs mounted in pickup beds or on the bed of flatbed trucks are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 938, § 22, 9-18-2013) 
Sec. 8-5-24. - Enforcement and penalties. 
The sign provisions of this article shall be administered and enforced by the City Manager or his/her designee. 
(1)  The City Manager or his/her designee may issue a citation for violation of this article by any person, including, if applicable, the owner, manager or tenant of the lot on which a sign is located; for a sign erected, altered, maintained, converted, or used in violation of this article; or in violation of any other applicable ordinance, including, but not limited to, building or electrical codes. 
(2)  Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of an offense, and upon conviction by a court of competent jurisdiction, shall be subject to a penalty of not less than $25.00 nor more than $1,000.00, or by confinement for a total time not to exceed 180 days, or both. Each day in which a sign is in violation of this chapter shall be a separate and distinct offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(3)  The City may seek affirmative equitable relief in a court of competent jurisdiction to cause the removal or repair of any sign in violation of this article. 
(4)  The City Manager or his/her designee may remove any sign or structure illegally placed upon a public right-of-way without any notice and may dispose of said sign or structure. Such removal and disposal of illegally placed signs shall not preclude the prosecution of any person for illegally placing such signs in the public right-of-way. 
(Code 1990, § 8-5-24; Ord. No. 666, 11-20-2002; Ord. No. 830, § II, 5-18-2011; Ord. No. 938, § 22, 9-18-2013) 
CHAPTER 6. - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS[8]

ARTICLE 1. - GENERAL 

Sec. 8-6-1. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the Land Subdivision Regulations of the City of Conyers, Georgia. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-1; Ord. No. 757, 6-20-2007) 
Sec. 8-6-2. - Purpose. 
These subdivision regulations are adopted in order to encourage appropriate development and subdivision of land within the incorporated City and for the following purposes: 
(a)  To ensure economically sound and stable land development; 
(b)  To ensure the provision of required streets, utilities, and other facilities and services to land developments; 
(c)  To ensure the adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, in land developments; 
(d)  To ensure the provision of needed public open spaces and building sites in land developments through the dedication or reservation of land for recreational, educational, and other public purposes; 
(e)  To ensure that the land is developed in conformity with the elements of the comprehensive plan, whenever reasonably practical; and 
(f)  To ensure adequate identification of property on the public records. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-2; Ord. No. 757, 6-20-2007) 
Sec. 8-6-3. - Authority. 
(a)  These subdivision regulations are enacted pursuant to the Constitution of the State of Georgia, Article 9, Section 2, Paragraphs 1 and 3 [Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶¶ 1, 3]; by the City's authority to enact regulations and exercise powers granted by local laws including 1977 Ga. Laws, page 2817, § 10, as amended [1977 Ga. Laws, page 2817, § 10]; by the City's planning authority and general police powers; and by other powers and authority provided by Federal, State, and local laws applicable hereto. 
(b)  These subdivision regulations shall take effect and shall be in force upon their adoption by the City Council. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-3; Ord. No. 757, 6-20-2007) 
Sec. 8-6-4. - Definitions. 
(a)  Rules of interpretation. For the purpose of these subdivision regulations, certain words or terms used herein are interpreted as follows: 
(1)  Reserved. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  The term "person" includes a firm, association, organization, partnership, trust, company, or corporation, as well as an individual. 
(4)  The term "lot" includes the terms "plot," "parcel" or "tract." 
(5)  The term "used" or "occupied," as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the terms "intended," "arranged," or "designed to be used or occupied." 
(6)  The term "erected" shall be deemed also to include constructed, reconstructed, altered, moved or placed. 
(7)  The terms "land use" and "use of land" shall be deemed also to include building use and use of building. 
(8)  The term "adjacent" means contiguous notwithstanding road right-of-way. 
(9)  Unless otherwise specified, all distances shall be measured along a straight line, horizontally. 
(10)  Unless indicated otherwise, reference to zoning districts refer to the most recent copy of the Official Zoning Map of the City of Conyers, Georgia. 
(b)  Rules of precedence. The following rules set forth the order of precedence that determines which definition applies in a specific instance within the provisions of these subdivision regulations: 
(1)  When definitions are provided within an individual article or section of these subdivision regulations, those definitions are to be applied within said article, or section. If the same term or phrase is also defined in this section, the definition in subsection (c) of this section shall not apply in that instance. 
(2)  When no definitions are provided within an individual article, or section of these subdivision regulations, words and phrases used in these subdivision regulations shall have the meaning established by the definitions provided in Subsection (c) of this section. 
(3)  All remaining words used in these subdivision regulations are intended to have the commonly accepted definitions contained in a recent edition of the Merriam-Webster Dictionary. 
(c)  Definitions. As used in these subdivision regulations, the following terms shall have the meaning set forth below, except where otherwise specifically set forth. 
Abutting means touching at one point or along a common side, boundary or property line. Two pieces of property that are separated by a street or right-of-way are adjacent, but not abutting. 
Accessory building. See Building, accessory. 
Accessory structure. See Structure, accessory. 
Accessory use. See Use, accessory. 
Acre means a unit of area equal to 43,560 square feet. 
Addition (to an existing building) means any walled and roofed expansion to the perimeter of a building in which the addition is connected by a common load-bearing wall other than a firewall. Any walled and roofed addition that is connected by a firewall or is separated by an independent perimeter load-bearing wall shall be considered new construction. 
Aggregate means washed gravel or washed stone meeting the GDOT standards for hardness or other materials approved by the GDOT. 
Alley means a private or publicly maintained way of narrow width used for secondary vehicular access. See Section 8-6-78(k). 
Alteration means any change, addition or modification in construction or type of occupancy; any change in the structural members of a building, such as walls, partitions, columns, beams, girders, doors, windows, means of ingress or egress, or any enlargement to, or diminution of a building or structure, whether horizontally or vertically, or the moving of a building from one location to another. 
Appeal means a request for a review to hear and decide where it was alleged there was an error in any order, requirement, permit, decision, determination, or refusal made by any officer of the City in the enforcement of these subdivision regulations. 
Application means a document and associated documentation filed by any person seeking approval to undertake any activity regulated by the City. 
Area of special flood hazard means the land in the floodplain within a community subject to a one percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. 
Automobile means a motorized vehicle with two axles and not more than six wheels, designed for carrying ten passengers or less and used for the transportation of persons. 
Basement means that portion of a building that is partly or completely below grade and has at least 6½ feet vertical interior clearance from floor or grade to ceiling or underside of structure. 
Berm means an earthen mound designed to screen undesirable views, reduce noise, or fulfill other such purposes. 
Best management practices (BMPs) means a collection of structural practices and vegetative measures which, when properly designed, installed and maintained, will provide effective erosion and sedimentation control for all rainfall events up to and including a 25-year, 24-hour event. The term "properly designed" means designed in accordance with the hydraulic design specifications contained in the latest edition of the Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia specified in O.C.G.A. 
Bike lane means a paved lane on a street or roadway that is reserved by pavement marking and/or signs for the exclusive use by bicycles. 
Block means a piece or parcel of land entirely surrounded by public highways or streets, other than alleys. 
Board of Appeals means the City of Conyers Board of Zoning Appeals and Adjustments. 
Buffer or buffer, transitional , means that portion of a lot set aside for open space and visual screening purposes, pursuant to applicable provisions of this chapter, to separate different use districts, or to separate uses on one property from uses on another property of the same use district or a different use district. 
Buildable area means the area of a lot remaining after the minimum front, side and rear yard setback requirements of the zoning district has been met. 
Building means any structure with a roof and enclosed on all sides. 
Building, accessory, means a building detached from the principal building located on the same lot and customarily incidental and subordinate in area, extent, and purpose to the principal building or use. 
Building permit. See Permit, building. 
Building principal means a building in which is conducted the main or dominant use of the lot on which such building is situated. 
Cash escrow means a cash deposit to be held in reserve for a set term by the City as a guarantee of performance or maintenance as provided in Section 8-6-28. Cash escrows are held in a secure financial institution in a separate, restricted account attributable to the property or property owner making the deposit. Withdrawal or use of the funds in the cash escrow account is restricted to specified parties for specified purposes within a fixed period of time, and may be used by the City upon failure of the escrowing party to make guaranteed improvements in a timely manner or to perform required maintenance activities. See Section 8-6-28. 
City Manager means the City Manager of Conyers, Georgia or his or her designee. 
Clearing means the removal of trees and brush from the land but not including removing roots and stumps or the ordinary mowing of grass. 
Clerk means the clerk serving the City Council of the City of Conyers, Georgia. 
Collector. See Street classifications. 
Common areas means those portions of a site and/or building collectively owned or controlled. 
Comprehensive plan means any part or element of the most recently adopted plan for development for the City of Conyers as provided by O.C.G.A. § 50-8-1 et seq. and Ga. Comp. R. and Regs. Chapter 110-12-1, Standards and Procedures for Local Comprehensive Planning. 
Condominium means a building, or group of buildings, in which dwelling units, offices, or floor areas are owned individually, and the structure, common areas, and facilities are owned by all the owners on a proportional, undivided basis. 
Conservation easement means a recorded agreement between a land owner and government agency or land trust that permanently protects open space or greenspace on the owner's land by limiting the amount and type of development that can take place, but continues to leave the remainder of the fee interest in private ownership. 
Construction activity means activities including, but not limited to, activities subject to the Georgia Erosion and Sedimentation Control Act or NPDES General Construction Permits, such as clearing and grubbing, grading, excavating, and demolition. The term "construction activity" includes construction projects resulting in land disturbance, erecting new structures and buildings, as well as redevelopment, remodeling or modification of an existing building or structure. 
Construction, new, means structures for which the start of construction commenced on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this subdivision regulations are derived; other structures that are built on previously undeveloped land and are not additions or alterations. 
Construction plans means the maps or drawings accompanying a subdivision plat and showing the specific location and design of the improvements to be installed in the subdivision in accordance with the requirements of the design standards of these regulations as a condition of the approval of the final plat. 
Construction, start of, means the point of time commemorating the breaking of ground for the construction of a development or structure. 
Cul-de-sac means a local street or road with one outlet and having an appropriate terminal for the safe and convenient reversal of traffic movement. See Section 8-6-75(b). 
Curb cut means the opening along the curb line or edge of pavement of a public street at which point a driveway begins for vehicular ingress and egress from a parcel. 
Cut means a portion of land surface or area from which earth has been removed or will be removed by excavations; the depth below original ground surface to excavated surface. The term "cut" also known as excavation. 
Density means the total number of square feet of a building, or number of lots or dwelling units per acre of land unless specifically provided otherwise in the zoning chapter, Chapter 7 of this title. 
Density, gross, means the total number of square feet of a building, or number of lots or dwelling units on a tract of land prior to development or subdivision; including all streets or rights-of-way, open space, floodplain and other unsubdivided or unused portions of the tract of land. 
Density, net, means the number of square feet, lots or dwelling units on a tract of land; less area for public or private streets, rights-of-way, utility easements, public lands, wetlands, ponds, lakes, rivers, streams, floodplain and other unbuildable portions of the tract of land. 
Department means the Department of Planning and Inspection Services of the City. 
Department of Environmental Health means the Rockdale County Department of Environmental Health. 
Detention means the temporary storage of stormwater runoff in a stormwater management facility for the purpose of controlling the peak discharge. 
Detention facility means a permanent basin or structure designed for the detention of stormwater runoff and gradual release of stored water at controlled rates in accordance with the Georgia Stormwater Management Manual. 
Developer means a person who undertakes land development activities. 
Development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate, including but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, clearing, grubbing, grading, paving, any other installation of impervious cover, excavation or drilling operations or storage of equipment or materials. 
Development permit means an official authorization issued by the Director allowing clearing, grubbing, grading or other alteration of the site that entails land disturbance related to construction activities in compliance with the zoning chapter, Chapter 7 of this title, and these subdivision regulations. 
Director means the Director of the City of Conyers Department of Planning and Inspection Services or his or her designee. 
District, zoning, means a tract of land or contiguous parcels of the City within which the zoning regulations are uniform. 
Drainage easement. See Easement, drainage. 
Drainage structure means a device composed of a virtually nonerodible material such as concrete, steel, plastic or other such material that conveys water from one place to another by intercepting the flow and carrying it to a release point for stormwater management, drainage control, or flood control purposes. 
Driveway means a vehicular access, or curb cut that is in private ownership and provides access primarily to one property. 
Dumpster means a portable container used for temporary storage of garbage, trash, or other refuse or receptacle material that has a capacity of one cubic yard or more. 
Dwelling means a building or portion thereof designed, arranged or used principally for residential occupancy (not including buildings designed for transient use such as hotels and motels), and which complies with the provisions of the international building code recommended by the International Code Council adopted by the City. 
Dwelling, single-family, means a dwelling structure that is designed for the use of one family. 
Dwelling unit means one or more rooms, designed, occupied or intended for occupancy as a separate living quarter, with cooking, sleeping and sanitary facilities provided within the dwelling unit for the exclusive use of a single housekeeping unit. The term "dwelling unit" does not include rooms in a hotel, motel, boardinghouse, bed and breakfast, or extended stay hotel. 
Easement means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
Easement, access, means an easement created for the purpose of providing vehicular or pedestrian access to or across a property. 
Easement, drainage, means land required for the installation of stormwater sewers or drainage ditches and/or required for the preservation or maintenance of a natural stream or watercourse or other drainage facility. 
Easement, utility, means a grant by a property owner for the use of real property for the specified purpose of constructing and maintaining utilities; including, but not limited to, sanitary sewers, water mains, electric lines, telephone lines, cable lines, storm sewer or storm drainage ways and gas lines. 
Engineer means a registered, professional engineer, licensed by the State. 
Erosion means the process by which land surface is worn away by the action of wind, water, ice or gravity. 
Family means one or more persons occupying a dwelling unit as a single housekeeping unit based on an intentionally structured relationship providing organization and stability. A family usually consists of persons who are related by blood, marriage or guardianship, however, a family may also consist of up to four persons who are not so related, or a blend of related and unrelated persons not to exceed six in number. Domestic servants employed on the premises may be housed on the premises without being counted as a separate family or families. The term "family" does not include any organization or institutional group. 
Fence means an artificially constructed barrier of any material or combination of materials erected to enclose, screen, or separate areas. See Chapter 7 of this title. 
Fill means a portion of land surface to which soil or other solid material has been added; the depth above the original ground. 
Finished grade means the final elevation and contour of the ground after grading. 
Flooding means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from: 
(1)  The overflow of inland or tidal waters. 
(2)  The unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
Floodplain means any land area susceptible to flooding, which would have at least a one percent probability of flooding occurrence in any calendar year based on: 
(1)  The basin being fully developed as shown on the current land use plan; or 
(2)  The regulatory floodplain as defined by the National Flood Insurance Program (FEMA). 
The more restrictive (wider) of either Subsection (1) or (2) of this definition shall be used. 
Floodway means the channel of a stream or other watercourse and the adjacent areas of the floodplain which is necessary to contain and discharge the base flood flow without cumulatively increasing the base flood elevation more than one foot. 
Floor means the lower horizontal finished surface of each story in a building that is intended to support the contents of the building and its occupants. 
Floor area means the sum of the gross horizontal areas of the total number of finished floors of a fully enclosed building measured from the exterior faces of the exterior walls or from the centerline of walls separating two buildings; excluding cellar space, carports and garages, and any space where the floor-to-ceiling height is less than 6½ feet. 
Floor, lowest, means the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area, including basement. An unfinished or flood-resistant enclosure, usable solely for parking of vehicles, building access or storage, in an area other than a basement area, is not considered a building's lowest floor, provided that such enclosure is not built so as to render the structure in violation of other provisions of these subdivision regulations. 
Georgia Stormwater Management Manual. See Stormwater Management Manual. 
Grade means a reference plane representing the average of finished ground level adjoining the building at all exterior walls. When the finished ground level slopes away from the exterior walls, the reference plane shall be established by the lowest points within the area between the building and the lot line or between the building and a point six feet from the building, whichever is closer. 
Grading means altering the shape of ground surfaces to a predetermined condition; this includes stripping, cutting, filling, stockpiling and shaping or any combination thereof and shall include the land in its cut and filled condition. 
Grubbing means removing roots and stumps from land that has been cleared, but not grading. 
Hardship means a condition of significant practical difficulty in using a lot because of physical problems relating solely to the size, shape or topography of the lot in question which are not economic difficulties and which are not self-imposed. 
Hazardous waste means any solid waste which has been defined as a hazardous waste in regulations, promulgated by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the Federal act, which are in force and effect on February 1, 1988, codified as 40 CFR 261.3. 
Health Department means the County Health Department which is duly authorized to perform health services in the City. 
Height means the vertical distance of a structure other than a building measured from the average elevation of the finished grade surrounding the structure to the highest point of the structure. When referring to a telecommunications antenna it shall mean the vertical distance from the base of the antenna to the highest point of the tower or any appurtenance attached to it. 
Height, building, means the vertical distance measured from the average elevation of the finished grade at the front of the building to the highest point of the roof if a flat roof; to the deck line of mansard roofs; and to the mean height level between eaves and ridge of gable, hip, and gambrel roofs. The term "building height" does not include steeples, cupolas, decorative towers, antennas and mechanical equipment attached to a building. 
Historic structure or archaeological feature means any structure that is: 
(1)  Listed individually in the National Register of Historic Places (a listing maintained by the Department of Interior) or preliminarily determined by the Secretary of the Interior as meeting the requirements of individual listing on the National Register; 
(2)  Certified or preliminary determined by the Secretary of the Interior as contributing to the historical significance of a registered historic district or a district preliminary determined by the Secretary to qualify as a registered historic district; 
(3)  Individually listed on a state inventory of historic places in states with historic preservation programs which have been approved by the Secretary of the Interior; or 
(4)  Individually listed on a local inventory of historic places in communities with historic preservation programs that have been certified either by an approved State program as determined by the Secretary of the Interior, or directly by the Secretary of the Interior in states without approved programs. 
Impervious means a material that water cannot pass through or be absorbed by. 
Impervious surface means a surface composed of any material that significantly impedes or prevents the natural infiltration of water into soil. The term "impervious surfaces" include, but are not limited to, rooftops, buildings, streets and roads, and any concrete or asphalt surface. 
Interstate principal arterial. See Street classifications. 
Joint access driveway means a driveway that provides direct vehicular access to two or more abutting properties from a public street. 
Land development means any land disturbing activity, including but not limited to clearing, grubbing, stripping, removal of vegetation, dredging, grading, excavating, transporting and filling of land, construction, paving and any other installation of impervious surface. 
Land disturbance means any land or vegetation changes, including but not limited to clearing, grubbing, stripping, removal of vegetation, dredging, grading, excavating, transporting and filling of land, that do not involve construction, paving or any other installation of impervious surface, but not including agriculture. 
Land disturbance permit. See Permit, land disturbance. 
Land disturbing activity means those actions or activities which comprise, facilitate or result in land disturbance. 
Line of credit means the promise of payment of a stipulated sum to the City by a reputable financial institution, drawn upon the credit of a developer or applicant holding an account in such financial institution, made payable to the City upon demand as provided in Section 8-6-28. The City shall be is entitled to collect on the credit upon presenting its draft or demand together with an affidavit or other documentation in compliance with the terms of the credit showing evidence of failure of the developer or applicant to perform required actions prior to the City pursuing its claim against the applicant or developer and irrespective of the local government's ability to demonstrate the existence of a default or compensable injury. 
Local road or street. See Street classifications. 
Lot means a portion, plot, or parcel of land separated from other portions, plots, or parcels by description as on a subdivision plat of record or survey map and intended for transfer of ownership or for building development. 
Lot, adjacent, means parcels or lots which are either abutting or separated only by a public right-of-way. 
Lot area means the total area within the boundaries of a lot. 
Lot, conforming, means a lot that meets all requirements of the zoning chapter, Chapter 7 of this title. 
Lot, corner, means a lot abutting upon two or more streets at their intersection. 
Lot, flag (or panhandle lot), means a prohibited lot not meeting minimum frontage requirements and where access to the lot from a public road is achieved by a narrow strip of land. 
Lot improvement means any improvement, facility, or mitigation that is required by this chapter or by conditions of zoning, plat or permit approval that is constructed on one or more privately owned lots. Lot improvements differ from public improvements because public improvements are constructed either on public property, or on the portion of a site that is to be dedicated for public ownership and maintenance. Common lot improvements include, but are not limited to, private drives, parking areas, and recreation facilities, utilities and drainage facilities in private easements, buffers, landscape strips, retaining walls, fences, and detention ponds. 
Lot of record means a lot that has been recorded in the office of the Clerk of the Superior Court, or a parcel of land, the deed of which has been recorded in the office of the Clerk of the Superior Court. 
Lot remnant means any portion or portions of a lot not suitable for building upon because of size or topography and remaining after the transfer of other portions of said lot to adjoining lots or rights-of-way. 
Lowest floor. See Floor, lowest. 
Mean sea level means the average height of the sea for all stages of the tide. It is used as a reference for establishing various elevations within the floodplain. The term "mean sea level" is synonymous with National Geodetic Vertical Datum (NGVD) or the North American Vertical Datum (NAVD) of 1988. 
Minor arterial. See Street classifications. 
Modification means any relief to a regulation or standard of this chapter that is authorized to be approved by the Director and that is in the form of a change in the form, character or quality of a required development practice, specified material, improvement, with or without additional mitigation. A modification differs from a variance only in terms of the character of the relief. The administrative procedures and standards for modifications are found in Section 8-6-28. 
New development means a land development activity on a previously undeveloped site. 
Nonconforming lot means a lot of record that does not conform to the requirements of the City ordinances. 
Nonconforming structure means any structure that does not conform to the requirements of the City zoning chapter, Chapter 7. 
Nonpoint source pollution means a form of water pollution that does not originate from a discrete point such as a sewage treatment plant or industrial discharge, but involves the transport of pollutants such as sediment, fertilizers, pesticides, heavy metals, oil, grease, bacteria, organic materials and other contaminants from land to surface water and groundwater via mechanisms such as precipitation, stormwater runoff, and leaching. Nonpoint source pollution is a by-product of land use practices such as agricultural, silvicultural, mining, construction, subsurface disposal and urban runoff sources. 
Nonresidential means a building, use, or zoning district that does not permit residential uses or buildings. 
Open space means areas that are primarily undeveloped and reserved to provide separation, resource protection, scenic enjoyment, recreation, or amenity to abutting developed property and that are not included in minimum lot areas required in the City zoning chapter, Chapter 7 of this title. 
Owner means the legal or beneficial owner of a site, including but not limited to, a mortgagee or vendee in possession, receiver, executor, trustee, or other person, in control of the site. 
Parcel means any plot, lot or acreage shown as a unit on the latest county tax assessment records. 
Parking lot means any area designed for temporary (less than 48 hours) storage of motor vehicles of the motoring public in normal operating condition. 
Parking, off-street, means a temporary (less than 48 hours) storage area for a motor vehicle that is directly accessible to an access aisle and that is not located on a dedicated street right-of-way. See zoning chapter, Chapter 7 of this title. 
Parking, on-street, means the areas along curbs of a street that are authorized for temporary (less than 48 hours) storage of automobiles belonging to owners, tenants, customers, or visitors of adjacent or nearby properties. See zoning chapter, Chapter 7 of this title. 
Paved means an area which is covered by asphalt, concrete, brick, or pavers meeting the specifications of the Department. Pervious paving materials are subject to approval by the City Manager or his or her designee. 
Permit means the authorization necessary to conduct a land disturbing activity, land development activity, building construction, or other activity regulated by the City that requires an official authorization as provided in these subdivision regulations. 
Permit, building, means a permit issued by the Director, to the owner that is required for undertaking any construction, alteration, addition or repair of a structure under the provisions of this City Code. 
Permit, land disturbance, means the permit issued by the Director to the owner that is required for undertaking any land disturbing or land development activity under the provisions of these subdivision regulations. 
Plan, concept, means written and graphic documents submitted to the Director for review that document the intent of a developer in a conceptual form, indicating the types, general arrangement and density of uses, extent and pattern of subdivision, and the relationship of the intended uses to surrounding tracts. 
Planning Commission means the Conyers-Rockdale Planning Commission. 
Plat means a map, plan or other graphic layout of a land lot, lot, tract, parcel or subdivision indicating the location and boundaries of one or more properties along with improvements subject to these subdivision regulations. 
Plat, final, means a finished drawing or map of a subdivision or development site plan, meeting all of the requirements of this City Code and certified as necessary for recording. See Section 8-6-66. 
Plat, preliminary, means a tentative plan of a proposed subdivision or development meeting the specified requirements of these subdivision regulations and showing the layout in sufficient detail to allow an evaluation of the proposed project. See Section 8-6-61. 
Pollution susceptibility means when used in relation to groundwater recharge areas, the relative vulnerability of an aquifer to being polluted from spills, discharges, leaks, impoundments, applications of chemicals, injections, and other human activities in the recharge area. 
Pre-application conference means an initial, informal and nonbinding stage of development review at which the developer may make known concept plan proposals and the Director may respond and/or advise the developer concerning the development regulations and other issues related to the development. 
Premises means any building, lot, parcel of land, or portion of land whether improved or unimproved including adjacent sidewalks and parking strips. 
Principal arterial. See Street classifications. 
Principal use means the principal purpose for which a lot or the principal building thereon is designed, arranged or intended, and for which it is or may be used, occupied or maintained. 
Private drive means a nonpublic, privately owned and maintained access way. 
Project means the entire proposed development, regardless of the size of the area of land to be disturbed. 
Project improvement means site improvements and facilities that are planned and designed to provide service for a particular development project and that are necessary for the use and convenience of the occupants or users of the project and are not system improvements, as further defined by the Georgia Development Impact Fee Act, O.C.G.A. § 36-71-1. 
Protective covenants means contracts made between private parties or conditions recorded with an approved plat and running with the title to the land, specifying the manner in which land may be use, developed or improved with the intent of protecting and preserving physical and economic integrity of any given area. Private covenants are not enforced by the City. 
Public entity means a Federal, State, county or municipal government, or any agency, authority or public utility of such government that is legally established to provide public services to the citizens of the City. 
Public facilities means a use conducted by, or a facility or structure owned or managed by a unit of government, and intended to provide for needs of the public. 
Public hearing means an official session of any elected or appointed board advertised according to law and called for purposes specified in the public notice. 
Public improvements means any improvement, facility, or service, together with its associated public site or right-of-way. Public improvements differ from lot improvements because public improvements are constructed either on public property, or on the portion of a site undergoing development that is to be dedicated for public ownership and maintenance. Common examples of public improvements include, but are not limited to, streets, sidewalks, curbs, traffic control devices, street signs, streetlights, trees and landscaping planted in rights-of-way, utilities, schools and parks. 
Public sewer means a common sewer controlled by a government agency or public utility, such as the Rockdale County Water and Sewer Authority. 
Public street means right-of-way dedicated to or owned by a public government agency for the purpose of providing principal access to abutting property. 
Required yard. See Yard, required. 
Reserve strip means a strip or parcel of land along, around or between properties, the sole purpose of which is to restrict access. 
Retaining wall. See Wall, retaining. 
Right-of-way means a strip of land dedicated to, designated, reserved, or purchased by the City for the purpose of pedestrian or vehicular access or utility line installation. 
Right-of-way line means the dividing line between a lot, tract or parcel of land and a contiguous right-of-way. 
Right-of-way width means the distance between property lines measured at right angles to the centerline of the street. 
Riparian means belonging or related to the bank of a river, stream, lake, pond or impoundment. 
Runoff. See Nonpoint source pollution. 
Sanitary sewer or sewer means a sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions together with minor quantities of groundwaters, stormwaters and surface waters that are not admitted intentionally. 
Screening means a method of shielding, obscuring or buffering one use or building from another use or building by fencing, walls, densely planted vegetation, natural vegetation, including a transitional buffer or other means; a visual and acoustical barrier which is of such nature and density that provides year-round maximum capacity from the ground to a height of at least six feet. 
Security means a cash deposit, cash escrow account or letter of credit payable to the City that is held in reserve as a guarantee of performance or maintenance as provided in Section 8-6-28. Such securities must be managed by a secure financial institution in a separate, restricted account attributable to the property or property owner making the deposit. Withdrawal or use of the funds in the security is restricted to specified parties for specified purposes within a fixed period of time, and may be used by the City upon failure of the escrowing party to make guaranteed improvements in a timely manner or to perform required maintenance activities. See Section 8-6-28. 
Sediment means solid material, both organic and inorganic, that is in suspension, is being transported, or has been moved from its site of origin by air, water, ice, or gravity as a product of erosion. 
Sedimentation means the process by which eroded material is transported and deposited by the action of water, wind, ice or gravity. 
Septic tank means an approved watertight tank designed or used to receive sewage from a building sewer and to affect separation and organic decomposition of sewage solids, and discharging sewage effluent to an absorption field or other management system. 
Setback means with respect to a structure abutting lot line, the shortest distance between the right-of-way of a street or an adjacent property line and the nearest wall of the building or structure on a lot. Buildings may not be placed within a required setback. 
Sewage. See Wastewater. 
Sewer means a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or stormwater. 
Shoulder means that portion of the street or road from the outer edge of the paved surface or back of curb to the inside edge of the ditch or gutter or original ground surface. 
Sidewalk means the portion of the right-of-way which is parallel to the street or road which is intended for pedestrian traffic, and meeting the requirements of Section 8-6-84(a) through (h). 
Site means any plot, parcel or area of land or combination of contiguous lots or parcels of land. 
Start of Construction. See Construction, start of. 
State waters means any and all rivers, streams, creeks, branches, lakes, reservoirs, ponds, drainage systems, springs, wells, and all other bodies of surface or subsurface water, natural or artificial, lying within or forming a part of the boundaries of the State which are not entirely confined and retained completely upon the property of a single individual, partnership, or corporation.
