Editor's note— Ord. No. 944, § 1, adopted October 16, 2013, repealed former Ch. 1., §§ 9-1-1—9-1-179, and enacted a new Ch. 1 as set out herein. Former Ch. 1 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 907, § 1(Exh. A), 1-19-2013. 
State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; authority to adopt rules and regulations relating to manufacture, sale and distribution of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-49. 

ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 9-1-1. - Purpose. 
This chapter has been enacted for the purposes, among others, of promoting the health and general welfare of the community, to establish reasonable and ascertainable standards for the regulation and control of the licensing and sales of alcoholic beverages; to protect and preserve schools and churches; to give effect to existing land use; and to preserve certain residential areas, with reasonable considerations, among others, to the character of the areas and their peculiar suitability for particular uses, the congestion in the roads and streets, and with a general view of promoting desirable living conditions and sustaining the stability of neighborhoods and property values. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-2. - Sales to be licensed; compliance with ordinance and State law required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale for consumption off of the premises or to offer for sale for consumption on the premises any alcoholic beverages within the City without having first complied with the provisions of this chapter. No person shall sell or possess for the purpose of sale any alcoholic beverage unless such person has a license from the City to sell or possess for sale alcoholic beverages. No person shall sell alcoholic beverages or make deliveries of alcoholic beverages beyond the boundaries of the premises covered by the license except as specifically permitted herein. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-3. - Sale within the incorporated areas of the City; license a privilege. 
(a)  Alcoholic beverages may be sold within the incorporated areas of the City under an annual license granted by the City Manager or his/her designee as governed by the terms and conditions hereafter provided. 
(b)  Any and all licenses granted herein are not a right, but are a mere grant of a privilege to carry on the business during the term of the license subject to all terms and conditions imposed by the ordinances of the City and State law. 
(c)  All licenses hereunder shall have printed on the front these words: "THIS LICENSE IS A MERE PRIVILEGE THAT IS SUBJECT TO BEING REVOKED OR SUSPENDED AND IS SUBJECT TO ANY FUTURE ORDINANCES WHICH MAY BE ENACTED. THE CITY IS UNDER NO OBLIGATION TO RENEW THIS LICENSE AFTER ITS EXPIRATION." 
(d)  Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this chapter the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violator of any such provision shall be subject to prosecution in Conyers Municipal Court and shall be subject to the penalty provisions contained in Section 7-103 of the City Charter and further the licensee shall be subject to the administrative penalties as set forth herein. 
(e)  Any violation of this chapter, of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated including any future amendments thereto or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the alcohol and tobacco tax division of the Georgia Department of Revenue including any future amendments thereto shall subject a licensee to the administrative penalties as set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-4. - Definitions. 
The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2 ("Alcoholic Beverages-General Provisions-Definitions"), shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2. For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply: 
(a)  Administrative penalty(ies) means those penalty(ies) set forth in Sections 9-1-155 and 9-1-156 of this chapter, as may be amended from time to time. 
(b)  Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, from whatever source or by whatever process produced. 
(c)  Alcoholic beverages means and includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages, wine or fortified wine. 
(d)  Alcoholic beverage handling permit shall mean the written authorization by the City Manager or his/her designee for a person to participate in the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(e)  Beer or malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops, or any other product, or any combination of such products in water containing not more than 14 percent alcohol by volume, and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer, strong beer, and hard cider as may be defined by State law. 
(f)  Bona fide nonprofit civic organization is an entity that is exempt from federal income tax pursuant to the provisions of subsection (c), (d) or (e) of 26 U.S.C. Section 50l. 
(g)  Brewpub is a restaurant in which beer or malt beverages are manufactured or brewed subject to State law barrel production limitations for retail consumption on the premises and sold solely in draft form. 
(h)  Building code means and includes all building, plumbing and electrical codes and any other similar technical code of the City. 
(i)  Church shall mean a permanent building where persons regularly assemble for religious worship. 
(j)  City shall mean the City of Conyers, Georgia. 
(k)  City Manager or his/her designee shall mean the City Manager and anyone designated by the City Manager to perform the official City duties as set forth in this chapter. 
(l)  Courtyard means an area open or partially open to the sky and enclosed or surrounded on all sides by buildings, walls, fences or other such structures, or a combination thereof. 
(m)  Distance for the purposes of this chapter only shall be measured in lineal feet and shall be the most direct route of travel on the ground from the front entrance of the proposed location to the nearest property line of the parcel of property to which the distance is being measured. 
(n)  Distilled spirits shall mean any alcoholic beverages containing alcohol obtained by distillation, mixed with water or other substance in solution, and includes brandy, rum, whiskey, gin, cordials, or other spirituous liquors by whatever name called to include fortified wines, as defined by the Federal Alcohol Administration. 
(o)  Drinking place means a place of business that is authorized to sell alcoholic beverages for immediate consumption on the premises, and where the sale of food (including nonalcoholic beverages) is incidental to the sale of such alcoholic beverages. A drinking place shall not impose a minimum charge or cover charge. Drinking places shall not permit the entry of any person that is under 21 years of age on the premises. Entertainment customarily incidental and subordinate to the traditional operations of a drinking place such as karaoke, DJs, individual or small group vocalists and/or instrumentalists that provide music, recorded music, televised programming, et cetera, may be supplied for its guests; but in no circumstance shall chairs and/or tables be rearranged for the viewing of such entertainment. Drinking places may include, but shall not be limited to: bars or cocktail lounges. 
(p)  Golf course shall mean an outdoor golf course covering three acres or more and containing at least nine tees, fairways and greens. "Outdoor golf course sales" refers to sales made outside the clubhouse or other primary structure and on or immediately adjacent to the golf course itself from a mobile or satellite location. 
(q)  Growler shall mean a container of not more than 64 ounces that is capable of being sealed with a tamper-proof cap and that is designed to be used and is in fact used for the purpose of being filled with a malt beverage from a tap. 
(r)  Hours of operation shall mean the hours during which a licensed establishment may remain open for various purposes, including the sale of alcoholic beverages on or off premises. 
(s)  Hotel shall mean a premises that consists of one or multiple buildings that are under single management that rents rooms and/or suites intended primarily as sleeping accommodations for public rental on a daily, or weekly basis. All hotels shall maintain a central, internal lobby, and provide daily room cleaning and linen changes. Supportive activities that are customarily incidental and subordinate to the traditional operations of a hotel such as, but shall not be limited to: drinking places, meeting rooms, recreational and fitness facilities, restaurants, retail, swimming pools or other similar facilities/services, may be supplied. Entertainment shall be restricted to entertainment customarily incidental and subordinate to the traditional operations of a drinking place or restaurant such as karaoke, individual or small group vocalists and/or instrumentalists that provide background music, recorded music, televised programming, etc., said forms of entertainment may be supplied for its guests, but in no circumstance shall chairs and/or tables be rearranged for the viewing of such entertainment. Motels shall be considered hotels. 
(t)  Indoor commercial recreational establishment shall mean and is limited to an indoor establishment: 
(1)  In which the sale of food (including nonalcoholic beverages) and alcoholic beverages is incidental to its primary activity on the premises and which shall derive at least 50 percent of its total annual gross sales from its primary activity; 
(2)  In which meals are served, such place being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining equipment and a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its customers. Said establishment shall be prepared to serve food every hour they are open; and 
(3)  In which the primary activity on the premises of the indoor commercial recreational establishment shall be family oriented in nature, generally meaning a use that attracts a range of individuals from all age groups. Uses may specifically include, but are not limited to, bowling centers, billiard parlors, video arcades, skating arenas and other similar uses. Bingo parlors, dance halls, nightclubs, adult entertainment and/or sexually related entertainment activities as defined in the City's adult entertainment establishment ordinances, Title 9, Chapter 10 et seq., and similar uses are specifically excluded from this definition of indoor commercial recreational establishments. 
(u)  License shall mean the written authorization by the City Manager or his/her designee to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages for the specified period of time. 
(v)  Licensee means the individual to whom a license is issued or, in the case of a partnership, corporation or company, all partners, officers, members, managers, and directors of the partnership, corporation or company. 
(w)  Live entertainment shall mean any combination of the following activities performed live by one or more persons for the amusement needs of the public generally, whether for a minimum charge or cover charge, or no cover charge at all, which may include, but shall not be limited to, the following: comedy, dancing, magic acts, musical acts (excluding karaoke), revues, theatrical acts (including plays), etc. Adult entertainment shall not be considered a form of live entertainment. 
(x)  Lounge means a separate room connected with a part of, and adjacent to a restaurant or located in hotels as defined herein with all booths, stools and tables being unobstructed and open to view. All lounges shall be air conditioned and have a seating capacity of at least 20 persons. 
(y)  Manager means the person who is on the premises of a licensed establishment and who is responsible for the supervision of employees who are involved in the service or sale of alcoholic beverages and who is authorized to interface with and to accept legal documents from the City regarding the sale of alcoholic beverages at that moment in time. 
(z)  Manufacturer means any maker, producer, or bottler of an alcoholic beverage. The term also means: 
(1)  In the case of distilled spirits, any person engaged in distilling, rectifying, or blending any distilled spirits; 
(2)  In the case of malt beverages, any brewer; and 
(3)  In the case of wine, any vintner. 
(aa)  Moral turpitude shall include any misdemeanor criminal offenses involving fraud, theft, identity theft or dishonesty, misdemeanor drug offenses, and any felony offense. However, all applicants shall be entitled to the full benefits of O.C.G.A. § 42-8-60 et seq. relating to first offender status if they were sentenced under the First Offender Act by the sentencing court. 
(bb)  Nightclub shall mean a place of business that is authorized to supply live entertainment for the amusement needs of the public generally, and may exclude persons under 18 years of age, and where the preparation and sale of food (including nonalcoholic beverages) and/or alcoholic beverages may be incidental to the provision of such live entertainment. Nightclubs may require a minimum charge or a cover charge. Nightclubs may include, but shall not be limited to: comedy clubs, dance clubs, dinner theaters, discotheques (including teen), etc. 
(cc)  Package alcoholic beverages means a bottle, can, keg barrel, or other original consumer container sold by a package store to a consumer for consumption off premises. 
(dd)  Package store shall mean a geographic location within the City wherein a license may be issued for the sale of package alcoholic beverages. Such package store must be operated as a distinct business and cannot be operated in conjunction with or as a part of any other business, except only as provided in this chapter and/or by the laws of this State. 
(ee)  Patio shall be defined as that portion of an establishment that is outside the main structure but only accessible from the main structure and is used for sales of food and/or beverages. 
(ff)  Performing arts facility shall mean and is limited to an establishment: 
(1)  That has as its principal objective or business the presentation of live music, mainline dramatic arts, plays, theatre productions and stand-up comedy; and 
(2)  That does not feature, show, allow, promote or advertise adult entertainment as defined and regulated in Title 9, Chapter 10 of the City's Code of Ordinances, including but not limited to adult dancing establishments, adult mini-motion picture theatres, adult motion picture theatres, adult motion picture arcades and erotic dance establishments. 
(gg)  Person means any individual, firm, partnership, cooperative, nonprofit membership corporation, joint venture, association, company, corporation, agency, syndicate, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, fiduciary, or other group or combination acting as a unit, body politic, or political subdivision, whether public, private, or quasi-public. 
(hh)  Premises shall mean: 
(1)  The definite closed or partitioned in-facility including, but not limited to, a room, shop or building wherein alcoholic beverages are sold. 
(2)  The temporarily or permanently defined areas of publicly owned property approved by the City for the consumption of alcoholic beverages on premises when the alcoholic beverages being consumed are sold by one holding a license for on premises consumption for an establishment that is immediately adjacent to such defined areas of publicly owned property. 
(3)  The temporarily defined areas of publicly owned property approved by the City for the consumption of alcoholic beverages on premises when the alcoholic beverages being consumed are sold or distributed by one holding a license for on premises consumption within the temporarily defined areas of publicly owned property and the sales or distribution are actually occurring. 
(ii)  RASS workshop shall mean a workshop conducted by the City to educate alcoholic beverage handlers on legal issues, restrictions, and regulations related to the responsible sales and service of alcoholic beverages. 
(jj)  Restaurant means a place of business that is authorized to prepare, cook and sell food (including nonalcoholic beverages) for immediate consumption either on, or off the premises, and where the preparation and sale of alcoholic beverages for immediate consumption on the premises, may be incidental to the sale of such food, for adequate pay, without a minimum charge or cover charge. Restaurants shall not exclude any person, and shall derive at least 50 percent of its total annual gross sales from the preparation and sale of food. Entertainment customarily incidental and subordinate to the traditional operations of a restaurant such as karaoke, DJs, individual or small group vocalists and/or instrumentalists that provide music, recorded music, televised programming, et cetera, may be supplied for its guests; but in no circumstance shall chairs and/or tables be rearranged for the viewing of such entertainment. Restaurants may include a separate, designated room within the building utilized on a temporary basis to accommodate private events; as used herein, "private event" shall mean a gathering of persons who have been individually invited to the event, and from which persons that are not so invited, are excluded. Food items and alcoholic or nonalcoholic beverages for private events shall be purchased from the restaurant hosting the private event. Any floor area used for dancing, speaking or other similar activities during a private event shall not exceed 100 square feet. Restaurants may include, but shall not be limited to: fast-food restaurants, full-service restaurants or limited service-restaurants. 
(kk)  Retail sales shall mean selling or offering for sale alcoholic beverages to any member of the public wherein consumption on the premises is prohibited. 
(ll)  Retailer or retail dealer means any person who sells alcoholic beverages at retail only to consumers wherein consumption on the premises is prohibited. 
(mm)  School means such State, County, City, church or other primary or secondary schools that teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools of this State and shall include private schools where only specialized subjects such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations and other special subjects are taught. 
(nn)  Sidewalk café means an area on the sidewalk that is associated with an abutting restaurant that contains chairs and tables, and sometimes benches, that is used for the sale and the consumption of food and/or beverages, outdoors. In no circumstance shall any preparation and/or cooking of food and beverages, nor the cooling, refrigeration, storage or any other similar activity related to the preparation and serving of food and/or beverages, occur within the confines of a sidewalk café. 
(oo)  Temporary special event means an event hosted by a bona fide nonprofit civic organization in which alcoholic beverages are sold for consumption on the premises. 
(pp)  Temporary special event license means a license issued to a bona fide nonprofit civic organization, authorizing the bona fide nonprofit civic organization to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises for a period not to exceed three calendar days. 
(qq)  Wholesaler or wholesale dealer means any person who sells alcoholic beverages to other wholesale dealers, to retail dealers, or to retail consumption dealers. 
(rr)  Wine shall mean any alcoholic beverages containing not more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines, champagnes, combinations of such beverages, vermouths, special natural wines, rectified wines, and like products. The term does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. A liquid shall first be deemed to be a wine at that point in the manufacturing process when it conforms to the definition of wine contained in this section. Fortified wine means any alcoholic beverage containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries, or grapes, either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. "Fortified wine" includes, but is not limited to, brandy. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014; Ord. No. 994, § 1, 8-19-2015; Ord. No. 1062, §§ 1, 2, 4-19-2017) 
Sec. 9-1-5. - Inspection of licensed establishments. 
At all times that an establishment holding a license issued under this chapter is open for business, the establishment shall be open to inspection by any officer of the police department, any licensed inspector of the City, or to any person designated by the Chief of Police or the City Manager. In addition, if the premises are being used before or after hours by employees or the owners or their agents, the premises may be inspected at such time by the designated persons in this section. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-6. - License and signs to be exhibited. 
(a)  Each license issued under this chapter shall at all times be kept in public in a public area plainly exposed to view upon the licensed premises. 
(b)  All holders of a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages regulated by this chapter shall be required to post such signs in a conspicuous location in their place of business as are required by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-24.2 and Georgia Department of Revenue regulations. 
(c)  Failure to post the notices as required herein shall constitute a violation of this chapter and shall be punishable in the Municipal Court as provided in Section 9-1-157. The penalty contained in this section shall be in addition to any administrative penalties that may be taken with regard to the holders' license as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-7. - Responsibility of licensee for violations. 
The licensee shall be subject to administrative penalties for any acts of their agents or their employees that are in violation of this chapter or of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division of the Georgia Department of Revenue. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-8. - Production of records; audits. 
(a)  In conjunction with any application for a license, or in conjunction with any license which has been issued under the terms hereof, or in conjunction with the revocation, suspension or cancellation of any license, or in conjunction with the payment or nonpayment of any excise tax levied or to be collected under this chapter, the City Manager or his/her designee shall have the right to demand the timely production of all or any part of the records, books, documents, electronic or magnetic media and associated software, reports or invoices of any licensee for the purpose of auditing the records of such licensee, securing compliance by such licensee with the provisions of this chapter, proving or disproving violation of any part of this chapter by any licensee, or showing payment or nonpayment of any taxes, fees, charges or the like due hereunder. 
(b)  All licensed establishments must maintain the following records for a three-year period and make the original records or certified copies available to the City upon the City's request within 72 hours: 
(1)  Monthly income or operating statements; and 
(2)  Monthly Georgia Sales and Use Tax Reports. 
(c)  Any failure to comply with the terms of this section shall subject the licensee to administrative penalties. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-9. - Invoices. 
(a)  Upon each and every delivery by a licensed wholesaler to a licensed retailer, an invoice in triplicate shall be prepared showing the quantities and brands of distilled spirits, malt beverages and wine delivered, together with the price thereof and the excise tax due and collected thereon. The original of such invoice shall be delivered by the wholesaler to the retailer simultaneously with such delivery. The wholesaler shall retain the second copy of such invoice and shall keep it for a period of 36 months after the date of delivery and during such thirty-six-month period, such invoices shall be made available for inspection by the City Manager or his/her designee or duly authorized representatives. The remaining copy of the invoice shall be distributed in accordance with Georgia law. Upon request of the City, a copy of such invoice shall be attached to any reports requested or required by the City. 
(b)  Each retailer doing business in the City shall keep and maintain accurate and complete records regarding the purchases and sales made by such business including, but not limited to, the original invoice of purchase by him from a wholesaler of any alcoholic beverages and shall maintain such records for at least 36 months after the date of such purchase. Such records shall reveal the gross sales from the operation of their business and the exact quantities of distilled spirits, malt beverages and wines by size and type of container purchased by such retail dealer together with the dates of delivery of such shipments by wholesale dealers as well as the identity of each wholesale dealer from whom such licensee purchases alcoholic beverages. The City or its duly authorized representative shall have the right to inspect the records of each retailer and make a complete audit of the records of each retailer at any time. Failure of a retailer to maintain proper records showing receipt of alcoholic beverages, payment therefore, and payment of the taxes due thereon to the appropriate wholesaler, and records which clearly show the sales, the amount of sales, and the types of sales of each retailer may, at the discretion of the City Manager or his/her designee, after a hearing as herein provided, result in the revocation or suspension of such license. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-10. - Penalties established for failure to keep records. 
(a)  If any wholesaler or retailer fails to keep and maintain the records of sales as required by this chapter or if a wholesaler or retailer refuses to allow an audit as provided by this chapter, then the license of such wholesaler or retailer shall be subject to administrative penalties. 
(b)  In the event that an audit of the records required to be kept by wholesalers and retailers under the terms of this chapter are found to vary from the monthly reports required to be furnished by the wholesalers to the City and such discrepancies are not explained to the satisfaction of the City Manager or his/her designee, the license of such wholesaler or retailer shall be subject to administrative penalties. If it appears to the City Manager or his/her designee that any retailer participated in or conspired with any wholesaler to falsify or keep and maintain incorrect records of such sales in order to avoid payment of the taxes imposed by this chapter, then all licenses of the licensees involved in such scheme shall be subject to administrative penalties as provided for under this chapter. In the event that any person intentionally falsified or intentionally failed to keep and maintain correct records of such sales, then that person shall be subject to the penalty provisions contained in Section 7-103 of the City's Charter. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-11. - Duration of licenses. 
(a)  All licenses, except as otherwise indicated, issued under this chapter shall be issued for the remaining portion of a calendar year, and all licenses shall expire at 11:59 p.m. on December 31 of each year regardless of issue date. 
(b)  No licensee shall have any vested right to renewal of any license issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-12. - Distance requirements. 
(a)  No person knowingly and intentionally may sell or offer to sell any distilled spirits for off-premises consumption: 
(1)  Within 200 yards of any school property; or 
(2)  Within 100 yards of any church building or alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by the State or any county or municipal government therein. 
(b)  No person knowingly and intentionally may sell or offer to sell for off-premises consumption any malt beverages or wines: 
(1)  Within 100 yards of any school property; or 
(2)  Within 100 yards of any alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by the State or any county or municipal government therein. 
(c)  No person knowingly and intentionally may sell or offer to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises: 
(1)  Within 100 yards of an alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by the State or any county or municipal government therein. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-13. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  Retail distilled spirits . The exterior entrances of retail stores for the sale of distilled spirits hereunder must be locked during the hours for which the sale of any distilled spirits is prohibited. Licensees shall not engage in the sale of any distilled spirits except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m., Monday through Saturday, and between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sunday. 
(b)  Retail malt beverages and wines . Licensees in the retail sale of malt beverages and wines shall be allowed to engage in the sale of such beverages for 24 hours a day Monday through Saturday and between the hours of 12:30 p.m. until 11:30 p.m. on Sunday. 
(c)  Consumption on the premises . No distilled spirits, malt beverages or wine shall be sold for consumption on the premises except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 3:00 a.m. of the following morning on Monday through Friday, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and 1:00 a.m. of the following Sunday morning, and between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Sunday. Each and every person shall be required to vacate the premises no later than one hour past any required closing time. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014; Ord. No. 1140, § 1, 7-18-2018) 
Sec. 9-1-14. - Exterior advertisement prohibited. 
(a)  No placard or sign which is visible from the exterior of the licensed premises shall make reference to the price of any distilled spirits sold therein, except that tags showing the prices of individual bottles or containers may be affixed to the bottles or containers or to the edge of the shelf whereon the bottles or containers are located. 
(b)  Advertisement of malt beverages or wines cannot be affixed or displayed in the window of any establishment licensed for retail sale. Any placards or advertisements of malt beverages or wines must be displayed from inside the location. There shall be no advertisements to the price of any malt beverages or wines visible from the outside of such establishment. 
(c)  No show-window advertising or display shall be visible from the exterior of the primary use structure, and no sign shall be erected anywhere within the City advertising the sale of distilled spirits by the drink. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-15. - Prohibition on service of alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to serve, dispense, or sell an alcoholic beverage while under the influence of alcohol. 
(b)  Inasmuch as the alcoholic beverage handling permits granted within this chapter are not a right, but a mere grant of privilege, all persons who are granted an alcoholic beverage handling permit under this chapter shall be deemed to consent to a breathalyzer test in the event that the Chief of Police or his/her designee has a reasonable basis to believe that such person is serving, dispensing or selling alcoholic beverages while under the influence of alcohol. 
(1)  In the event that such person is found to have an alcohol concentration of 0.05 grams or more, then such person will be deemed to have been serving, dispensing or selling alcoholic beverages while under the influence of alcohol, which shall be grounds for the revocation of such person's alcoholic beverage handling permit and the imposition of administrative penalties. 
(2)  A refusal by such person to submit to a breathalyzer test shall be grounds for the revocation of such person's alcoholic beverage handling permit and the imposition of administrative penalties. 
(c)  If an employee violates this section, then the licensee shall be subject to administrative penalties. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-16. - Drive-in window or curb service. 
It  shall be unlawful to sell alcoholic beverages from a "drive-in" or "service" window. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Secs. 9-1-17—9-1-19. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 968, § 1, adopted June 4, 2014, amended the Code by repealing former § 9-1-17, which pertained to fees, and derived from Ord. No. 950, § I, adopted November 20, 2013. 
ARTICLE B. - APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 9-1-20. - Application procedures. 
All persons must follow the applicable procedures hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-21. - Procedure for considering application. 
The City Manager or his/her designee shall not consider any application for a license until the written application provided for herein is made, the investigative fee paid, the plat required herein filed and the fingerprinting and investigation of all persons as required under this chapter has been completed by the police department. The Chief of Police shall, upon completion of the investigation, file a written report of the results of such investigation, which report shall be attached to said application and form a part of the permanent City record. Upon the completion of all of the foregoing, the application, together with all data, shall be submitted to the City Manager or his/her designee for consideration pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-22. - Application; data; information; requirement for. 
Applicants are required to complete all aspects of all prescribed forms required under this chapter. The failure to provide all information required by such forms may result in denial of any application under this chapter. All applicants shall furnish all omitted data, information and records requested of them by the City Manager or his/her designee or the Chief of Police, and the failure to furnish such omitted data, information and records within 30 calendar days from the date of such request shall automatically serve to cause such application to be denied. The applicants, by filing an application for a license permitted under this chapter, agree to produce, for oral interview, any person or persons requested by the City Manager or his/her designee or the Chief of Police, considered by either as being important in ascertaining the facts relative to such application and/or licenses issued under this chapter. The failure to produce such person or persons within 30 calendar days after being requested to do so shall result in the automatic denial of any application pending under this chapter. The application form and all data requested by the City Manager or his/her designee or the Chief of Police shall be subscribed by the applicant(s) under oath before a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths. Any untrue or misleading information contained in, or material statement omitted from, an original, renewal or transfer application for a license shall be cause for the denial or revocation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-23. - Citizenship; residence requirements; corporation requirements. 
No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be issued in the name of any individual who is not a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully permitted for permanent residence. Where the applicant is a corporation or other business entity other than an individual, any person, stockholder or principal owning more than a ten percent financial interest must meet the requirements contained herein as if the license was to be issued in their name, and in the event any license provided for hereunder shall be issued, such license shall be issued in the name of the corporation or business entity and the principal stockholder or principal behind such business entity. If the applicant is a partnership, the requirements contained herein shall be met by all partners, whether general or limited partners. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-24. - Annexation of licensed businesses. 
Any person, persons, establishment or other entity that holds a license from a county for the sale of alcoholic beverages and that is located in an area annexed by the City, shall have 30 calendar days from the effective date of the annexation to apply for the appropriate licenses and permits under this chapter. However, all applicable fees and costs for the equivalent license(s) in the City shall be waived for the year of annexation. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-25. - Other licenses. 
The license fees provided for in this chapter are not levied in lieu of any other license fees or taxes that may be levied upon licensees, but are in addition thereto. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-26. - Applications for license. 
(a)  The provisions of this Code regarding occupation taxes shall apply in addition to the provisions in this section. 
(b)  All applications for licenses under this chapter shall be accompanied by a payment in cash, credit/debit card, personal/business check, or by cashiers/certified check, for all the fees and occupation taxes provided for in the City's Code for the classification into which the applicant falls. 
(c)  All City applications shall be in original form and shall be accompanied by a full photocopy of all the appropriate State applications. 
(d)  Any false statement or material misrepresentation in any application hereunder shall be grounds for the denial of any application or for the revocation of any license granted hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-27. - Notice of intention to secure license for sale of distilled spirits. 
(a)  No application for a license for the sale of distilled spirits, either for retail sale or for consumption on premises, shall be acted upon until after the applicant has published in the newspaper that publishes the legal advertisements of the City a notice of his intention to secure a license for sale of distilled spirits. Such notice shall be published at least once during the 30 calendar days immediately preceding the filing of the application for a license. Such notice shall be in large boldface type and shall state: 
(1)  The type of license for which application has been filed; 
(2)  The exact location of the place of business for which a license is sought; 
(3)  The names and addresses of each owner of the business; and 
(4)  If the applicant is a corporation, the names and titles of all corporate officers. 
(b)  Proof of publication of the notice required by this section shall be attached to an application for a license for sale of distilled spirits, both for retail sale and for consumption on premises. 
(c)  An applicant for a renewal license for the sale of distilled spirits shall not be subject to the notice requirements of this section. However, the notice section shall apply to all other applications for a license for the sale of distilled spirits, including, but not limited to, an application involving a new business, a change of location and a change of license holder. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-28. - Application forms. 
(a)  All persons desiring to receive a license shall make application on a form prescribed by the City Manager or his/her designee. No application will be processed until the applicant has completed the required interview with the City Manager or his/her designee. 
(b)  The application shall include but shall not be limited to: the name and address of the applicant; the proposed business to be carried on; if a partnership, the names and residence address of the partners, the name of the manager, and the name of all shareholders holding more than ten percent of any class of corporate stock, or any other entity having a financial interest in each entity which is to own or operate the establishment for which a license is sought. If the manager changes, the applicant must furnish the City Manager or his/her designee the name and address of the new manager and other information as requested within ten calendar days of such change. 
(c)  There shall be separate processing fees to cover the expense of an investigation and the expense of processing the application, which fees shall not be refundable. The amount of the investigation fee and the processing fee for the application shall be as established by the City Council, from time to time. 
(d)  All applications shall contain proof that the location of the proposed premises complies with all zoning and planning requirements. 
(e)  All applicants shall furnish data, information and records as required by the City Manager or his/her designee and to ensure compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Failure to furnish data as requested shall cause the application to be denied. 
(f)  A complete set of fingerprints of each applicant for a new license shall be required. 
(1)  Authority. This subsection is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2), the Georgia Umbrella Statute entitled "Dissemination of information to public agencies, political subdivisions, authorities, and instrumentalities." 
(2)  Fingerprinting required. An individual seeking to receive an alcoholic beverage license shall be fingerprinted as a condition of submitting an application for a new license. By filing such application, the applicant consents to the City obtaining their criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). While fingerprinting shall typically only be required at the time of the initial application, the submission by the applicant of a renewal application shall authorize the City to request a new set of fingerprints if needed and shall authorize the City to once again obtain the applicant's criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). 
(3)  Access authorized; usage regulations. 
a.  The City is hereby authorized to access national criminal history record information pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2). 
b.  Information obtained and handled for any purposes pursuant to this subsection shall comply with all Georgia laws and the Federal Privacy Act. 
c.  No information given as part of the request for a criminal history and no record obtained pursuant to this section may be entered on any database. 
d.  No information given or obtained pursuant to this section shall be subject to the provisions of the Georgia Open Records Act. 
(4)  Administration; fees; procedures. 
a.  Applicant shall provide his/her fingerprints, which may be taken by the City of Conyers Police Department or may be taken at any Georgia Applicant Processing Services location so long as the applicant registers in such a manner that allows the Conyers Police Department to receive the criminal history results. 
b.  The applicant shall bear the cost of the electronic fingerprinting submission services set by the Georgia Applicant Processing Services and an administrative fee allowed by statute to be charged by the City, which shall be the maximum allowed by statute, which is currently $20.00, which fee shall include fingerprinting when carried out by the Conyers Police Department. 
c.  Upon receipt of the fingerprints and the appropriate fees, the City will transmit said fingerprints and appropriate fees (unless a satisfactory billing arrangement has been entered into between the City Police Department and the GCIC and/or FBI) to the GCIC. As provided by law, the GCIC will compare the subject's fingerprints against its criminal file and submit the fingerprints to the FBI for a comparison with nation-wide records, unless submission to the FBI is automatic pursuant to the use of live-scan. The results of the FBI check will be returned based on its current procedure, presently being directly to the City Police Department if submissions are made manually to the GCIC, or electronically from both the GBI and FBI where submissions are made electronically to the GCIC. 
d.  In compliance with Federal law 95-544, which provides for the rendering of a "fitness determination," the City will decide whether the applicant has been convicted of, or is under pending indictment for enumerated disqualifiers, as set forth within this chapter. 
e.  A person who has consented to the City for a criminal history based on fingerprinting record may request and receive a copy of the criminal history record report from the City at no additional charge. Should the person seek to amend or correct the record, he or she shall be responsible for contacting the GCIC as to Georgia records and/or the FBI concerning records from other jurisdictions maintained in its file. 
(g)  All applications shall be sworn to by the applicant before a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths. 
(h)  The City shall have 60 calendar days to process any completed application for a license under the terms of this chapter, provided that the 60 calendar days may be extended by agreement of the applicant and the City. In the event that the City does not issue a decision on the completed application within this time period, then the application fee shall be refunded to the applicant and shall be waived with respect to the present application only. 
(i)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall provide written notice to any applicant whose application is denied under the provisions of this chapter, which shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for such denial and shall advise the applicant of the right to appeal under the provisions of this chapter. 
(j)  In the event the applicant is denied a license by the State, any alcoholic beverage license fee paid to the City shall be refunded, but all other application and investigative fees paid to the City shall be retained by the City. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-29. - Separate application and separate license for each location of sale. 
A separate application must be made for each location of sale, and, if such application is granted, a separate license must be issued for each location of sale. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-30. - Restriction upon transfers. 
Licenses under this chapter may not be transferred to another person except as otherwise provided in this chapter. Instead, all persons desiring licenses shall make application to the City for a new license and pay any appropriate fees and occupation taxes, and that person must otherwise meet the requirements hereunder for a new license. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-31. - Change of location. 
(a)  All persons desiring to change the physical location of their premises where alcoholic beverages are sold shall make application on a form prescribed by the City Manager or his/her designee. 
(b)  An application for a change of location shall included the following information: 
(1)  Proof of planning and zoning compliance; 
(2)  Proof of building code compliance; 
(3)  A legal description of the property upon which the new premises is located; and 
(4)  An affidavit from a registered surveyor stating that the establishment complies with any distance or location requirements contained in this chapter or otherwise imposed by law or regulation. 
(c)  There shall be separate processing fees to cover the expense of an investigation and the expense of processing the change of location application, which fees shall not be refundable. The amount of the investigation fee and the processing fee for the application shall be as established by the City Council, from time to time. 
(d)  Failure to furnish data as requested shall cause the change of location application to be denied. 
(e)  The City shall have 60 calendar days to process any completed change of location application, provided that the 60 calendar days may be extended by agreement of the applicant and the City. In the event that the City does not issue a decision on the completed change of location application within this time period, then the application fee shall be refunded to the applicant and shall be waived with respect to the present change of location application only. 
(f)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall provide written notice to any applicant whose application is denied under the provisions of this chapter, which shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for such denial and shall advise the applicant of the right to appeal under the provisions of this chapter. 
(g)  If the proposed change of location relates to a license for the sale of distilled spirits on the premises or off-premises, the change of location application shall not be acted upon until the applicant has published in the newspaper which publishes the legal advertisements of the City a notice of his intention to change locations for the sale of distilled spirits. Such notice shall be published at least once during the 30 calendar days immediately preceding request for a change of location. Such notice shall be in large boldface type and shall state: 
(1)  The exact location of the place of business for which the change is being sought; 
(2)  The names and addresses of each owner of the business; and 
(3)  If the applicant is a corporation, the names and titles of all corporate officers. 
(h)  Proof of publication of the notice required by this section shall be attached to an application for change of location. 
(i)  Any change of location allowed under this section may be denied or revoked on the same basis as for an application for license under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-32. - Effect of expiration, surrender, revocation or suspension of license. 
In the event that a license expires, is surrendered, revoked or suspended, the establishment shall immediately cease selling alcoholic beverages as of 11:59 p.m. on the date of said expiration, surrender, revocation or suspension. Any appeal procedures related to the suspension or revocation of a license by the City that is utilized by a licensee, as set forth herein, shall have the effect of tolling any revocation or suspension of the license until the appeal process has become final. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-33. - Substitution of licensee. 
(a)  In the event that a licensee severs his association with a licensed establishment, whether by resignation or by termination with his employer, then the establishment may continue to sell alcoholic beverages under the existing license for a period not to exceed 45 calendar days from the date that is determined to be the date of severance which shall be subject to being shortened in the event that the license expires or is suspended or revoked. 
(b)  The application for a substitute licensee shall require substantially the same information as the initial application, including a complete investigation of the criminal history of the licensee. 
(c)  There shall be separate processing fees to cover the expense of an investigation and the expense of processing the substitute licensee application, which fees shall not be refundable. The amount of the investigation fee and the processing fee for the application shall be as established by the City Council, from time to time. 
(d)  Failure to furnish data as requested shall cause the substitute licensee application to be denied. 
(e)  The City shall have 60 calendar days to process any completed substitute licensee application, provided that the 60 calendar days may be extended by agreement of the applicant and the City. In the event that the City does not issue a decision on the completed substitute licensee application within this time period, then the application fee shall be refunded to the applicant and shall be waived with respect to the present substitute licensee application only. 
(f)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall provide written notice to any applicant whose application is denied, which shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for such denial and shall advise the applicant of the right to appeal under the provisions of this chapter. 
(g)  Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one or more of the partnership holding a license to withdraw from the partnership in favor of one or more of the partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of the license. This section shall not prohibit transfer of stock between persons who held stock in the corporate ownership at the time of issuance of the license. 
(h)  A licensee may take in partners or additional stockholders; provided, however, that any additional partners or any new stockholders holding more that ten percent of any class of corporate stock must be approved by the City Council as provided hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-34. - License required. 
(a)  No malt beverage, wines, distilled spirits or any other alcoholic beverage shall be sold or manufactured in the City except under a license issued under this chapter by the City Manager or his/her designee. 
(b)  The requirements of this chapter shall be in addition to any other requirements for occupation taxes under this Code and if other provisions of the Code conflict with this chapter, then this chapter shall control. 
(c)  Licenses which may be issued under this chapter include: 
(1)  Manufacturing alcoholic beverages; 
(2)  Wholesale malt beverages and wines; 
(3)  Wholesale distilled spirits; 
(4)  Retail malt beverages and wines; 
(5)  Retail distilled spirits; 
(6)  Consumption on the premises malt beverages and wines; 
(7)  Consumption on the premises distilled spirits; 
(8)  Sales off-premises for catered functions; 
(9)  Any combination of subsection (c)(2) and (3) of this section; 
(10)  Any combination under subsection (c)(4) and (5) of this section; and 
(11)  Any combination under subsection (c)(6) and (7) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-35. - Annual renewal. 
(a)  Licensees shall make a written application for renewal of licenses issued under this chapter on forms supplied by the City Manager or his/her designee by November 15 of each year, which application may require substantially the same information as the initial application, including a complete investigation of the criminal history of the licensee. 
(b)  If the City Manager or his/her designee determines that it would be appropriate under the standards set forth within this chapter to renew the license under consideration, then he/she shall be authorized to approve the application for renewal. Any license which has not been renewed and paid for in full by close of business on the last business day prior to the end of the calendar year shall expire at 11:59 p.m. on December 31 and shall not serve to authorize the license holder to perform under such license after that date and time until such time as the new license has been issued to the license holder. 
(c)  Any license which is not renewed during the calendar year during which it was issued but is renewed by January 31 of the subsequent year shall be charged an administrative surcharge of ten percent of the license fee in addition to the license fee itself. 
(d)  Any license which is not renewed during the calendar year during which it was issued and is not renewed by January 31 of the subsequent year shall not be renewed. Any person desiring to have a license issued for such an establishment shall be required to initiate a new application process. 
(e)  The City shall have a minimum of 30 calendar days to review a completed license renewal application. In the event that the City does not issue a decision on the completed renewal application within this time period, then the application fee shall be refunded to the applicant and shall be waived with respect to the present renewal application only. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-36. - Amount of fees to be set by City Council. 
All fees associated with alcohol licensing shall be determined from time to time and set by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-37. - Annual fees. 
All annual license fees herein shall be paid prior to the issuance of the license. Any new license granted hereunder during a calendar year shall pay the full license fee without proration; provided, however, that if a license is granted after July 1, the license fee shall be one-half of the annual license for the remainder of such calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-38. - Miscellaneous. 
In case of death of any person holding a license, or any interest therein, the license may, with the approval by motion of the City Council, and subject to the terms of this chapter, be transferred to the administrator, executor or personal representative of the deceased person, or to the heirs at law of the deceased person, if such heirs meet all of the other qualifications contained herein. The license of the deceased person shall be held by the administrator, executor or personal representative of the deceased person only for the time necessary to complete administration of his estate and to dispose of the license or the interest therein, but in no event shall exceed 12 months. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Secs. 9-1-39—9-1-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - CONSIDERATION OF LICENSE APPLICATIONS 

Sec. 9-1-50. - Considerations for granting a license permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall have the discretion to grant or refuse to grant any application for a license hereunder; however, the City Manager or his/her designee shall consider the following matters in connection with each application for a license hereunder, which considerations are deemed to be in the public interest and welfare, as follows: 
(1)  Whether the applicant, or any person having a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the issuance of the license, has had any license issued by the City or by any other city in the State, or by any other licensing authority in the State relating to the manufacture, distribution or sale of alcoholic beverages suspended within the past five years or revoked within the past ten years; 
(2)  Whether any applicant for a license to sell distilled spirits or package beer and wine, or any person having a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the issuance of the license, has had any license issued by the City or by any other city in the State, or by any other licensing authority in the State relating to the manufacture, distribution or sale of alcoholic beverages suspended within the past five years or revoked within the past ten years; 
(3)  Whether the applicant or any person owning a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the license for which application is made has sufficient mental capacity to conduct the business for which the application is made; 
(4)  Whether the applicant or any person owning a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the license for which application is made has been dishonorably discharged from the armed services of the United States; 
(5)  Whether the applicant or any person owning a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the license for which application is made fails to demonstrate financial stability; 
(6)  Whether the applicant is 21 years of age or older; 
(7)  Whether the applicant is a citizen of the United States or a resident alien lawfully permitted for permanent residence; 
(8)  Whether the location of the premises from which the proposed sale of alcoholic beverages shall be conducted meets the distance restrictions set forth by State law and local ordinance; 
(9)  Whether the applicant, owner, and manager have obtained a valid alcoholic beverage handling permit as required by this chapter; 
(10)  The applicant's reputation, character, criminal history, and mental and physical capacity to conduct the business proposed to be conducted; 
(11)  Whether the applicant has been convicted of, pled guilty to, or entered a plea of nolo contendre to, or is presently charged with any felony, any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, any criminal offense related to lottery rules or regulations, any offense related to illegal gambling, soliciting for prostitution, pandering, letting of premises for prostitution, keeping a disorderly place, any offense related to the illegal possession or sale of illegal drugs or alcoholic beverages, any sex offense found in O.C.G.A. Title 16, Chapter 6 or any similar violation found in any other State or federal statute, any charges related to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages, or a second offense of driving under the influence of alcohol within the last ten years; 
(12)  Whether the applicant, or any person who shall have a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the license, as a previous holder of a license to sell any type of alcoholic beverages has been found to have violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business within a ten-year period, immediately preceding the date of the application for license hereunder; 
(13)  If applicant is a previous holder of a license to sell any type of alcoholic beverages, the manner in which he or she conducted the business under such license and the necessity for any unusual police observation and inspection of such prior business in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business; 
(14)  If applicant has had a prior license, whether any such prior license for the sale of any type of alcoholic beverages has been suspended or revoked or whether or not hearings have been held for the revocation or suspension of any such license regardless of whether or not any such license was revoked or suspended as a result of such hearing; 
(15)  The location of the premises from which the proposed sale of alcoholic beverages shall be conducted; 
(16)  Whether the applicant, or any person who shall have a direct or indirect beneficial interest in the license, has had any City license revoked within two years prior to the filing of the application; 
(17)  Whether the facility where the applicant proposes to sell alcoholic beverages meets City zoning requirements; 
(18)  Whether it appears that the applicant would have adequate financial participation in the proposed business to direct and manage its affairs, or whether it appears that the applicant is intended to be a mere surrogate for a person or persons who would not otherwise qualify for a license for any reason whatsoever; and 
(19)  Whether the applicant has failed to meet any other criteria specified by this chapter or State law. 
(b)  The City Manager or his/her designee has discretionary authority to consider any other objective criteria that is rationally related to the application including any extenuating circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, application, or the proposed location of the business when making a decision to approve or deny a license requested hereunder. If, in the judgment of the City Manager or his/her designee, circumstances are such that granting the license would not be in the best interest of the general health, safety, and public welfare, such circumstances shall be grounds for denying the application. 
(c)  The City Manager or his/her designee may issue any City license provided for in this chapter only after a motion to that effect is adopted by the City Council. The City Manager or his/her designee may issue a license for the off-premises sale of alcoholic beverages for catered functions without the necessity of City Council approval. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-51. - Continuing duty to report criminal convictions. 
All license holders shall have a continuing duty to notify the City in writing in the event that the license holder or any shareholder or partner that holds a ten percent or greater interest in the entity to whom the license is issued is charged with, is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendre to any criminal offense under the laws of this State or any other state or other jurisdiction after a license has been granted. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-52. - Payment of taxes and other debts to the City. 
The City Manager or his/her designee shall cause an inquiry to be made into the tax records of the City to determine if any applicant or any shareholder or partner that holds a ten percent or greater interest in the entity to whom the license is issued have any outstanding taxes or special assessments that are delinquent or any other monies owing to the City. No license shall be issued, nor shall a license be renewed, until all such debts are paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-53. - Change in relationships and/or ownership interest. 
Any change in any of the ownership interest contained on the original application for a license or for an application for the renewal of an existing license must be filed in writing with the City Manager or his/her designee within 30 calendar days after such change is made. The failure to do so shall be grounds for the imposition of administrative penalties or for the immediate denial of any pending application for such a license or for the renewal of such a license. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-54. - Completion of proposed licensed premises. 
Where a building in which an applicant proposes to operate under a license permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages is at the time of the application for such license not in existence, or not yet completed, a license may be issued for such location providing the plans and specifications for the proposed building are filed with the City Manager or his/her designee and show clear compliance with the other provisions of this chapter and other applicable ordinances of the City. No sales shall be allowed in such location until the location has been completed in accordance with said plans and specifications and is in conformity with all other provisions of this chapter, all building codes, and other applicable ordinances of the City and until a certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-55. - Application for new license in existing license location. 
An application for a new license in an existing license location shall be required to comply with all requirements of this chapter for the granting of a new license except that an application for an annual renewal license shall not be subject to the notice requirements of Section 9-1-27. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-56. - Managers and employees; responsibilities. 
No licensee shall allow any manager or employee who is required under this chapter to secure an alcoholic beverage handling permit to work beyond ten calendar days after their first work day unless the licensee has on file, on the premises, the current, valid alcoholic beverage handling permit of each such manager or employee. An individual working on the premises beyond ten calendar days after their first work day in an establishment holding a license to sell alcoholic beverages without the required permit shall be considered in violation of this chapter, and the employee and licensee shall be subject to administrative penalties. An individual that works on the licensed premises beyond ten calendar days after their first work day without securing an alcoholic beverage handling permit shall be subject to prosecution in Conyers Municipal Court and shall be subject to the penalty provisions contained in Section 7-103 of the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Secs. 9-1-57—9-1-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE D. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE HANDLING PERMIT 

Sec. 9-1-60. - Alcoholic beverage handling permit application process. 
(a)  All persons involved in the selling of alcoholic beverages at package stores and all persons involved in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages at businesses which hold a license to sell alcoholic beverages for on premises consumption shall not work more than ten calendar days after the date of their first work day without first securing an alcoholic beverage handling permit. 
(b)  In order to apply for an alcoholic beverage handling permit, the applicant must submit an application which shall include, but shall not be limited to, the applicant's full legal name, date of birth, and social security number. In the event that the applicant has already secured employment where an alcoholic beverage handling permit is required, the applicant shall also list the name and address of the licensee on the application. The applicant shall also certify that he or she has read and understands the legal restrictions related to the handling and sales of alcoholic beverages and the consequences that may be imposed if the applicant does not comply with such restrictions. 
(c)  A complete set of fingerprints of each applicant for a new alcoholic beverage handling permit may be required at the discretion of the City. 
(1)  Authority. This subsection is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(l.2), the Georgia Umbrella Statute entitled "Dissemination of information to public agencies, political subdivisions, authorities, and instrumentalities." 
(2)  Fingerprinting required. An individual seeking to receive an alcoholic beverage handling permit may be required to be fingerprinted as a condition of submitting an application for a new alcoholic beverage handling permit. By filing such application, the applicant consents to the City obtaining their criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). While fingerprinting shall typically only be required, if at all, at the time of the initial application, the submission by the applicant of a renewal application shall authorize the City to request a new set of fingerprints if needed and shall authorize the City to once again obtain the applicant's criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). 
(3)  Access authorized; usage regulations. 
a.  The City is hereby authorized to access national criminal history record information pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(l.2). 
b.  Information obtained and handled for any purposes pursuant to this subsection shall comply with all Georgia laws and the Federal Privacy Act. 
c.  No information given as part of the request for a criminal history and no record obtained pursuant to this section may be entered on any database. 
d.  No information given or obtained pursuant to this section shall be subject to the provisions of the Georgia Open Records Act. 
(4)  Administration; fees; procedures. 
a.  Applicant shall provide his/her fingerprints if requested, which may be taken by the City of Conyers Police Department or may be taken at any Georgia Applicant Processing Services location so long as the applicant registers in such a manner that allows the Conyers Police Department to receive the criminal history results. 
b.  The applicant shall bear the cost of the electronic fingerprinting submission services set by the Georgia Applicant Processing Services and an administrative fee allowed by statute to be charged by the City, which shall be the maximum allowed by statute, which is currently $20.00, which fee shall include fingerprinting when carried out by the Conyers Police Department. 
c.  Upon receipt of the fingerprints and the appropriate fees, the City will transmit said fingerprints and appropriate fees (unless a satisfactory billing arrangement has been entered into between the City Police Department and the GCIC and/or FBI) to the GCIC. As provided by law, the GCIC will compare the subject's fingerprints against its criminal file and submit the fingerprints to the FBI for a comparison with nation-wide records, unless submission to the FBI is automatic pursuant to the use of live-scan. The results of the FBI check will be returned based on its current procedure, presently being directly to the City Police Department if submissions are made manually to the GCIC, or electronically from both the GBI and FBI where submissions are made electronically to the GCIC. 
d.  In compliance with Federal law 95-544, which provides for the rendering of a "fitness determination," the City will decide whether the applicant has been convicted of, or is under pending indictment for enumerated disqualifiers, as set forth within this chapter. 
e.  A person who has consented to the City for a criminal history based on fingerprinting record may request and receive a copy of the criminal history record report from the City at no additional charge. Should the person seek to amend or correct the record, he or she shall be responsible for contacting the GCIC as to Georgia records and/or the FBI concerning records from other jurisdictions maintained in its file. 
(5)  All applications shall be sworn to by the applicant before a Notary Public or other officer authorized to administer oaths. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-61. - Considerations for granting applications for alcoholic beverage handling permits. 
(a)  The Chief of Police or his/her designee shall have the discretion to grant or refuse to grant any application for an alcoholic beverage handling permit hereunder; however, the Chief of Police or his/her designee shall consider the following matters in connection with each application for an alcoholic beverage handling permit, which considerations are deemed to be in the public interest and welfare, as follows: 
(1)  Whether the applicant has had any alcoholic beverage handling permit issued by the City or by any other licensing authority in the State relating to the sale or service of alcoholic beverages suspended within the past five years or revoked within the past ten years; 
(2)  Whether the applicant has been dishonorably discharged from the armed services of the United States; 
(3)  Whether the applicant is 18 years of age or older; 
(4)  Whether the applicant is a citizen of the United States or a resident alien lawfully permitted for permanent residence; 
(5)  Whether the applicant's reputation, character, and mental and physical capacity indicate an ability to competently fulfill the functions and duties performed by those holding alcoholic beverage handling permits; 
(6)  Whether the applicant has been convicted of, pled guilty to, or entered a plea of nolo contendre to, or is presently charged with any felony, any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, any criminal offense related to lottery rules or regulations, any offense related to illegal gambling, soliciting for prostitution, pandering, letting of premises for prostitution, keeping a disorderly place, any offense related to the illegal possession or sale of illegal drugs or alcoholic beverages, any sex offense found in O.C.G.A. Title 16, Chapter 6 or any similar violation found in any other State or federal statute, any charges related to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages, or a second offense of driving under the influence of alcohol within the last five years; 
(7)  Whether the applicant has been found to have violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to the sales or service of alcoholic beverages within a five-year period immediately preceding the date of the application for an alcoholic beverage handling permit; and, 
(8)  Whether the applicant has failed to meet any other criteria specified by this chapter or State law. 
(b)  The Chief of Police or his/her designee has the discretionary authority to consider any other objective criteria that is rationally related to the application, including any extenuating circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, when making a decision to approve or deny an alcoholic beverage handling permit. If, in the judgment of the Chief of Police or his/her designee, circumstances are such that granting the alcoholic beverage handling permit would not be in the best interest of the general health, safety, and public welfare, such circumstances shall be grounds for denying the application. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-62. - Denial of applications for alcoholic beverage handling permits. 
(a)  If an application for an alcoholic beverage handling permit is denied, the Chief of Police or his/her designee shall notify the applicant that the applicant's application was denied. The applicant will be provided an explanation in writing as to the basis for the denial of the application. 
(b)  All alcoholic beverage handling permits issued hereunder shall remain the property of the City and shall be produced for inspection upon the demand of the Chief of Police or his/her designee or the City Manager or his/her designee. Such permits shall be present on the premises at all times while the permittee is working. Any permit that is issued through administrative error may be rescinded by the Chief of Police or his/her designee.
