(c)  No person shall be issued an alcoholic beverage handling permit if it is determined that the person knowingly and willfully falsified, concealed, or covered up any material fact by any device, trick, or scheme while making application to the City Manager or his/her designee or to the Chief of Police or his/her designee for an alcoholic beverage handling permit under this chapter. Any such act on the part of an applicant shall also be a violation of this chapter and shall be punishable as set forth elsewhere within this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-63. - Continuing duty to report criminal convictions. 
All alcoholic beverage handling permit holders shall have a continuing duty to notify the City in writing in the event that the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder is charged with, is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendre to any criminal offense under the laws of this State or any other state or other jurisdiction after an alcoholic beverage handling permit has been granted. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-64. - Alcoholic beverage handling permit; renewal. 
Any alcoholic beverage handling permit issued hereunder shall expire one year from the date of issuance, unless earlier rescinded by the Chief of Police or his/her designee. All persons holding alcoholic beverage handling permits and seeking to renew such permits shall submit an application to renew their permits in advance of the expiration date on forms prescribed by the City Manager or his/her designee. The City shall have 30 calendar days to review such completed renewal application. Handling alcohol without a valid permit is expressly prohibited. In the event that the City does not issue a decision on the completed renewal application within this time period, then the application fee shall be refunded to the applicant and shall be waived with respect to the present renewal application only. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-65. - Required workshop. 
(a)  Within 90 calendar days of obtaining an alcoholic beverage handling permit, all employees involved in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages at package stores or for consumption on the premises will be required to provide proof of satisfactory completion of a RASS workshop conducted by the City. Such certificate shall be maintained at the licensed premises and available for inspection during normal business hours. A copy of such certificate for every employee who was involved in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages during the prior year shall be attached to the licensee's yearly renewal application. A licensee's failure to require such employees to obtain such certification shall be grounds for the imposition of administrative penalties. In addition, the employees shall attach a copy of his or her certificate to any renewal application for his or her alcoholic beverage handling permit. The failure of a permitted alcoholic beverage handler to obtain such certification shall also be grounds for the imposition of administrative penalties on the licensee. 
(b)  All employees involved in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages at package stores or for consumption on the premises will be required to provide proof of satisfactory completion of a RASS workshop conducted by the City once every three years. In the event that said employee has not satisfactorily completed a RASS workshop conducted by the City within the last three years, then that employee shall be deemed to be in violation of this section and shall be subject to administrative penalties. Further, the alcoholic beverage handling permit of such employee shall not be renewed until such time as the employee satisfactorily completes a RASS workshop conducted by the City. The failure of a permitted alcoholic beverage handler to comply with this requirement shall also be grounds for the imposition of administrative penalties on the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Secs. 9-1-66—9-1-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE E. - CONSUMPTION ON PREMISES; LICENSING REQUIREMENTS, REGULATION AND TYPES OF LICENSES 

Sec. 9-1-70. - License permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises for consumption on the premises. 
(a)  Only the following types of establishments or activities shall be licensed under this article for the sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises for consumption on the premises: 
(1)  Restaurants; 
(2)  Brewpubs; 
(3)  Drinking places; 
(4)  Hotel/lounge; 
(5)  Nightclub; 
(6)  Indoor commercial recreational establishments; 
(7)  Golf course; and 
(8)  Performing arts facility. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-71. - Issuance of licenses limited to designated business; occupational tax certificate. 
(a)  No license permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall be issued to any person unless the business or the proposed business to be licensed hereunder is a restaurant, brewpub, drinking place, hotel/lounge, nightclub, indoor commercial recreational establishment, golf course, or performing arts facility as each of these terms is defined in this chapter. 
(b)  Licenses shall only be issued for a business that is a permitted use in that particular zoning district and no license for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises may be issued to any business licensed for operating as any type of adult entertainment establishment. 
(c)  No license permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall be issued to any person unless the business or the proposed business to be licensed hereunder has made application for and received an occupation tax certificate as a restaurant, performing arts facility, hotel, lounge, drinking place, nightclub, indoor commercial recreational establishment, golf course or brewpub. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-72. - Off-premises sale of alcoholic beverages for catered functions. 
(a)  In addition to the occupation tax requirements of this Code and Article A of this chapter, the following requirements shall apply to the licensing and operations for sales of alcoholic beverages off-premises for catered functions. Should this section conflict with any other provisions of this chapter or the occupation tax requirements of this Code, then this section shall control. 
(b)  Any applicant who holds a license issued by the City under the terms and conditions set forth in Chapter 1 of Title 9 to sell malt beverages or wine by the drink for consumption on the premises may be issued an off-premises license that authorizes such applicant to sell malt beverages or wine by the drink off-premises and in connection with an authorized catered function. For purposes of this section, the term "authorized catered function" may include a function held inside a publicly or privately owned building or structure or a function held outside such a building or structure that is located within the City limits of the City. 
(c)  Any applicant who holds a license issued by the City under the terms and conditions set forth in Chapter 1 of Title 9 which authorizes the applicant to sell distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises may be issued an off-premises license which authorizes such applicant to sell distilled spirits by the drink off-premises and in connection with an authorized catered function. For purposes of this section the term "authorized catered function" may include a function held inside a publicly or privately owned building or structure or a function held outside such a building or structure that is located within the City limits of the City. 
(d)  In order to distribute or sell distilled spirits, malt beverages or wine at an authorized catered function, an applicant shall be required to: 
(1)  Apply to the City for an alcoholic beverage special event permit. The application shall include the name of the applicant; the date, address and time of the event; and the applicant's alcoholic beverage license number. 
(2)  If applicable, provide satisfactory reports as required to the State on forms provided by the State, stating the quantity of any and all alcoholic beverages transported from the applicant's primary premises to the location of the authorized catered function and such other information as may be required by the State. 
(3)  If applicable, maintain original event permits and documents in the vehicle transporting the alcoholic beverage to the catered function at all times. 
(4)  Pay an alcoholic beverage special event permit fee according to the schedule approved from time to time by the City Council. 
(e)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall review the applicant's application and supporting documentation. Based upon the requirements set forth in this section, the City Manager or his/her designee shall either approve or deny, in writing, said alcoholic beverage special event application. 
(f)  All alcoholic beverage special event license applications must be submitted at least 20 calendar days prior to the planned special event. 
(g)  No limitations will be applied as to the number of alcoholic beverage special event license applications made by a retail consumption dealer in any one calendar year. 
(h)  The restrictions set forth in the Section 9-1-13, Hours of operation, shall apply to all sales of alcoholic beverages at authorized catered functions. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-73. - Restaurants. 
(a)  An establishment may be licensed to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises as a restaurant where the establishment meets all other applicable requirements under this chapter. 
(b)  A restaurant licensee shall have the right to serve alcoholic beverages to persons seated at that restaurant's sidewalk café. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-74. - Sidewalk café. 
(a)  A licensee operating a sidewalk café shall not have the right to serve alcoholic beverages to any person who is not seated at a table and in a chair provided by the licensee. 
(b)  Alcoholic beverages shall only be transported into the sidewalk café and/or opened in the sidewalk café by licensee's employees as part of their work duties. 
(c)  All sidewalk cafés shall be confined to the portion of the sidewalk that is directly in front of the abutting restaurant; and the width of the sidewalk café shall not extend beyond the width of the abutting restaurant. A sidewalk café may either remain open to the elements, or be covered with an awning, pitched roof or other similar architectural element, provided that all such awnings and architectural elements do not encroach within 24 inches of the street curb. 
(d)  A sidewalk café shall contain no more than 25 percent of the total seating capacity for the abutting restaurant. The sidewalk café shall be maintained, at all times, by the restaurant licensee, in a clean, neat and safe condition, and all chairs, tables and other furnishings shall be of uniform design, and shall be made of quality materials and workmanship to ensure the safety and convenience of restaurant guests, and to enhance the visual quality of both the restaurant's and the surrounding area's aesthetics. 
(e)  All sidewalk cafés shall comply with the provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act, specifically including, but not limited to, a minimum distance of 48 inches between the street curb and any chairs and tables. 
(f)  All sidewalk cafés shall operate in compliance with the City's noise ordinance. 
(g)  All sidewalk cafés shall be subject to the same hours of operation and use limitations of the abutting restaurant. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-75. - Brewpub licenses. 
(a)  No person shall be permitted to own or operate a brewpub without first obtaining a consumption on premises license from the City Manager or his/her designee, and each brewpub license holder shall comply with all other applicable State and local license requirements. 
(b)  Possession of a brewpub license shall not prevent the holder of such license from obtaining another license authorized under Section 9-1-70 (license permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises) for the same premises. 
(c)  A brewpub license does not authorize the holder of such license to sell alcoholic beverages at retail by package for consumption off the premises. 
(d)  A brewpub licensee shall pay all State and local license fees and excise taxes applicable to individuals licensed as manufacturers, retailers, and, where applicable, wholesalers. 
(e)  A brewpub licensee shall measure all beer manufactured on the premises and otherwise comply with applicable regulations respecting excise and enforcement tax determination of such beer as required. There is hereby levied an excise tax on all beer and malt beverage produced by a brewpub in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80, as amended. Such tax shall be paid to City Hall no later than the tenth day of each month for the preceding month's production. A late payment penalty not to exceed ten percent of the tax otherwise due shall be added to the amount due for any payment not received by the due date. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-76. - Performing arts facility. 
(a)  Alcoholic beverages may be sold and/or dispensed at a performing arts facility only where the facility meets the definition for a performing arts facility set forth herein. 
(b)  A business meeting the definition of a performing arts facility under this chapter shall be eligible to apply for and be considered for an annual license to allow alcoholic beverages to be sold for consumption on the premises from the City Manager or his/her designee. 
(c)  A business granted a performing arts facility license for consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises shall be required to obtain all required licenses from the State and to follow all State and local laws, ordinances and rules governing the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises. 
(d)  Alcoholic beverages may be sold at a performing arts facility only at a bar located in the lobby area of the facility or by a waiter or waitress serving patrons within the facility. 
(e)  In addition to the hours of sale requirements set out in this chapter, alcoholic beverages may not be dispensed at a performing arts facility earlier than one hour before the start of a performance or later than one hour after the performance has ended, provided that no alcoholic beverages shall be sold past the hours listed in this chapter for retail consumption on premise licensees. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-77. - Indoor commercial recreation establishments. 
Indoor commercial recreation establishments that are licensed to serve alcoholic beverages shall only sell alcoholic beverages at a bar or by a waiter or waitress in the dining or bar areas at tables located therein. Alcoholic beverages shall not be sold in the areas of the establishment not intended predominately for food or beverage consumption. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-78. - Outdoor golf course sales. 
Only the sale of malt beverages and wine shall be permitted as outdoor golf course sales notwithstanding that the facility may hold a license allowing for the sale of distilled spirits for consumption on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-79. - Pitchers. 
(a)  No consumption on the premises licensee shall sell, offer to sell or deliver alcoholic beverages, including malt beverages, in any container that holds more than 32 fluid ounces at any one time to one person. 
(b)  A consumption on the premises licensee may sell, offer to sell or deliver alcoholic beverages, including malt beverages, in a pitcher containing not more than 64 fluid ounces to a group of persons consisting of at least two or more persons. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-80. - Courtyard, patio, and deck sales. 
(a)  For the purposes of this chapter, an establishment may include a courtyard, patio, and/or deck area as a part of their premises within which they are allowed to serve and sell alcoholic beverages if: 
(1)  The courtyard, patio, or deck is separated from the general public by a permanent wall, fence, hedge, or similar device or structure that is approved by the City Manager or his/her designee; 
(2)  The patrons of the establishment may only access the courtyard, patio, or deck area through the primary structure of the establishment; 
(3)  The location of the courtyard, patio, or deck does not encroach upon any public sidewalk, any public right-of-way, or any other area customarily used for ingress to the primary structure of the establishment, egress from the primary structure of the establishment, pedestrian traffic, or vehicular traffic; 
(4)  The location and placement of the courtyard, patio, or deck shall first have been approved by the City Manager or his/her designee; and 
(5)  The plans for the courtyard, patio, or deck shall first have been approved by the City Manager or his/her designee as being in conformity with applicable City building codes and all other applicable codes. 
(b)  The use of the courtyard, patio, or deck shall be subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The use of the courtyard, patio, or deck shall be subject to the City's noise and nuisance ordinances and shall be subject to applicable State noise and nuisance statutes; 
(2)  No additional license shall be required for the sale or service of alcoholic beverages in a courtyard, patio, or deck area; however, the licensee must apply for an amendment to his/her consumption on the premises license to reflect the additional service area added by the inclusion of the courtyard, patio, or deck area, and such application shall be accompanied by two copies of the plans for the proposed courtyard, patio, or deck area which shall be subject to the approval of the City Manager or his/her designee; 
(3)  The courtyard, patio, or deck area shall be adequately illuminated for the safety of the patrons as determined by the City Manager or his/her designee; 
(4)  The licensee shall comply with all setback lines and buffer requirements of the City zoning ordinance which is in effect at the time said alcoholic beverage license application is submitted; and 
(5)  The use of a courtyard, patio, or deck as a part of the premises may be suspended or revoked by the City Manager or his/her designee if its use interferes with other permissible uses in the area surrounding the premises or if its use becomes a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-81. - "Happy hour" promotions and sales. 
(a)  No licensee or employee or agent of a licensee, in connection with the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall: 
(1)  Offer any free alcoholic beverage to any person or group of persons; 
(2)  Deliver more than one alcoholic beverage to one person at one time; with the exception of any one and one-half ounce serving of a distilled spirit at such time the customer is in possession of a malt beverage. 
(3)  Encourage or permit on the licensed premises any game or contest which involves the drinking of alcoholic beverages or the awarding of alcoholic beverages as a prize. 
(4)  Require or allow the purchase of a second or subsequent alcoholic beverage at the same time another alcoholic beverage is purchased or before the previous alcoholic beverage has been consumed or otherwise discarded; with the exception of any one and one-half ounce serving of a distilled spirit at such time the customer is in possession of a malt beverage. 
(b)  No licensee shall advertise or promote in any way, whether within or without the licensed premises, any of the practices prohibited under subsection (a). 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the delivery of a bottle of wine to the patrons of a restaurant for consumption during the course a meal. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Secs. 9-1-82—9-1-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE F. - PACKAGE MALT BEVERAGE AND WINE; LICENSE REQUIREMENTS AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 9-1-90. - Wine tasting. 
Persons who are licensed by the State and by the City to sell wine for off-premises consumption and that derive at least 51 percent of their daily revenue from the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed to conduct wine tastings on premises pursuant to all applicable Department of Revenue regulations as such regulations may be amended from time to time with the following additional restrictions: 
(1)  Wine tastings may only be conducted during the hours which wine may be sold for off-premises consumption; 
(2)  No person may participate in a wine tasting unless that person is 21 years of age or older; 
(3)  Any person participating in a wine tasting must pay a fee to participate that is equal to or greater than the pro rata wholesale cost of the portion size of each serving of wine that is provided to be tasted; 
(4)  The portion size of the serving of the wines to be tasted shall not exceed four fluid ounces per serving; and 
(5)  The licensee may not serve any person more than 16 ounce samples of wine in any one calendar day. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014; Ord. No. 1013, § 1, 8-17-2016) 
Sec. 9-1-91. - Malt beverages tasting. 
Persons who are licensed by the State and by the City to sell malt beverages for off-premises consumption and that derive at least 51 percent of their daily revenue from the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed to conduct malt beverage tastings pursuant to all applicable Department of Revenue regulations as such regulations may be amended from time to time with the following additional restrictions: 
(1)  Malt beverage tastings may only be conducted during the hours which malt beverages may be sold for off-premises consumption; 
(2)  No person may participate in a malt beverage tasting unless that person is 21 years of age or older; 
(3)  Any person participating in a malt beverage tasting must pay a fee to participate that is equal to or greater than the pro rata wholesale cost of the portion size of each serving of malt beverage that is provided to be tasted; 
(4)  The portion size of the serving of the malt beverages to be tasted shall not exceed four fluid ounces per serving; and 
(5)  The licensee may not serve any person more than 16 ounce samples of malt beverages in any one calendar day. 
(Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014; Ord. No. 1013, § 2, 8-17-2016) 
Sec. 9-1-92. - Sale of malt beverages in growlers. 
(a)  The sale of malt beverages in growlers shall only be allowed in establishments that are licensed for the sale of malt beverages for off-premises consumption and that derive at least 51 percent of their daily revenue from the sale of malt beverages. 
(b)  The filling of growlers by means of a tapped keg shall not constitute the breaking of a package as contemplated by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-26 or other provisions of this chapter, provided that after the growler is filled the growler must be sealed on the licensed premises with a tamper-proof plastic cap and may not thereafter be opened or consumed on the premises. Licensees or employees of the licensed establishment may fill or refill growlers with draft malt beverages at a licensed location for retail package sales as provided herein in a growler not smaller than 12 ounces in volume and not to exceed 64 ounces in volume. 
(c)  No person shall consume malt beverages from a growler on any licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Secs. 9-1-93—9-1-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE G. - PACKAGE DISTILLED SPIRITS; LICENSE REQUIREMENTS AND REGULATION 

Sec. 9-1-100. - Applicability of chapter to those businesses operating both the retail sale of distilled spirits and package malt beverages and wine. 
For licensees who wish to operate a business that conducts both the retail sale of distilled spirits and package malt beverages and wine, in the case of conflict, the provisions of this chapter regulating the sale of distilled spirits shall prevail, and compliance with those provisions, rather than the provisions applicable to the license permitting the sale of package malt beverages and wine, is required. The applicant shall be required to complete the application(s) required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-101. - Separation of alcoholic beverages from nonalcoholic merchandise. 
All holders of licenses under this article shall separate alcoholic beverages from their nonalcoholic merchandise so that the alcoholic beverages may be closed off from the rest of the premises at all times when sale thereof is prohibited, and the same shall be so closed off during the prohibited times for sale. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-102. - Consumption prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage on premises licensed for the sale of package alcoholic beverages. For the purpose of this section only, "premises" shall include the parking area immediately adjoining the premises licensed for the sale of package alcoholic beverages and available for the use of the customers of the licensed premises, whether or not the same are owned or leased by the license holder. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on said premises or to sell unsealed (broken) alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-103. - Sale or delivery off premises. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee of a retail establishment permitted to sell distilled spirits hereunder to make deliveries of any alcoholic beverages by the package beyond the boundaries of the premises covered by the license. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Secs. 9-1-104—9-1-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE H. - WHOLESALERS: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 9-1-110. - Requirements of wholesalers generally. 
All wholesale dealers or distributors shall be licensed by the State revenue department and shall comply with all laws and regulations of the State revenue department before they sell or deliver any alcoholic beverages in the City. Deliveries and sales shall be made only to retailers licensed under the provisions of this article and all deliveries shall be made in conveyances owned and operated by such wholesale dealers or distributors. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-111. - Other licenses. 
The licenses and taxes provided for in this article are not levied in lieu of any other license fees or taxes that may be levied upon licensees, but are in addition thereto. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-112. - Issuance of licenses limited to designated area. 
No license permitting the wholesale distribution of alcoholic beverages shall be granted to any applicant proposing to locate within the City unless the premises are located in an area of the City that is properly zoned for such use. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-113. - Regulations governing retail storage. 
All licensed retailers shall store all alcoholic beverages on the premises for which the license was issued and at no other place. No wholesaler shall store for any retail dealer those alcoholic beverages that have been purchased. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-114. - Consumption prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage on premises licensed for the wholesale sale of alcoholic beverages. For the purpose of this section only, "premises" shall include the parking area immediately adjoining the wholesaler's premises and available for the use of the customers of the licensed premises, whether or not the same are owned or leased by the license holder. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on said premises or to sell unsealed (broken) alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Secs. 9-1-115—9-1-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE I. - ALCOHOL IN PUBLIC PLACES, BROWN-BAGGING 

Sec. 9-1-120. - Alcoholic beverages in public places. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation licensed to sell alcoholic beverages shall permit any person to remove from such premises any alcoholic beverage in any open container. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to nor shall it affect the sale of or possession of a partially consumed bottle of wine purchased with a meal from a restaurant and resealed as permitted by O.C.G.A. §§ 3-6-4 and 40-6-253(2). 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-121. - Bring your own bottle "brown-bagging" prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to bring any alcoholic beverage (brown bag) onto any property unless such person is the lawful owner of said property, unless the occupational tax on said property has been paid in full and is current, and unless the alcoholic beverage is for the owner's personal use. This restriction shall not be applicable to residential or government-owned property. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any corporation, partnership, individual or other entity who maintains a business which is subject to any of the occupational tax provisions of the City or is specifically exempted from occupational taxes as provided for in the City occupational tax ordinance to knowingly allow a person to violate the provisions of subsection (a) on their property. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Secs. 9-1-122—9-1-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE J. - AGE REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 9-1-130. - Age requirements on licensed premises. 
(a)  The age requirements for employees shall be as follows: 
(1)  Package alcoholic beverage and wholesale licensees: Except as provided in this subsection, no wholesale dealer or package store licensee shall allow any employee under the age of 18 years to sell, take orders for, or handle alcoholic beverages. The provisions of this subsection shall not prohibit persons under 18 years of age who are employed in grocery stores supermarkets, convenience stores, breweries or drug stores from selling or handling alcoholic beverages that are sold for consumption off the premises; however, the licensee shall ensure that said person under 18 years of age shall be under direct supervision of a person who shall be both employed by said establishment and who shall be over the age of 21 years of age and shall be on-site at all times during which the underage employee is working. 
(2)  Consumption on the premises licensees and caterers: No consumption on the premises licensee or licensed caterer shall allow any employee under the age of 18 years to dispense, sell, serve, take orders for, or handle alcoholic beverages. 
a.  The subsection shall not prohibit the employment of persons under the above ages on licensed premises where such persons do not dispense, sell, serve, take orders for, or handle alcoholic beverages. 
b.  This section shall not apply to those employees who clear tableware between customers, also known as "busboys," nor shall it apply to those employees who are cooks or dishwashers. 
c.  Those employees of a consumption on the premises licensee and licensed caterers who are 18 years of age but younger than 21 years of age shall be under direct supervision of a person who shall be both employed by said establishment and who shall be over the age of 21 years of age and shall be present at all times during which the underage employee is working. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Secs. 9-1-131—9-1-139. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE K. - STORAGE AND LABELING OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 

Sec. 9-1-140. - Storage on unlicensed premises. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or corporation not holding an alcoholic beverage license granted by the City to store any alcoholic beverages on the grounds of any retail establishment, excluding alcoholic beverages for personal consumption, in accordance with all applicable provisions of law. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-141. - Keeping or storing without appropriate license. 
It shall be unlawful for any person operating under a license for the sale of malt beverages or wine or both to store or have therein any distilled spirits without an appropriate license. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-142. - Regulations governing retail storage. 
All alcoholic beverages shall be available at all times for inspection by the Chief of Police of the City or his/her designee. Any alcoholic beverages found in any retailer's stock that is purchased from another retail dealer or any alcoholic beverages that were sold or distributed by a wholesaler who is not licensed in accordance with the laws of the State to make sales and deliveries in the State shall be subject to immediate confiscation and disposal in accordance with applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-143. - Misrepresentation of alcoholic beverages. 
It shall be unlawful for licensees or their agents to add to the contents of a bottle or to refill empty bottles or in any manner misrepresent the quantity, quality, or brand names of any alcoholic beverage. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Secs. 9-1-144—9-1-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE L. - LICENSE SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION; APPEAL HEARINGS; PENALTIES 

Sec. 9-1-150. - Emergency suspension situations. 
The City Manager or his/her designee is hereby authorized to suspend any license issued hereunder for any emergency situation such as civil disorders or natural disasters or in any situation that the City Manager deems such immediate suspension necessary for the protection of the health and welfare of the citizens of the City, and such suspension may be made effective immediately and shall remain in force until the license is reinstated by the City Manager or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-151. - Removal of signs. 
When any license for the sale of alcoholic beverages is revoked, all signs indicating that such beverages may be sold or purchased shall immediately be removed from both inside and outside the place of business. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-152. - Appeal hearings. 
No license or permit shall be denied, suspended, or revoked without the opportunity for a hearing as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-153. - Denial of alcoholic beverage handling permit application. 
The Chief of Police or his/her designee shall provide written notice to an applicant for an alcoholic beverage handling permit of the Chief of Police or his/her designee's decision to deny said alcoholic beverage handling permit application. Such written notification shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for such action. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-154. - Denial of alcoholic beverage license; appeals. 
(a)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall provide written notice to an alcoholic beverage license applicant of the City Manager or his/her designee's decision to deny said alcoholic beverage license application. Such written notification shall set forth in reasonable detail the reasons for such action and shall notify the applicant of the right to appeal under the provisions of this article. 
(b)  An applicant may appeal the denial of an alcoholic beverage license application by providing written notification to the City Manager at City Hall within ten calendar days of the denial of the alcoholic beverage license application. The written notification shall include the legal and factual basis upon which the applicant's appeal is based. 
(c)  In order to defray administrative costs, the appeal must be accompanied by a filing fee of $500.00. If, following the administrative hearing, the City Manager or his/her designee issues an alcoholic beverage license to the applicant, then the $500.00 filing fee shall be applied towards the cost of the alcoholic beverage license. 
(d)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall set an administrative hearing date that shall occur within 30 calendar days of the filing of the appeal request. Notice of said administrative hearing shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage license applicant at the address shown on the alcoholic beverage license applicant's application. 
(e)  At the administrative hearing, the alcoholic beverage license applicant is entitled to be heard and present evidence on his/her behalf. The City Manager or his/her designee shall determine whether the denial of the alcoholic beverage license application is justified using a preponderance of the evidence standard. 
(f)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall consider the following factors in determining whether to uphold the denial of an application: 
(1)  Compliance with the criminal history requirements; 
(2)  Compliance with the requirements of this chapter; 
(3)  The history of and facts relating to previous violations of this chapter; 
(4)  Non-alcohol related violations of this Code; 
(5)  Violations of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division of the Georgia Department of Revenue; 
(6)  Documented efforts at avoiding violations of this chapter, this Code or State law; 
(7)  Community involvement; and 
(8)  Any other objective and relevant facts. 
(g)  The City Manager or his/her designee, after hearing evidence, shall have the authority to uphold, modify or overturn the City Manager or his/her designee's previous decision. The City Manager or his/her designee shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 calendar days of the date of the administrative hearing. All decisions by the City Manager or his/her designee shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage license applicant at the address set forth in the license application. 
(h)  Any applicant may appeal the City Manager or his/her designee's decision to the Mayor and City Council within ten calendar days of the date that the adverse decision is issued by the City Manager. Notice of the appeal shall be delivered in writing to the Clerk of the City. The written notification shall include the legal and factual basis upon which the applicant's appeal is based. 
(i)  In order to defray administrative costs, the appeal must be accompanied by an additional filing fee of $500.00. If, following the administrative hearing, the Mayor and City Council issue an alcoholic beverage license to the applicant, then the $1,000.00 in total filing fees shall be applied towards the cost of the alcoholic beverage license. 
(j)  The Mayor and City Council shall set a hearing date within 30 calendar days of receiving the appeal request. Notice of said hearing shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the alcoholic beverage license applicant's application. At the hearing, the applicant is entitled to be heard and present evidence on his/her behalf. The City Manager or his/her representative may similarly be heard and present evidence in support of the denial. The decision of the City Manager or his/her designee shall not be set aside unless the Mayor and City Council finds it to be: 
(1)  Contrary to law or ordinances; 
(2)  Unsupported by substantial evidence on the record as a whole; or 
(3)  Unreasonable. 
(k)  All decisions of the Mayor and City Council shall be final. The Mayor and City Council shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 calendar days of the date of the hearing. All decisions by the City Council shall be in writing and shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage license applicant at the address set forth in the applicable license application. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-155. - Administrative penalties and appeal hearings for alcoholic beverage handling permit holders. 
(a)  The Chief of Police or his/her designee shall provide written notice to an alcoholic beverage handling permit holder of the Chief of Police or his/her designee's intention to impose one or more of the following administrative penalties: 
(1)  Suspend their permit; 
(2)  Revoke their permit; 
(3)  Impose an administrative monetary penalty not to exceed $1,000.00; or 
(4)  Convey a warning for any violation of this chapter, of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division of the Georgia Department of Revenue. 
Such written notification shall set forth in reasonable detail the facts supporting such violation, shall set forth the proposed administrative penalty(ies), and shall notify the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder of their right to appeal under the provisions of this article. Said written notification shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder at the address set forth in the applicable application, and a copy of said written notification shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(b)  An alcoholic beverage handling permit holder may appeal the proposed administrative penalty(ies) by providing written notification to the Chief of Police within ten calendar days of the date that said written notification was hand delivered to the premises. The written notification shall include the legal and factual basis upon which the applicant's appeal is based. 
(c)  In the event that the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder does not timely appeal said proposed administrative penalty(ies), then said alcoholic beverage handling permit holder shall be deemed to agree with said proposed administrative penalty(ies). Further, in the event that said proposed administrative penalty(ies) include the imposition of an administrative monetary penalty, said administrative monetary penalty shall be due and owing to the City within five calendar days of the date of hand delivery of the written notification. The failure to timely pay any administrative monetary penalties shall subject the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder to further administrative penalties. 
(d)  In the event that the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder does timely appeal said proposed administrative penalty(ies), then the Chief of Police shall set an administrative hearing date that shall occur within 30 calendar days of the filing of the appeal request. Notice of said administrative hearing shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder at the address shown on the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder's application and a copy of said written notice shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(e)  At the administrative hearing, the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder is entitled to be heard and present evidence on his/her behalf. The Chief of Police shall determine whether the proposed administrative penalty(ies) of the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder as set forth in the written notification is justified using a preponderance of the evidence standard. 
(f)  The Chief of Police shall consider the following factors in determining whether the proposed administrative penalty(ies) of the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder as set forth in the written notification is justified: 
(1)  Compliance with the criminal history requirements; 
(2)  The history of and facts relating to previous violations of this chapter; 
(3)  Non-alcohol related violations of this Code; 
(4)  Violations of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division of the Georgia Department of Revenue; 
(5)  Documented efforts at avoiding violations of this chapter, of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division of the Georgia Department of Revenue; 
(6)  Community involvement; and 
(7)  Any other objective and relevant facts. 
(g)  The Chief of Police, after hearing evidence, shall have the authority to uphold, modify or overturn the Chief of Police or his/her designee's proposed administrative penalty(ies). The Chief of Police shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 calendar days of the date of the hearing. All decisions by the Chief of Police shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder at the address set forth in the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder's application and a copy of said written decision shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(h)  Any alcoholic beverage handling permit holder may appeal the Chief of Police's decision to the City Manager within ten calendar days of the date that the adverse decision is hand delivered to the premises. Notice of the appeal shall be delivered in writing to the Clerk of the City. The written notification shall include the legal and factual basis upon which the applicant's appeal is based. 
(i)  The City Manager shall set a hearing date within 30 calendar days of receiving the appeal request. Notice of said hearing shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder's application and a copy of said notice shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. At the hearing, the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder is entitled to be heard and present evidence on his/her behalf. The Chief of Police or his/her representative may similarly be heard and present evidence in support of the imposition of the administrative penalty(ies). The decision of the Chief of Police shall not be set aside unless the City Manager finds it to be: 
(1)  Contrary to law or ordinances; 
(2)  Unsupported by substantial evidence on the record as a whole; or 
(3)  Unreasonable. 
(j)  All decisions of the City Manager shall be final. The City Manager shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 days of the date of delivery of the hearing. All decisions by the City Manager shall be in writing and shall be mailed to the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder at the address set forth in the alcoholic beverage handling permit holder's application and a copy of said written decision shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-156. - Administrative penalties and appeal hearings for license holders. 
(a)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall provide written notice to a license holder of the City Manager or his/her designee's intention to impose one or more of the following administrative penalties: 
(1)  Suspend their license; 
(2)  Revoke their license; 
(3)  Impose an administrative monetary penalty not to exceed $5,000.00; or 
(4)  Convey a warning for any violation of this chapter, of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division of the Georgia Department of Revenue. 
Such written notification shall set forth in reasonable detail the facts supporting such violation, shall set forth the proposed administrative penalty(ies), and shall notify the license holder of their right to appeal under the provisions of this article. Said written notification shall be mailed to the license holder at the address set forth in the applicable application, and a copy of said written notification shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(b)  A license holder may appeal the proposed administrative penalty(ies) by providing written notification to the City Manager at City Hall within ten calendar days of the date that said written notification was hand delivered to the premises. The written notification shall include the legal and factual basis upon which the applicant's appeal is based. 
(c)  In the event that the license holder does not timely appeal said proposed administrative penalty(ies), then said license holder shall be deemed to agree with said proposed administrative penalty(ies). Further, in the event that said proposed administrative penalty(ies) include the imposition of an administrative monetary penalty, said administrative monetary penalty shall be due and owing to the City within five calendar days of the date of hand delivery. The failure to timely pay any administrative monetary penalties shall subject the license holder to further administrative penalties. 
(d)  In the event that the license holder does timely appeal said proposed administrative penalty(ies), then the City Manager or his/her designee shall set an administrative hearing date that shall occur within 30 calendar days of the filing of the appeal request. Notice of said administrative hearing shall be mailed to the license holder at the address shown on the license holder's application and a copy of said written notice shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(e)  At the administrative hearing, the license holder is entitled to be heard and present evidence on his/her behalf. The City Manager or his/her designee shall determine whether the proposed administrative penalty(ies) of the license holder as set forth in the written notification is justified using a preponderance of the evidence standard. 
(f)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall consider the following factors in determining whether the proposed administrative penalty(ies) of the license holder as set forth in the written notification is justified: 
(1)  Compliance with the criminal history requirements; 
(2)  The history of and facts relating to previous violations of this chapter; 
(3)  Non-alcohol related violations of this Code; 
(4)  Violations of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division of the Georgia Department of Revenue; 
(5)  Documented efforts at avoiding violations of this chapter, of Title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, or of Subtitle 560-2 of the Georgia Regulations pertaining to the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division of the Georgia Department of Revenue; 
(6)  Training history of employees; 
(7)  Community involvement; and 
(8)  Any other objective and relevant facts. 
(g)  The City Manager or his/her designee, after hearing evidence, shall have the authority to uphold, modify or overturn the City Manager or his/her designee's proposed administrative penalty(ies). The City Manager or his/her designee shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 calendar days of the date of the hearing. All decisions by the City Manager or his/her designee shall be mailed to the license holder at the address set forth in the license holder's application and a copy of said written decision shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(h)  Any license holder may appeal the City Manager or his/her designee's decision to the Mayor and City Council within ten calendar days of the date that the adverse decision is hand delivered to the premises. Notice of the appeal shall be delivered in writing to the Clerk of the City. The written notification shall include the legal and factual basis upon which the applicant's appeal is based. 
(i)  In order to defray administrative costs, the appeal shall be accompanied by a filing fee of $500.00. If, following the administrative hearing, the City Manager or his/her designee's decision is modified or overturned, then the $500.00 filing fee shall be refunded. The Mayor and City Council shall set a hearing date within 30 calendar days of receiving the appeal request. Notice of said hearing shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the alcoholic beverage license applicant's application and a copy of said notice shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. At the hearing, the license holder is entitled to be heard and present evidence on his/her behalf. The City Manager or his/her representative may similarly be heard and present evidence in support of the imposition of the administrative penalty(ies). The decision of the City Manager or his/her designee shall not be set aside unless the Mayor and City Council finds it to be: 
(1)  Contrary to law or ordinances; 
(2)  Unsupported by substantial evidence on the record as a whole; or 
(3)  Unreasonable. 
(j)  All decisions of the Mayor and City Council shall be final. The Mayor and City Council shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 calendar days of the date of delivery of the hearing. All decisions by the City Council shall be in writing and shall be mailed to the license holder at the address set forth in the license holder's application and a copy of said written decision shall be hand delivered to the premises where said violation(s) are alleged to have occurred. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Sec. 9-1-157. - Ordinance violation penalties. 
(a)  Upon conviction in the Municipal Court of Conyers of any violation of this chapter, the person so convicted shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or imprisonment for a period of not more than six months, or both. Each act in violation and each day upon which any violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  In the event of a suspension of a license is imposed upon any licensed establishment where a violation of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23 has occurred by employees, managers, or owners, the licensed establishment shall be required to post signs, to be provided by the City Manager or his/her designee, on the exterior doors of the establishment which contains the following language: "An employee or owner of this store has violated State law and City of Conyers Ordinances by selling alcoholic beverages to a minor" for the period of the suspension imposed by the City Manager or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 944, § 1, 10-16-2013; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-4-2014) 
Secs. 9-1-158, 9-1-159. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE M. - TEMPORARY SPECIAL EVENT LICENSE 

Sec. 9-1-160. - Responsible party designation. 
A bona fide nonprofit civic organization wishing to apply for and receive a temporary special event license shall designate a responsible party who shall be a member in good standing of said bona fide nonprofit civic organization. The responsible party shall make the application for said temporary special event license, and the temporary special event license shall be issued in the responsible party's name on behalf of the bona fide nonprofit civic organization. The responsible party shall be individually responsible for any and all claims, losses or liability arising out of or connected with the temporary special event, whether in contract or in tort (including negligence), law or equity. 
(Ord. No. 994, § 2, 8-19-2015) 
Sec. 9-1-161. - Temporary special event license application forms. 
(a)  All bona fide nonprofit civic organizations desiring to receive a temporary special event license shall make application on a form prescribed by the City Manager or his/her designee. No application will be processed until the responsible party has completed the required interview with the City Manager or his/her designee. 
(b)  The application shall include, but shall not be limited to: 
(1)  The name and address of the responsible party; 
(2)  The date, address, beginning time and ending time of the temporary special event; 
(3)  A description of the premises at which said temporary special event shall occur (said description shall be an aerial map, a description of the metes and bounds, or other such specific descriptions as will allow the City to determine the boundaries of said premises). 
(4)  A copy of the 50l(c)(3) letter issued by the IRS for the bona fide nonprofit civic organization; 
(5)  A copy of the By-laws and corporate charter from the Secretary of State's office for the bona fide nonprofit civic organization; 
(6)  A copy of the special event non-profit permit issued by the state for said temporary special event; 
(7)  A resolution issued by the bona fide nonprofit civic organization authorizing the temporary special event; and 
(8)  Written documentation evidencing a partnership between the bona fide nonprofit civic organization and an alcoholic beverage license holder who has been granted an off-premises consumption license. 
(c)  The responsible party shall furnish data, information and records as required by the City Manager or his/her designee and to ensure compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Failure to furnish data as requested shall cause the application to be denied. 
(d)  A complete set of fingerprints of the responsible party for a new temporary special event license shall be required. 
(1)  Authority. This subsection is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2), the Georgia Umbrella Statute entitled "Dissemination of information to public agencies, political subdivisions, authorities, and instrumentalities." 
(2)  Fingerprinting required. An individual seeking to receive a temporary special event license shall be fingerprinted as a condition of submitting an application for a temporary special event license. The responsible party shall be required to provide fingerprints each time an application is submitted, unless that same responsible party has already provided fingerprints to the city within the same calendar year. By filing such application, the applicant consents to the City obtaining their criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (F.B.I.). 
(3)  Access authorized; usage regulations. 
a.  The City is hereby authorized to access national criminal history record information pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2). 
b  Information obtained and handled for any purposes pursuant to this subsection shall comply with all Georgia laws and the Federal Privacy Act. 
c.  No information given as part of the request for a criminal history and no record obtained pursuant to this section may be entered on any database. 
d.  No information given or obtained pursuant to this section shall be subject to the provisions of the Georgia Open Records Act. 
(d)  Administration; fees; procedures. 
(1)  The applicant shall provide his/her fingerprints, which may be taken by the City of Conyers Police Department or may be taken at any Georgia Applicant Processing Services location, so long as the applicant registers in such a manner that allows the Conyers Police Department to receive the criminal history results. 
(2)  The applicant shall bear the cost of the electronic fingerprinting submission services set by the Georgia Applicant Processing Services and an administrative fee allowed by statute to be charged by the City, which shall be the maximum all owed by statute, which fee shall include fingerprinting when carried out by the Conyers Police Department. 
(3)  Upon receipt of the fingerprints and the appropriate fees, the City will transmit said fingerprints and appropriate fees (unless a satisfactory billing arrangement has been entered into between the City Police Department and the GCIC and/or FBI) to the GCIC. As provided by law, the GCIC will compare the subject's fingerprints against its criminal file and submit the fingerprints to the F.B.I. for a comparison with nation-wide records, unless submission to the F.B.I. is automatic pursuant to the use of live-scan. The results of the F.B.I. check will be returned based on its current procedure, presently being directly to the City Police Department if submissions are made manually to the GCIC, or electronically from both the OBI and F.B.I. where submissions are made electronically to the GCIC. 
(4)  In compliance with Federal law 95-544, which provides for the rendering of a "fitness determination," the City will decide whether the applicant has been convicted of, or is under pending indictment for enumerated disqualifiers, as set forth within this chapter. 
(5)  A person who has consented to the City for a criminal history based on fingerprinting record may request and receive a copy of the criminal history record report from the City at no additional charge. Should the person seek to amend or correct the record, he or she shall be responsible for contacting the GCIC as to Georgia records and/or the F.B.I. concerning records from other jurisdictions maintained in its file. 
(e)  All applications shall be sworn to by the applicant before a Notary Public or other officer authorized to administer oaths. 
(Ord. No. 994, § 2, 8-19-2015) 
Sec. 9-1-162. - Temporary special event license. 
(a)  In order to distribute or sell alcoholic beverages at a temporary special event, a bona fide nonprofit civic organization shall be required to: 
(1)  Apply to the City for an alcoholic beverage temporary special event license; and 
(2)  Pay an alcoholic beverage temporary special event license fee according to the schedule approved from time to time by the City Council. 
(b)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall review the responsible party's application and supporting documentation and shall evaluate the application based upon the following factors: 
(1)  The City Manger or his/her designee's perception of whether the event can be conducted safely; 
(2)  Whether the City of Conyers Police Department can adequately provide security for said temporary special event; 
(3)  The number of people anticipated to be attending the temporary special event; 
(4)  The geographic location of the premises upon which the temporary special event will be held; 
(5)  The impact of the temporary special event on surrounding businesses or residents; and 
(6)  Whether the responsible party has failed to meet any other criteria specified by this chapter or state law. 
(c)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall have discretion when evaluating the aforementioned factors and shall either approve or deny, in writing, said temporary special event license application. 
(d)  All temporary special event license applications must be submitted at least 30 calendar days prior to the planned special event. 
(e)  No more than two temporary special event licenses may be issued to a bona fide nonprofit civic organization in any one calendar year. 
(f)  A list of all donated alcoholic beverages from the wholesaler must be maintained by the temporary special event license holder at all times. 
(g)  The restrictions set forth in the section 9-1-13, hours of operation , shall apply to all sales of alcoholic beverages at authorized temporary special events. 
(h)  Said temporary special event license shall only be valid for the premises specified in the temporary special event license. 
(Ord. No. 994, § 2, 8-19-2015) 
CHAPTER 2. - OCCUPATION TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Chapter 2, Business Licenses, was completely replaced by Ord. No. 564, 4-4-95 and renamed Occupation Tax, and amended in its entirety by Ord. No. 575, adopted 2-6-96. 
State Law reference— Business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5 et seq.; municipal business license tax on depository financial institutions authorized, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 

Sec. 9-2-1. - Occupation tax required. 
Each person engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in the City, whether with a location in the City or in the case of an out-of-State business with no location in the State exerting substantial efforts within the State pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, shall pay an occupation tax for said business, trade, profession, or occupation annually. Upon payment of such occupation tax, the City shall provide to each such taxpayer certificate of registration or a receipt as evidence of the payment of such tax. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in the City, such business tax certificate or receipt shall be shown to the City Manager or his/her designee or to any Police Officer of the City, upon request. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-1; Ord. No. 607, 11-4-1997) 
Sec. 9-2-2. - Purpose and scope of tax. 
The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5 to 48-13-28. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-2; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996; Ord. No. 780, § I, 12-17-2008) 
Sec. 9-2-3. - Construction of terms; definitions. 
When used in this article, the following words and phrases have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, unless the context indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. 
(2)  Dominant line means the type of business, within a multiple-line business, that the greatest amount of income is derived from. 
(3)  Employee means: 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this definition, an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, Federal Income Tax, or State Income Tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form IRS W-2 but not a form IRS 1099. 
(b)  An individual who performs work under the direction and supervision of one business or practitioner in accordance with the terms of a contract or agreement with another business which recruits such individual is an employee of the business or practitioner which issues to such individual, for purposes of documenting compensation, a form IRS W-2. 
(4)  Location or office includes any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. The renter's or lessee's location which is the site of personal property which is rented or leased from another does not constitute a location or office for the personal property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor. The site of real property which is rented or leased to another does not constitute a location or office for the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor unless the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor, in addition to showing the property to prospective lessees or tenants and performing maintenance or repair of the property, otherwise conducts the business of renting or leasing the real property at such site or otherwise conducts any other business, profession, or occupation at such site. 
(5)  Municipal Court Judge means the Judge of the Municipal Court of the City. 
(6)  Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue raising purposes. 
(7)  Person shall be held to include sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofits, or any other form of business organization. 
(8)  Practitioner of profession or occupation is one who by State law requires State licensure regulating such profession or occupation. 
(9)  Practitioners of professions and occupations shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. 
(10)  Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the City. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee or registration fee. Development impact fees, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(8), or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development, are not regulatory fees. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-3; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996; Ord. No. 780, § II, 12-17-2008) 
Sec. 9-2-4. - Administrative and regulatory fee structure; occupation tax structure. 
(a)  A nonprorated, nonrefundable administrative fee shall be required on all business and occupation tax accounts for the initial start-up, renewal, or reopening of those accounts. 
(b)  A regulatory fee will be imposed as provided under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9 on those applicable businesses. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. 
(c)  The amounts of the administrative fee and the regulatory fee shall be as established by the City Council, from time to time. 
(d)  The regulatory fee schedule for persons in occupations and professions shall be maintained by the City and a copy thereof shall be maintained in the office of the City Manager or his/her designee. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-4; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-5. - Occupation tax levied; restrictions; information required. 
(a)  An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices within the corporate limits of the City and upon the applicable out-of-State businesses with no location or office in the State exerting substantial efforts within the State pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7 based upon the following criteria: Profitability ratio for the type of business, profession, or occupation as measured by nationwide averages derived from statistics, classifications, or other information published by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget, the U.S. Internal Revenue Service, or successor agencies of the United States. 
(b)  Occupation tax schedule; profitability ratios. The tax rate determined by profitability ratios for each business, trade, profession, or occupation is as follows and will be developed and updated from time to time by the Mayor and City Council: 

 
(c)  (1)  No business or practitioner shall be required to pay more than one occupation tax except as otherwise provided. 
(2)  Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, real estate brokers shall be subject to occupational tax pursuant to the terms of this chapter only if they maintain a principal or branch office in the City. 
(d)  Upon request of the City Manager or his/her designee, any businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations doing business within the corporate limits of the City shall provide information regarding the site of any location or office and payment of occupation taxes or regulatory fees to other local governments. Businesses and practitioners who fail to comply with this subsection shall be subject to the penalties provided herein. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-5; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996; Ord. No. 780, § III, 12-17-2008; Ord. No. 951, § II, 11-20-2013) 
Sec. 9-2-6. - Paying occupation tax for businesses with no location in Georgia. 
Registration and assessment of an occupation tax is imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the State if the business's largest dollar volume of business in the State is in the City and the business or practitioner: 
(1)  Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the corporate limits of the City for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or 
(2)  Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the corporate limits of the City. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-6; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-7. - Each line of business to be identified on business registration. 
The business registration of each business operated in the City shall identify the dominant line of business which each such business conducts. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-7; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-8. - More than one place or line of business. 
Where a business includes more than one line of business, said business shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for each line of business and pay an occupation tax in accordance with the prevailing taxing method and tax rate for each line of business. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-8; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-9. - Professionals as classified in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1) through (18). 
Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1) through (18) shall elect as their entire occupation tax one of the following: 
(1)  The occupation tax based on profitability ratio as set forth in Section 9-2-5. 
(2)  A fee of $400.00 per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service. The per-practitioner fee applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the State's regulatory guidelines and framework. 
(3)  This election is to be made on an annual basis and must be done by January 31 of each year. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-9; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-10. - Practitioners exclusively practicing for a government. 
Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the State, a municipality or county of the State, instrumentalities of the United States, the State, or a municipality or county of the State shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-10; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-11. - When tax due and payable. 
(a)  Each such occupation tax shall be for each calendar year unless otherwise specifically provided. The registration and occupation tax for each calendar year shall be renewed January 1 of each year and shall be due and payable on January 31 of each year. On any new profession, trade, or calling begun in the City, the registration and tax shall be due and payable 30 days following the commencement of the business. 
(b)  In addition to the above penalty, the City Manager or his/her designee may proceed to collect in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-11; Ord. 607, 11-4-1997) 
Sec. 9-2-12. - Exemptions. 
(a)  All State and local authorities and nonprofit organizations shall be exempt from the occupation tax, regulatory fee and administrative fee imposed by this chapter. 
(b)  Upon submission of a certificate of exemption issued by the commissioner of veterans service, no occupation tax, regulatory fee or administrative fees shall be required of a disabled veteran or blind person as set forth in State law, O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1 et seq., as may hereinafter be amended. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-12; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996; Ord. No. 886, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-2-13. - Evidence of State license if applicable. 
(a)  Each person who is licensed by the Secretary of State pursuant to Title 43 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated shall provide evidence of proper and current State licensure before City registration may be issued. 
(b)  Each person who is licensed by the State shall provide evidence of such license before the City registration may be issued. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-13; Ord. No. 607, 11-4-1997) 
Sec. 9-2-14. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. 
Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a City business registration, show evidence that such requirements have been met. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-14; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-15. - Liability of officers and agents for failure to pay occupation tax. 
All persons subject to the occupation tax levy pursuant to this chapter shall be required to pay the occupation tax for said business as described in this chapter, and in default thereof, the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to pay such occupation tax. Every person commencing business in the City after January 1 of each year shall likewise pay the occupation tax herein provided within 30 days after commencing same; and shall be subject to penalties provided thereof. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-15; Ord. 607, 11-4-1997) 
Sec. 9-2-16. - When registration and tax due and payable; penalties imposed. 
Each such registration shall be for the calendar year in which the registration was obtained unless otherwise specifically provided. There is hereby imposed a penalty of ten percent of the tax or fee due hereunder upon each business which fails to pay all tax and fees as provided in this chapter within 90 days from the due date of such tax or fees. Said penalties may be collected by the remedies herein provided for collection of the occupation tax, and shall have the same lien and priority as the occupation tax to which the penalty is applied. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-16; Ord. 607, 11-4-1997) 
Sec. 9-2-17. - Penalty of ordinance violation. 
In addition to any other penalty or remedy provided for herein, any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction before the Municipal Court Judge, be fined an amount not exceeding $500.00. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-17; Ord. No. 619, 10-19-1998; Ord. No. 620, 12-14-1998; Ord. No. 780, § IV, 12-17-2008) 
Sec. 9-2-18. - Businesses not covered by this chapter. 
The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this chapter but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the State or by local law: 
(1)  Those businesses regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission; 
(2)  Those electrical service businesses organized under Chapter 3 of Title 46 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; 
(3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness; 
(4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105; 
(5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8 et seq.; 
(6)  Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15; 
(7)  Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. (Businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal and hulls);
