(8)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in the State governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356; 
(9)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93; 
(10)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-18; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-19. - Occupation tax inapplicable where prohibited by law or provided for pursuant to other existing law. 
An occupation tax shall not apply to any part of a business where such levy is prohibited or exempted by the laws of Georgia or of the United States. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-19; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-20. - Amount of fee or tax due from businesses commenced on or after July 1. 
When any person commences business on or after July 1 in any year, the occupation tax imposed pursuant to this chapter for the remaining portion of the year shall be 50 percent of the occupation tax imposed for the entire year. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-20; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Secs. 9-2-21—9-2-23. - Reserved. 
Sec. 9-2-24. - Effect of failure to comply with chapter provisions. 
Any persons, their managers, agents, or employees, who are required to make occupation tax returns, and who fail to make said returns within the time and in the manner herein provided, who refuse to amend such returns so as to set forth the truth, or who shall make false returns; and any persons, their managers, agents, or employees who refuse to permit an inspection of books in their charge when the officers, agents, employees, or representatives of the City request such inspection, during normal business hours of the City, for the purpose of determining the accuracy of the returns herein provided for, shall be subject to penalties provided herein. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-24; Ord. No. 607, 11-4-1997) 
Sec. 9-2-25. - Lien taken for delinquent occupation tax. 
In addition to the other remedies herein provided for the collection of the occupation tax herein levied, the City Manager or his/her designee, upon any tax or installment of said tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the correct amount of said tax against the persons, partnership, or corporation liable for said tax, which said execution shall bear interest at the rate of 1.5 percent per month from the date when such tax or installment becomes delinquent, and the lien shall cover the property (in the City) of the person, partnership or corporation liable for said tax, all as provided by the ordinances and charter of the City and the laws of the State. The lien of said occupation tax shall become fixed on and date from the time when such tax or any installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the City Manager or his/her designee upon the property of defendant located in said jurisdiction, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of said execution, with interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be had as is provided by ordinances and Charter of the City and the laws of Georgia, and the defendant in said execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the applicable laws in regard to tax executions. When a nulla bona entry has been entered by proper authority upon an execution issued by the City Manager or his/her designee against any person defaulting on the occupation tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due him or her as though he or she had never defaulted in the payment of the taxes. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-25; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-26. - Amendment; repeal of provision. 
This chapter shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the City Council to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Said amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the jurisdiction of additional occupation taxes upon the same person, property, or business. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-26; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-27. - Applications of provisions to prior ordinance. 
This chapter does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereinafter passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in said ordinance or ordinances, or failure to comply with any other provisions hereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee, or assessment shall be fully paid. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-27; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-28. - Enforcement of provisions. 
It is made the duty of the City Manager or his/her designee to see that the provisions of this chapter relating to occupation taxes are observed, and to summon all violators of the same to appear before the court. It is made the further duty of the City Manager or his/her designee, Chief of Police, members of the Department of Public Safety to inspect all registrations issued by the City, as often as in their judgment it may seem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-28; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-29. - Provisions to remain in full force and effect until changed by governing body. 
The ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the City Council. All provisions hereto relating to any form of tax herein levied shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-29; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-30. - Requirement of public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution regarding occupation tax. 
The City Council shall conduct at least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution regarding occupation tax as set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-30; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-31. - Requirement of public hearing if the revenues from occupation tax is greater than the preceding year. 
The City Council shall conduct at least one public hearing in any year when the revenue from occupation taxes is greater than the revenue for the preceding year as part of the process of determining how to use the additional revenue. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-31; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-32. - Option to establish exemption or reduction in occupation tax. 
(a)  The City Council, by subsequent ordinance or resolution, may provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax to one or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious, and the reasons shall be set forth in the minutes of the City Council. 
(b)  Exemptions or reductions in occupation tax pursuant to subsection (a) of this section may include, but shall not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Absolute dollar amount limitations on the total amount of tax, either by criterion or combination of criteria used for classification or for businesses and practitioners; provided, that such maximum tax shall be levied and collected only once on each business entity or practitioner even if a business or practitioner has more than one office or location within the City; 
(2)  Tax credits for the retention or creation of jobs, or for jobs of a specific description, including but not limited to entry level jobs or jobs with compensation of a specified range; 
(3)  Tax credits for other taxes paid to the local government, including but not limited to ad valorem taxes; 
(4)  A credit or rebate to businesses or practitioners who paid occupation taxes in the previous year; and 
(5)  A limitation on the dollar or percentage amount of increase in tax from a base year to a subsequent year, provided that the limitation is made applicable to new businesses or practitioners by imputing the profitability ratio of the subsequent year to the base year in calculating tax for the base year, tax for the subsequent year, and the increase in tax. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-32; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 9-2-33. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. 
Where there is an apparent conflict in this chapter between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-33; Ord. No. 564, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 575, 2-6-1996) 
CHAPTER 4. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS, PEDDLERS AND CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; transient merchants, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq.; Georgia Charitable Solicitations Act of 1988, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE A. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND PEDDLERS 

Sec. 9-4-1. - Intent and purpose. 
It is the intent of the Mayor and City Council in enacting this article to: 
(1)  Serve and protect the health, safety and welfare of the general public; 
(2)  Establish a uniform set of rules and regulations that are fair and equitable; 
(3)  Develop rules and regulations which will enhance the overall appearance and environment along public streets, pedestrian ways and other public properties; and 
(4)  Provide economic development opportunities for small entrepreneurs in the City. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-1; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006) 
Sec. 9-4-2. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any peddler or transient merchant, as defined by this article, to engage in such business within the City without first complying with the provisions of this article and having been issued the required permit. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-2; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006) 
Sec. 9-4-3. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Mobile food vendor is a motorized, wheeled vehicle designed and utilized for the preparation and sale of food and non-alcoholic beverage items to the general public, and whose operations are self-contained within the confines of the vehicle. Such vehicles shall operate in accordance with state law and the rules and regulations for food service of the Rockdale County Environmental Health Department. 
(2)  Peddler includes any person, whether as agent, consignee, or employee, when traveling by foot, wagon, motor vehicle, or any other type of conveyance, going from place to place and selling or offering to sell services or exhibiting wares and actually selling them whenever the opportunity arises, and carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, food items, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale. 
(3)  Transient merchant means any person, firm or corporation, whether as principal or agent, or both, that is not a permitted retail or wholesale merchant with a permanent place of business in the City, but rather one who sells or offers to sell services or displays samples, model goods, wares or merchandise in any lot, building, room or structure of any kind, whether fixed or mobile for the purpose of securing orders for the retail sale of such items or items of like kind or quality for immediate or future delivery. The person, firm, or corporation so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this article merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant, or auctioneer. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-3; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006; Ord. No. 800, § 1, 6-20-2010; Ord. No. 1046, § 1, 2-15-2017) 
Sec. 9-4-4. - Application. 
(a)  Applicants for a permit under this article must file with the City Manager or his/her designee an application on forms to be furnished by the City Manager or his/her designee, that shall give information identifying the applicant by providing his/her full name and permanent address; the name and permanent address of the applicant's registered agent or office (if applicable); and the date and State of incorporation of the applicant's corporation (if applicable). 
(b)  All applicants shall attach to the application a complete and accurate description of all the articles to be sold. 
(c)  If applicable, no permit shall be issued unless the applicant has satisfied all requirements imposed for the sale of merchandise, produce, or other food items, and proof is furnished that the County Health Department conditions imposed have been met. 
(d)  If the applicant uses the interior of any trailer or motor vehicle for any purpose other than storage of merchandise, the applicant shall provide proof of liability insurance. 
(e)  If a property owner has given permission for the use of a portion of the interior of his/her structure for the temporary location of a transient merchant, the applicant shall furnish the property owner's name, written permission from the property owner, telephone number and the applicable street address as well as the approximate square foot dimensions of the interior temporary location. A permit for the temporary interior use of a portion of a property owner's structure may be granted for a time period not to exceed 45 days. 
(f)  All transient merchants shall comply with the provisions of the State law set forth in Title 43, Chapter 46, as hereinafter may be amended from time to time. 
(g)  A peddler shall comply with the provisions of State law set forth in Title 43, Chapter 32, as hereinafter may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-4; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006; Ord. No. 800, § 2, 6-20-2010; Ord. No. 835, § 1, 5-4-2011) 
Sec. 9-4-5. - Investigation and issuance. 
(a)  For the protection of the public health, safety and welfare, a background investigation of the applicant's business and the applicant's moral character shall be conducted to regulate the issuance of peddler permits and transient merchant permits. 
(b)  A complete set of fingerprints of each applicant shall be required. 
i.  Authority. This subsection is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2), the Georgia Umbrella Statute entitled Dissemination of Information to Public Agencies, Political Subdivisions, Authorities, and Instrumentalities. 
ii.  Fingerprinting required. An individual seeking to receive a transient merchant or peddler's license shall be fingerprinted as a condition of submitting an application for said license. By filing such application, the applicant consents to the City obtaining their criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). 
iii.  Access authorized; usage regulations. 
A.  The City is hereby authorized to access national criminal history record information pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2). 
B.  Information obtained and handled for any purposes pursuant to this subsection shall comply with all Georgia laws and the Federal Privacy Act. 
C.  No information given as part of the request for a criminal history and no record obtained pursuant to this section may be entered on any database. 
D.  No information given or obtained pursuant to this section shall be subject to the provisions of the Georgia Open Records Act. 
iv.  Administration; fees; procedures. 
A.  Applicant shall provide his/her fingerprints, which may be taken by the City Police Department or may be taken by the County Sheriff's Office if the City Police Department is unable to do so. 
B.  The applicant shall bear the cost of: 
(1)  Fingerprinting if carried out by the County Sheriff; 
(2)  The charge by the GBI and the FBI for the CHRI history at their latest rate, paid to the City by certified or cashier's check or money order; and 
(3)  An administrative fee allowed by statute to be charged by the City, which shall be the maximum allowed by statute, which is currently $20.00, which fee shall include fingerprinting when carried out by the City Police Department. 
C.  Upon receipt of the fingerprints and the appropriate fees, the City will transmit said fingerprints and appropriate fees (unless a satisfactory billing arrangement has been entered into between the City Police Department and the GCIC and/or FBI) to the GCIC. As provided by law, the GCIC will compare the subject's fingerprints against its criminal file and submit the fingerprints to the FBI for a comparison with nation-wide records, unless submission to the FBI is automatic pursuant to the use of live-scan. The results of the FBI check will be returned based on its current procedure, presently being directly to the City Police Department if submissions are made manually to the GCIC, or electronically from both the GBI and FBI where submissions are made electronically to the GCIC. 
D.  In compliance with Federal Law 95-544, which provides for the rendering of a fitness determination, the City will decide whether the record applicant has been convicted of, or is under pending indictment for enumerated disqualifiers, as set forth within this chapter. 
E.  A person who has consented to the City for a criminal history based on fingerprinting record may request and receive a copy of the criminal history record report from the City at no additional charge. Should the person seek to amend or correct the record, he or she shall be responsible for contacting the GCIC as to State records and/or the FBI concerning records from other jurisdictions maintained in its file. 
(c)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall endorse on such permit application his/her approval or disapproval and his/her reasons for the same within 30 days of receipt of a completed application. 
(d)  In no event shall a permit be granted to any person, officials or directors of any corporation who have been convicted of, pled guilty to, or have entered a plea of nolo contendere to any felony or to any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, as defined herein, within a period of ten years prior to the filing of the application. A misdemeanor involving moral turpitude shall include any misdemeanor criminal offenses involving an act of fraud, theft, dishonesty and misdemeanor drug offenses. However, all applicants shall be entitled to the full benefits of O.C.G.A. § 42-8-60 et seq. relating to first offender status. If, at the time of application, the applicant is charged with any of the offenses prescribed in this subsection, then consideration of the application shall be suspended until the entry of a plea or verdict or dismissal. If the permit is approved, the City Manager or his/her designee shall execute the appropriate permit upon payment of the prescribed permit fee, issue a permit, and deliver the permit to the applicant. In the event a permit is denied, the applicant may appeal such denial as set forth in Section 9-4-17. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-5; Ord. No. 769, 5-7-2008; Ord. No. 835, § 2, 5-4-2011) 
Sec. 9-4-6. - Permit not transferable. 
Any permit issued under this article is not transferable from one person to another, and it is to be used solely by the person to whom it is issued. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-6; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006) 
Sec. 9-4-7. - Computation of fees. 
Permit holders shall pay an occupational permit fee according to the schedule approved from time to time by the City Council. There shall be no proration of the fee. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-7; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006) 
Sec. 9-4-8. - Exemptions. 
(a)  No permit fee shall be required of a peddler selling the agricultural products of any State, nor to persons selling agricultural implements, nor to persons engaged in the manufacturing of jugs and flower pots, as provided by State law, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-6, as may hereinafter be amended. 
(b)  Upon submission by the applicant of a certificate of exemption issued by the commissioner of veterans service, no permit fee shall be required of a disabled veteran or blind person as set forth in State law, O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1 et seq., as may hereinafter be amended. 
(c)  Trade shows shall be exempt from these licensing requirements, provided that no product is sold to the general public and that any orders taken are from members of the trade and shall be for future delivery only. 
(d)  No permit fee or application under this article shall be required for a rummage, estate, garage, antique or similar sale when the person holding the event is a City resident and complies with the relevant City ordinance and when such sale is not a part of the regular business activity of such person. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-8; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006; Ord. No. 886, § 2, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-9. - Display of permits. 
Permittees under this article must keep the original issued permit with them at all times while doing business in the City. Permittees are required to exhibit the original permit at the request of any citizen, Police Officer or City Official. A permit under this article shall be good for only one point of operation, such as a stand, building, motor vehicle or other conveyance. Additional points of operation shall require additional permits. Each peddler shall obtain an individual permit. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-9; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006) 
Sec. 9-4-10. - Permit restrictions and prohibitions. 
No permittee shall use any part of the streets or sidewalks of the City for the display of goods or merchandise. The City Council may approve the use of streets and sidewalks by vendors, exhibitors and performers during City-authorized festivals, in accordance with such standards and guidelines as it may establish from time to time. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-10; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006) 
Sec. 9-4-11. - Use of streets. 
No permittee under this article shall have any exclusive right to any location in the public streets, nor shall any permittee be allowed a stationary location on public property. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-11; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006) 
Sec. 9-4-12. - Permittee selling from motor vehicles. 
(a)  Permittees selling ice cream from a motor vehicle and mobile food vendors shall be subject to this section. 
(b)  Standards specific to selling ice cream from a motor vehicle. 
(i)  Permittees selling ice cream from a motor vehicle shall, before making any sale, park the vehicle at the right curb and at least eight feet from any other vehicle that may be parked on the street and not less than 100 feet from any intersecting street. When the vehicle stops, all sound equipment or other devices used to notify customers of the presence of the permittee shall be stopped and shall not resume until the vehicles is again put in motion. 
(ii)  No permittees selling ice cream from a motor vehicle using sound equipment or other methods of attracting customers shall operate such equipment before 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. daily. 
(iii)  No permittees selling ice cream from a motor vehicle shall stop or stand and do business for more than 30 minutes at the same location. 
(c)  Standards specific to mobile food vendors. 
(i)  No mobile food vendor shall conduct business on public streets or in the public right-of-way except as part of a city-sponsored or sanctioned special event. 
(ii)  Mobile food vendor operations shall be limited to the parking areas of privately owned, non-residential property in the following zoning districts: Office—Institutional District, Mixed-use Development District, General Business District, Downtown Center District, Downtown Civic District, Industrial/Distribution District, and Gateway Village—Urban Village District. 
(iii)  Any and all drivers of a mobile food vending vehicle must possess a valid Georgia driver's license. 
(iv)  All mobile food vendors shall maintain a $1,000,000.00 liability insurance policy. Proof of current liability insurance, issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state of Georgia, protecting the mobile food vendor, the public, and the City of Conyers from all claims of damage to property and bodily injury, including death, which may arise from operation under or in connection with the permit. Such insurance shall name the City of Conyers as an additional insured and shall provide that the policy shall not terminate or be canceled prior to the expiration date without 30 days advanced written notice to the City. 
(v)  Prior to issuance of the required permit under this article, any person or entity operating as a mobile food vendor shall execute an indemnity agreement indemnifying and releasing the City of Conyers, its agents, employees, and elected officials from any and all liability against any and all claims, actions, and suits of any type whatsoever. 
(vi)  Prior to the issuance of the required permit under this article, mobile food venders shall submit the written, notarized consent of the private property owner upon whose lot it is requesting to operate, a valid food service permit obtained from the Rockdale County Environmental Health Department, proof of liability insurance, the indemnity agreement releasing the City of Conyers, and a valid Georgia driver's license to the Department of Planning and Inspection Services. The mobile food vendor permit, written consent of the property owner, food service permit, and Georgia driver's license must be readily available for inspection within the vehicle at all times during hours of operation. 
(vii)  No mobile food vendor shall be located within 150 linear feet of the property line of a lot containing a single-family home or townhouse, or within 50 linear feet of an entrance to a restaurant. Additionally, no mobile food vendor shall be located within 15 linear feet of any street intersection, pedestrian crosswalk, driveway, fire hydrant, alleys, handicapped parking spaces, or building entrances. Mobile food vendors shall not be located within 100 feet of gas pumps, underground gas storage tanks, and vent pipes. 
(viii)  Mobile food vendors shall not operate between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. daily and shall not be left unattended, parked, or stored on a vending site during the restricted hours of operation or while not actively vending. All mobile food vending vehicles must return to their base of operations when not in use. 
(ix)  Except as may be allowed during a city-sponsored or sanctioned special event, no more than two mobile food vendors may operate on a single property at any one time. 
(x)  No external speakers, sound equipment or other devices shall be used to play music or omit noises for the purpose of advertising the mobile food vendor's location while vending. 
(xi)  No flashing, blinking, or strobe lights shall be used on or within a mobile food vendor vehicle. 
(xii)  No mobile food vendor shall be permitted to have or operate as a vehicular drive-through facility or drive-up window. 
(xiii)  All mobile food vending vehicles shall be equipped with a reverse gear signal alarm that is distinguishable from the surrounding noise level and rear-vision mirrors, firmly attached, on each side of the vehicle. 
(xiv)  Free-standing signs or signage that projects from the body of the mobile food vending vehicle shall be prohibited. No sign used on a mobile food vendor vehicle shall be illuminated, flash, or produce motion. 
(xv)  No external items, equipment, or structures shall be allowed at the vending site, including, but not limited to, tables, seating, displays, lighting, decks, or roofed structures. 
(xvi)  Mobile food vendors shall conduct business only when positioned on hard- surfaced, designated parking areas and shall not block driveway entrances, parking lot aisles, access to loading areas, or emergency access or fire lanes. 
(xvii)  At no time shall the operation of a mobile food vendor reduce the number of parking spaces available on a property below the minimum required in Section 8-7-93(b) Parking space requirements. 
(xviii)  Each mobile food vendor shall provide at least one trash receptacle for its patrons that is regularly emptied and shall remove all such waste materials before departing from the site. Such waste materials shall be disposed of at the mobile food vendor's base of operations. The mobile food vendor shall be responsible for maintaining the area around their vehicle clear of trash and debris at all times. 
(xix)  The dumping of gray water, grease, or other waste liquids on public or private property or into storm drains shall be prohibited. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-12; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006; Ord. No. 1046, § 2, 2-15-2017) 
Sec. 9-4-13. - Duration of peddler's permit. 
All peddler's permits issued under this article shall be in effect until December 31 of each year. There shall be no proration of the fee. Permits may be renewed upon application and payment of the required fee for 12-month periods thereafter, unless the permit for the preceding period has been revoked or is under suspension. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-13; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006) 
Sec. 9-4-14. - Transient merchant permit requirements and restrictions. 
(a)  A transient merchant permit may be issued by the City Manager or his/her designee for the sale of merchandise or services at a location, whether it is in the interior or exterior of a structure if the following conditions are met: 
(i)  Written permission of the property owner is provided; 
(ii)  Services are not provided and merchandise is not located within 50 feet of any public right-of-way; 
(iii)  A sign (not portable) may be erected on the property, provided it does not exceed a total of 16 square feet and ten feet in height, and provided it is not placed within 20 feet of any public right-of-way; 
(iv)  Adequate parking, ingress and egress are provided on-site or written permission from the adjoining property owner is obtained if such parking, ingress and egress are provided by an adjoining property; and 
(v)  All other requirements set forth in this chapter are met. 
(b)  Each transient merchant permit shall be valid for up to a maximum of 45 consecutive days. 
(c)  No transient merchant shall apply for or be issued more than one transient merchant permit in any calendar year. 
(d)  No transient merchant shall apply for or be issued more than one transient merchant permit more than once every six months from the date of the prior approval. 
(e)  A given parcel of property, or any portion thereof, can only be used as a location for a permitted transient merchant for up to a maximum of 45 consecutive days in any calendar year. 
(f)  No transient merchant permit shall be issued for a given parcel of property, or any portion thereof, more than once in any calendar year. 
(g)  No transient merchant permit shall be issued for a given parcel of property, or any portion thereof, more than once every six months from the date of the prior approval. 
(h)  No transient merchant permit shall be issued for a given parcel of property unless the sale of goods or services offered by the transient merchant would be an allowable use within the given parcel of property's zoning classification. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-14; Ord. No. 736, 6-7-2006; Ord. No. 800, § 3, 6-20-2010) 
Sec. 9-4-15. - Enforcement. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any Police Officer to require any person seen peddling, and who is not known by such officer to be duly permitted, to produce his/her peddler's permit and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any Police Officer to require any transient merchant, who is not known by such officer to be duly permitted, to produce his/her transient merchant's permit and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(c)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall have the authority to cite for violations of this article. The fees for violations of this article shall be as provided by Section 1-1-8. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-15; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006) 
Sec. 9-4-16. - Revocation of permit. 
Permits issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked, suspended or probated by the City Manager or his/her designee after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for permit, or made in the course of carrying on his/her business as peddler or transient merchant; 
(2)  Any violation of this article or this Code; 
(3)  Conviction of any crime involving moral turpitude; 
(4)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statements made in connection with the selling of any article, merchandise, produce or food item; 
(5)  Violations of the provisions of the County Health Department regulations applicable to holders of food permits; 
(6)  Conducting the business of peddling in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public; 
(7)  Conducting the business of a transient merchant in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public; and 
(8)  A person whose permit has been revoked may appeal the revocation as set forth in Section 9-4-17. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-16; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006) 
Sec. 9-4-17. - Appeals procedure. 
(a)  Any person may appeal the denial of or the suspension/revocation of his/her permit to the Director of Planning and Inspections within 30 days of the date that the adverse decision is issued. Notice of the appeal shall be delivered in writing to the Clerk of the City. The Director of Planning and Inspections shall set a hearing date within ten days of receiving the appeal request. Notice of said hearing shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the applicant's application. The Director of Planning and Inspections may require the submission of additional written evidence from the aggrieved person and shall hold a hearing on the matter. At the hearing, the aggrieved person is entitled to be heard and present evidence in his/her behalf. The City Manager's designee may similarly be heard and present evidence in support of the denial, suspension or revocation. The Director of Planning and Inspections shall determine whether the denial, suspension or revocation of the permit is justified, utilizing the criteria for denial, suspension or revocation set forth in this chapter. 
(b)  The Director of Planning and Inspections, after hearing evidence, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, shall have the authority to uphold the decision of the City Manager's designee, modify the decision of the City Manager's designee, or revoke the decision of the City Manager's designee. 
(c)  The Director of Planning and Inspections shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 days of the date of delivery of the notice of appeal. All decisions by the Director of Planning and Inspections shall be in writing and shall be served on the aggrieved person personally or by registered certified mail and mailed to the address set forth in the applicable license or permit application. 
(d)  Any person may appeal the Director of Planning and Inspections' decision to the City Manager within 30 days of the date that the adverse decision is issued by the Director of Planning and Inspections. Notice of the appeal shall be delivered in writing to the Clerk of the City. The City Manager shall set a hearing date within ten days of receiving the appeal request. Notice of said hearing shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the applicant's application. The City Manager may require the submission of additional written evidence from the aggrieved person and shall hold a hearing on the matter. At the hearing, the aggrieved person is entitled to be heard and present evidence in his/her behalf. The City Manager's designee and the Director of Planning and Inspections may similarly be heard and present evidence in support of the denial, suspension or revocation. The City Manager shall determine whether the denial, suspension or revocation of the permit is justified, utilizing the criteria for denial, suspension or revocation set forth in this chapter. 
(e)  The City Manager, after hearing evidence from the City Manager's designee, the Director of Planning and Inspections and the aggrieved person or his/her representative, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, shall have the authority to uphold, modify, or revoke the Director of Planning and Inspections' decision. 
(f)  The City Manager shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 days of the date of delivery of the notice of appeal. All decisions by the City Manager shall be in writing and shall be served on the aggrieved person personally or by registered certified mail and mailed to the address set forth in the applicable license or permit application. 
(g)  Any person may appeal the City Manager's decision to the Mayor and City Council within 30 days of the date that the adverse decision is issued by the City Manager. Notice of the appeal shall be delivered in writing to the Clerk of the City. The Mayor and City Council shall set a hearing date within ten days of receiving the appeal request. Notice of said hearing shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the applicant's application. The Mayor and City Council may require the submission of additional written evidence from the aggrieved person and shall hold a hearing on the matter. At the hearing, the aggrieved person is entitled to be heard and present evidence in his/her behalf. The City Manager's designee, the Director of Planning and Inspections and the City Manager may similarly be heard and present evidence in support of the denial, suspension or revocation. The Mayor and City Council shall determine whether the denial, suspension or revocation of the permit is justified, utilizing the criteria for denial, suspension or revocation set forth in this chapter. 
(h)  The Mayor and City Council, after hearing evidence from the City Manager's designee, the Director of Planning and Inspections, the City Manager, and the aggrieved person or his/her representative, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, shall have the authority to uphold, modify, or revoke the City Manager's decision. 
(i)  All decisions of the Mayor and City Council shall be final. The Mayor and City Council shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 days of the date of delivery of the notice of appeal. All decisions by the Mayor and City Council shall be in writing and shall be served on the aggrieved person personally or by registered certified mail and mailed to the address set forth in the applicable license or permit application. 
(j)  The appeal process contained in this section shall be a condition precedent to the person whose permit application has been denied or a permittee whose permit has been revoked seeking judicial relief. Any decisions of the Mayor and City Council may be reviewed upon application for writ of certiorari before the Superior Court of the County filed within 30 days of the date of the service of the decision of the Mayor and City Council. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-17; Ord. No. 731, 5-24-2006) 
Secs. 9-4-18—9-4-21. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 887, § 1, adopted Sept. 19, 2012, amended Art. B in its entirety to read as herein set out. The former Art. B, §§ 9-4-22—9-4-27, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from §§ 9-4-22—9-4-27 of the 1990 Code; and Ord. No. 731, adopted May 24, 2006. 

Sec. 9-4-22. - Intent and purpose. 
It is the intent of the Mayor and City Council in enacting this article to: 
(1)  Serve and protect the health, safety and welfare of the general public; and 
(2)  Establish a uniform set of rules and regulations that are fair and equitable. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-23. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit donations or contributions for, or to sell any insignia, novelty or other merchandise in the City on behalf of, or under the sponsorship of, any charitable organization, as defined by this article, within the City without first complying with the provisions of this article and having been issued the required permit. This article shall not apply to any canvasser or to any person or organization not engaged in the solicitation of funds. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-24. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Charitable organization means any benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic or religious person who solicits or obtains contributions solicited from the general public, any part of which contributions is used for charitable purposes; and any person who or which falsely represents himself, herself, or itself to be a charitable organization as defined by this paragraph. 
(2)  Charitable purpose means any charitable, benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary purpose for religion, health, education, social welfare, arts and humanities, environment, civic, or public interest; and any purpose which is falsely represented to be a charitable purpose as defined by this paragraph. 
(3)  Executive officer means the chief executive officer, the president, the principal financial officer, the principal operating officer, each vice president with responsibility involving policy-making functions for a significant aspect of a person's business, the secretary, the treasurer, or any other person performing similar functions with respect to any charitable organization, whether incorporated or unincorporated. 
(4)  Solicitation, solicitation of funds, or solicit means the request or acceptance directly or indirectly of money, credit, property, financial assistance, or any other thing of value to be used for any charitable purpose. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-25. - Application. 
The application required by this article shall be on a form to be furnished by the City Manager or his/her designee, shall be signed by the Executive Officer of the charitable organization and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address (headquarters), phone number, location, if applicable, and objective of the charitable organization conducting or sponsoring the solicitation to which this application relates; 
(2)  The day or days on which the solicitation will take place; 
(3)  The purpose and objective for which the funds to be derived from the solicitation will be utilized; 
(4)  The name, address and phone number of the Executive Officer of the charitable organization in direct control of conducting or sponsoring the solicitation and of the person preparing the application form; 
(5)  Whether or not the charitable organization, if not exempt under State law (O.C.G.A. § 43-17-9), or as hereinafter may be amended, has registered with the Secretary of State. If the charitable organization has registered with the Secretary of State, then the charitable organization shall provide a copy of registration notification from the Secretary of State; 
(6)  An outline of the method or methods to be used in conducting the solicitation; 
(7)  The estimated cost of the solicitation; 
(8)  The amount of any wages, fees, commissions, expenses, or emoluments to be expended or paid to any person in connection with the solicitation and the names and addresses of all such persons as provided by State law, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-3, or as hereinafter may be amended; 
(9)  A financial statement for the last preceding fiscal year of any funds collected by the applicants may be required and if required, the statement shall give the amount of money so raised together with the cost of raising it and the final distribution thereof; 
(10)  A statement to the effect that if a permit is granted, it will not be used or represented in any way as an endorsement by the City, or by any department or officer thereof; and 
(11)  All applicants granted a permit shall comply with the provisions of the State law set forth in Title 43, Chapter 17, as hereinafter may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-26. - Investigation and issuance. 
(1)  For the protection of the public health, safety and welfare, a background investigation of the applicant's business and the applicant's moral character shall be conducted to regulate the issuance of charitable solicitation permits. 
(2)  A complete set of fingerprints of each applicant shall be required. 
(a)  Authority. This subsection is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2), the Georgia Umbrella Statute entitled Dissemination of Information to Public Agencies, Political Subdivisions, Authorities, and Instrumentalities. 
(b)  Fingerprinting required. An individual seeking to receive a charitable solicitation permit shall be fingerprinted as a condition of submitting an application for said permit. By filing such application, the applicant consents to the City obtaining their criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). 
(c)  Access authorized; usage regulations. 
1.  The City is hereby authorized to access national criminal history record information pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2). 
2.  Information obtained and handled for any purposes pursuant to this subsection shall comply with all Georgia laws and the Federal Privacy Act. 
3.  No information given as part of the request for a criminal history and no record obtained pursuant to this section may be entered on any database. 
4.  No information given or obtained pursuant to this section shall be subject to the provisions of the Georgia Open Records Act. 
(d)  Administration; fees; procedures. 
1.  Applicant shall provide his/her fingerprints, which may be taken by the City Police Department or may be taken by the County Sheriffs Office if the City Police Department is unable to do so. 
2.  The applicant shall bear the cost of: 
a.  Fingerprinting if carried out by the County Sheriff; 
b.  The charge by the GBI and the FBI for the CHRI history at their latest rate, paid to the City by certified or cashier's check or money order; and 
c.  An administrative fee allowed by statute to be charged by the City, which shall be the maximum allowed by statute, which is currently $20.00, which fee shall include fingerprinting when carried out by the City Police Department. 
3.  Upon receipt of the fingerprints and the appropriate fees, the City will transmit said fingerprints and appropriate fees (unless a satisfactory billing arrangement has been entered into between the City Police Department and the GCIC and/or FBI) to the GCIC. As provided by law, the GCIC will compare the subject's fingerprints against its criminal file and submit the fingerprints to the FBI for a comparison with nation-wide records, unless submission to the FBI is automatic pursuant to the use of live-scan. The results of the FBI check will be returned based on its current procedure, presently being directly to the City Police Department if submissions are made manually to the GCIC, or electronically from both the GBI and FBI where submissions are made electronically to the GCIC. 
4.  In compliance with Federal Law 95-544, which provides for the rendering of a fitness determination, the City will decide whether the record applicant has been convicted of, or is under pending indictment for enumerated disqualifiers, as set forth within this chapter. 
5.  A person who has consented to the City for a criminal history based on fingerprinting record may request and receive a copy of the criminal history record report from the City at no additional charge. Should the person seek to amend or correct the record, he or she shall be responsible for contacting the GCIC as to State records and/or the FBI concerning records from other jurisdictions maintained in its file. 
(3)  The City Manager or his/her designee shall endorse on such permit application his/her approval or disapproval and his/her reasons for the same within 30 days of receipt of a completed application. 
(4)  In no event shall a permit be granted to any person, officials or directors of any corporation who have been convicted of, pled guilty to, or have entered a plea of nolo contendere to any felony or to any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, as defined herein, within a period of ten years prior to the filing of the application. A misdemeanor involving moral turpitude shall include any misdemeanor criminal offenses involving an act of fraud, theft, dishonesty and misdemeanor drug offenses. However, all applicants shall be entitled to the full benefits of O.C.G.A. § 42-8-60 et seq. relating to first offender status. If, at the time of application, the applicant is charged with any of the offenses prescribed in this subsection, then consideration of the application shall be suspended until the entry of a plea or verdict or dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-27. - Issuance of permit. 
The City Manager or his/her designee shall issue the permit provided for in this article whenever he/she finds the following facts to exist: 
(1)  That all of the statements made in the application are true; 
(2)  That all of the requirements of the application have been met; 
(3)  That the control and supervision of the solicitation will be adequate to prevent fraud and danger to the public and to the solicitors; 
(4)  That the applicant has not engaged in any fraudulent transaction or enterprise; 
(5)  That the solicitation will not be a fraud on the public; and 
(6)  That the solicitation is to finance and promote the purpose or objective described in the application and will not be conducted primarily for private profit. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-28. - Permit not transferable. 
Any permit issued under this article is not transferable from one charitable organization to another, and it is to be used solely by the charitable organization to whom it is issued. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-29. - Time period of permit. 
The permit under this article shall be valid only for the day or days on which the solicitation will take place. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-30. - Display of permits. 
Solicitors shall be required to carry on their person and exhibit their permits or copies thereof provided by the City, at the request of any representative of the City. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-31. - Enforcement. 
The City Manager or his/her designee shall have the authority to cite for violations of this article. The fees for violations of this article shall be as provided by Section 1-1-8. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-32. - Revocation or suspension of permit. 
Permits issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked or suspended by the City Manager or his/her designee after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for permit, or made in the course of soliciting funds; 
(2)  Any violation of this article or this Code; 
(3)  Conviction of any crime involving moral turpitude; 
(4)  Soliciting funds in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public; and 
(5)  A person whose permit has been revoked or suspended may appeal the revocation as set forth in Section 9-4-33. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-33. - Appeals procedure. 
(1)  Any person may appeal the denial of or the suspension/revocation of his/her permit to the Director of Planning and Inspections within 30 days of the date that the adverse decision is issued. Notice of the appeal shall be delivered in writing to the Clerk of the City. The Director of Planning and Inspections shall set a hearing date within ten days of receiving the appeal request. Notice of said hearing shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the applicant's application. The Director of Planning and Inspections may require the submission of additional written evidence from the aggrieved person and shall hold a hearing on the matter. At the hearing, the aggrieved person is entitled to be heard and present evidence in his/her behalf. The City Manager's designee may similarly be heard and present evidence in support of the denial, suspension or revocation. The Director of Planning and Inspections shall determine whether the denial, suspension or revocation of the permit is justified, utilizing the criteria for denial, suspension or revocation set forth in this chapter. 
(2)  The Director of Planning and Inspections, after hearing evidence, in accordance with the provisions of this article, shall have the authority to uphold the decision of the City Manager's designee, modify the decision of the City Manager's designee, or revoke the decision of the City Manager's designee. 
(3)  The Director of Planning and Inspections shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 days of the date of delivery of the notice of appeal. All decisions by the Director of Planning and Inspections shall be in writing and shall be served on the aggrieved person personally or by registered certified mail and mailed to the address set forth in the applicable permit application. 
(4)  Any person may appeal the Director of Planning and Inspections' decision to the City Manager within 30 days of the date that the adverse decision is issued by the Director of Planning and Inspections. Notice of the appeal shall be delivered in writing to the Clerk of the City. The City Manager shall set a hearing date within ten days of receiving the appeal request. Notice of said hearing shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the applicant's application. The City Manager may require the submission of additional written evidence from the aggrieved person and shall hold a hearing on the matter. At the hearing, the aggrieved person is entitled to be heard and present evidence in his/her behalf. The City Manager's designee and the Director of Planning and Inspections may similarly be heard and present evidence in support of the denial, suspension or revocation. The City Manager shall determine whether the denial, suspension or revocation of the permit is justified, utilizing the criteria for denial, suspension or revocation set forth in this chapter. 
(5)  The City Manager, after hearing evidence from the City Manager's designee, the Director of Planning and Inspections and the aggrieved person or his/her representative, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, shall have the authority to uphold, modify, or revoke the Director of Planning and Inspections' decision. 
(6)  The City Manager shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 days of the date of delivery of the notice of appeal. All decisions by the City Manager shall be in writing and shall be served on the aggrieved person personally or by registered certified mail and mailed to the address set forth in the applicable permit application. 
(7)  Any person may appeal the City Manager's decision to the Mayor and City Council within 30 days of the date that the adverse decision is issued by the City Manager. Notice of the appeal shall be delivered in writing to the Clerk of the City. The Mayor and City Council shall set a hearing date within ten days of receiving the appeal request. Notice of said hearing shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the applicant's application. The Mayor and City Council may require the submission of additional written evidence from the aggrieved person and shall hold a hearing on the matter. At the hearing, the aggrieved person is entitled to be heard and present evidence in his/her behalf. The City Manager's designee, the Director of Planning and Inspections and the City Manager may similarly be heard and present evidence in support of the denial, suspension or revocation. The Mayor and City Council shall determine whether the denial, suspension or revocation of the permit is justified, utilizing the criteria for denial, suspension or revocation set forth in this chapter. 
(8)  The Mayor and City Council, after hearing evidence from the City Manager's designee, the Director of Planning and Inspections, the City Manager, and the aggrieved person or his/her representative, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, shall have the authority to uphold, modify, or revoke the City Manager's decision. 
(9)  All decisions of the Mayor and City Council shall be final. The Mayor and City Council shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 days of the date of delivery of the notice of appeal. All decisions by the Mayor and City Council shall be in writing and shall be served on the aggrieved person personally or by registered certified mail and mailed to the address set forth in the applicable permit application. 
(10)  The appeal process contained in this section shall be a condition precedent to the person whose permit application has been denied or a permittee whose permit has been revoked seeking judicial relief. Any decisions of the Mayor and City Council may be reviewed upon application for writ of certiorari before the Superior Court of the County filed within 30 days of the date of the service of the decision of the Mayor and City Council. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
Sec. 9-4-34. - Unlawful acts. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to execute an application that contains any false statement, and it shall be unlawful for any person to solicit funds on the streets of the City purportedly on behalf of or under the sponsorship of any charitable organization that does not in fact exist. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 9-19-2012) 
CHAPTER 6. - BILLIARDS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Local governments power to license, regulate, and tax billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-6; minors prohibited where alcoholic beverages sold, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-10. 

Sec. 9-6-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Billiard room means any public place where at least three seven-foot long billiards tables are located within the premises, where the game of billiards is permitted to be played and for which a charge is made for use of the equipment. 
Billiards means any of the several games played on a table surrounded by an elastic ledge of cushions, with balls which are impelled by a cue, and includes all forms of the game known as carom billiards, pocket billiards, pool, and English billiards. 
(Code 1978, § 8-4021; Code 1990, § 9-6-1; Ord. No. 865, § 1, 3-7-2012) 
Sec. 9-6-2. - License application. 
(a)  No person shall operate a billiard room in the City without first having obtained a license to do so. In addition to any information required for a City business license generally, the application for the license shall be in writing on a form furnished by the City and shall contain at least the following information: 
(1)  The names, ages and addresses of all persons and interests in the licensed business; 
(2)  If the applicant is a corporation, the application must include: 
a.  Complete names and addresses of all officers; 
b.  The registered agent and the registered office of the corporation; 
c.  The State, County, and date of incorporation; and 
d.  The complete names and addresses of the manager or managers of the billiard room to be opened; 
(3)  The address where the billiard room is to be located and operated; 
(4)  The number of tables to be operated; 
(5)  The name, age and address of owner (or manager if operated by a corporation); 
(6)  All the previous experience manager or owner has had in operation of billiard rooms; 
(7)  The name and address of owner of the property where the billiard room is to be located; and 
(8)  A complete set of fingerprints of the applicant, the manager(s) and the owner(s) (hereinafter collectively referred to as "applicant"): 
a.  Authority. This subsection is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2), the Georgia Umbrella Statute entitled Dissemination of Information to Public Agencies, Political Subdivisions, Authorities, and Instrumentalities. 
b.  Fingerprinting required. An individual seeking to receive a billiards license shall be fingerprinted as a condition of submitting an application for said license. By filing such application, the applicant consents to the City obtaining their criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). 
c.  Access authorized; usage regulations. 
i.  The City is hereby authorized to access national criminal history record information pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2). 
ii.  Information obtained and handled for any purposes pursuant to this subsection shall comply with all State laws and the Federal Privacy Act. 
iii.  No information given as part of the request for a criminal history and no record obtained pursuant to this section may be entered on any database. 
iv.  No information given or obtained pursuant to this section shall be subject to the provisions of the Georgia Open Records Act. 
d.  Administration; fees; procedures. 
i.  Applicant shall provide his/her fingerprints, which may be taken by the City Police Department or may be taken by the County Sheriff's Office if the City Police Department is unable to do so. 
ii.  The applicant shall bear the cost of: 
(1)  Fingerprinting if carried out by the County Sheriff; 
(2)  The charge by the GBI and the FBI for the CHRI history at their latest rate, paid to the City by certified or cashier's check or money order; and 
(3)  An administrative fee allowed by statute to be charged by the City, which shall be the maximum allowed by statute, which is currently $20.00, which fee shall include fingerprinting when carried out by the City Police Department. 
iii.  Upon receipt of the fingerprints and the appropriate fees, the City will transmit said fingerprints and appropriate fees (unless a satisfactory billing arrangement has been entered into between the City Police Department and the GCIC and/or FBI) to the GCIC. As provided by law, the GCIC will compare the subject's fingerprints against its criminal file and submit the fingerprints to the FBI for a comparison with nation-wide records, unless submission to the FBI is automatic pursuant to the use of live-scan. The results of the FBI check will be returned based on its current procedure, presently being directly to the City Police Department if submissions are made manually to the GCIC, or electronically from both the GBI and FBI where submissions are made electronically to the GCIC. 
iv.  In compliance with Federal Law 95-544, which provides for the rendering of a fitness determination, the City will decide whether the record applicant has been convicted of, or is under pending indictment for enumerated disqualifiers, as set forth within this chapter. 
v.  A person who has consented to the City for a criminal history based on fingerprinting record may request and receive a copy of the criminal history record report from the City at no additional charge. Should the person seek to amend or correct the record, he or she shall be responsible for contacting the GCIC as to State records and/or the FBI concerning records from other jurisdictions maintained in its file. 
(b)  The application must be signed by the applicant, if an individual, and by the manager, if a corporation. 
(c)  A copy of the applicant's County billiard license must be attached as provided by O.C.G.A. § 43-8-3. 
(d)  The City shall have 14 days after the application is completed and filed with the Chief of Police or his/her designee in which to investigate the applicant and issue or deny the license. No license to operate a billiard room will be issued if the applicant: 
(1)  Has been convicted of, or has entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to, a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude or to any felony. As used herein, the term "a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude" shall include any misdemeanor criminal offenses involving fraud, theft, dishonesty and misdemeanor drug offenses. However, all applicants shall be entitled to the full benefits of O.C.G.A. § 42-8-60 et seq. relating to first offender status. If, at the time of application, the applicant is charged with any of the offenses prescribed in this subsection, then consideration of the application shall be suspended until the entry of a plea or verdict or dismissal; 
(2)  Has had any previous license to operate a billiard room revoked; or 
(3)  Has violated any other billiard room regulation. 
(e)  In any case in which it appears to the Chief of Police or his/her designee that an applicant is not entitled to the issuance of a permit under the provisions of this chapter, the Chief of Police or his/her designee shall so notify the applicant in writing by mailing said notice to the last address furnished by the applicant. In the event that the Chief of Police or his/her designee refuses to issue a permit, or in the event that a permit is surrendered pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, the applicant or permit holder shall have an absolute right of appeal to the City Manager according to the procedures set forth herein. The appeal shall be perfected by filing with the Chief of Police a notice of appeal to the City Manager. The notice of appeal to the City Manager must be filed with the Chief of Police within 14 days following the mailing of the Chief of Police's or his/her designee's notification of denial or surrender of the permit, and it shall be the duty of the Chief of Police, upon receipt thereof, to transmit said notice of appeal to the City Manager, together with copies of all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. Thereafter, the City Manager shall set a date for hearing on the matter within 30 days after receipt by the Chief of Police of the notice of appeal. Moreover, the City Manager shall notify the appellant in writing of the date, time and place when the matter shall be heard. 
(Code 1990, § 9-6-2; Ord. No. 831, § 1, 5-4-2011) 
Sec. 9-6-3. - Revocation. 
In addition general revocation conditions, the license of any billiard room operator may be revoked for: 
(1)  Being convicted of, or entering a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to, any felony or to any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, as such term is defined within this chapter. However, all applicants shall be entitled to the full benefits of O.C.G.A. § 42-8-60 et seq. relating to first offender status; 
(2)  Violation of any City ordinance pertaining to the operation of billiard rooms; or 
(3)  Misrepresentation regarding the character or former conduct of the operator of the billiard room. 
(Code 1978, § 8-4023; Code 1990, § 9-6-3; Ord. No. 831, § 2, 5-4-2011) 
Sec. 9-6-4. - Sanitation requirements. 
All billiard rooms shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, shall have at least one restroom on the premises, and shall comply with all sanitary rules and regulations of the Health Departments of the State, County and City. 
(Code 1978, § 8-4027; Code 1990, § 9-6-4) 
Sec. 9-6-5. - Reserved. 
Sec. 9-6-6. - Gambling and alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  No games of chance of any kind shall be allowed in a billiard room. 
(b)  No malt beverage, wines, distilled spirits or any other alcoholic beverage shall be sold, served or allowed to be used in or on the premises of a billiard room except under a license issued under Section 9-1-1 et seq. 
(Code 1990, § 9-6-6; Ord. No. 527, 12-8-1992) 
State Law reference— Games of chance and alcoholic beverages prohibited in billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-2. 
Sec. 9-6-7. - Inspection of billiard rooms by Police Department. 
It shall be the duty of the Police Department to inspect all public billiard rooms in the City for the purpose of ascertaining that they are not in violation of any of the provisions of this article, and it shall be their duty to enforce all aspects of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 8-4030; Code 1990, § 9-6-7) 
CHAPTER 7. - PRECIOUS METALS DEALERS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— The provisions of this chapter, unless otherwise indicated, are derived from Ord. No. 443, adopted 2-6-90. 
State Law reference— Local governments authorized to license, regulate, and tax dealers in precious metals or gems, O.C.G.A. § 43-37-1 et seq. 

Sec. 9-7-1. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this chapter, unless the context indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Dealer means: 
a.  Any person engaged in the business of purchasing precious metals or gems or goods made from precious metals or gems from persons or sources other than manufacturers, manufacturers' representatives, or other dealers in precious metals or gems; or 
b.  A person engaged in any other business if, in conjunction with such business, precious metals or gems or goods made from precious metals or gems are purchased from persons or sources other than manufacturers, manufacturers' representatives, or other dealers in precious metals or gems where such purchase is for resale in its original form or is changed by remounting, melting, reforming, remolding, or recasting or for resale as scrap or in bulk. 
(2)  Department of Public Safety means the City Department of Public Safety, Police Services Division. 
(3)  Employee means any person working for a dealer whether or not he is in the direct employment of the dealer, who in the performance of his duties or the management of the business affairs of the dealer, handles precious metals or gems, or who prepares any reports or records which are required by this chapter; provided, however, that this subsection shall not be construed so as to include employees of any bank, armored car company, private security company, or other business entity which is acting in the sole capacity of bailee-for-hire in relationship to the dealer. 
(4)  Gems means any precious or semiprecious stone cut and polished. 
(5)  Person means an individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, trust, association, or any other legal entity however organized. 
(6)  Precious metals means gold, silver, platinum, or any alloy containing gold, silver, or platinum. 
(7)  Purchase means buy, barter, trade, accept as collateral for a loan, or receive for the purpose of melting down, crushing, or otherwise altering the appearance of the item. 
(Code 1990, § 9-7-1) 
Sec. 9-7-2. - Annual permit prerequisite to issuance of business license. 
(a)  No business license shall be issued to conduct the business of purchasing precious metals or gems until the annual permit required by this section shall have been issued by the Department of Public Safety. 
(b)  No dealer shall engage in the business of purchasing precious metals or gems without having first obtained an annual permit issued by the Department of Public Safety; no dealer shall allow an employee to involve himself in any way in the purchase of precious metals or gems until that employee has first obtained an annual employee permit from said Department of Public Safety; and no person shall work as an employee of a dealer until he has first obtained an annual employee permit. No annual employee permit shall be issued unless the dealer with whom employment is authorized is a holder of a current dealer's permit. 
(Code 1990, § 9-7-2) 
Sec. 9-7-3. - Application for dealer's permit. 
(a)  The application for the annual dealer's permit required by Section 9-7-2 shall include such fingerprints, photographs, and information as may be reasonably required by the Chief of Police or his/her designee, but shall in any case include the following: 
(1)  The name, age and business address of the person or entity applying for the permit. 
(2)  The telephone number of the applicant entity or person. 
(3)  The name, age and business address of all other persons having an ownership interest or actually employed in the business other than publicly held corporations. 
(4)  The address of the premises upon which the business is conducted and the zoning and planning classification of the premises. 
(5)  The applicant shall be required to notify the Department of Public Safety, within seven calendar days of any change of address of the applicant or business or any change of ownership in the business. 
(b)  The applicant shall attach to this application a completed and signed employee or owner application as described in Section 9-7-5 hereof for each person named in the dealer's application. Each such application shall be signed by the owner, managing partner, corporate president, or chief elected officer of the business, and there shall be a description of the capacity in which the signator is acting. 
(Code 1990, § 9-7-3; Ord. No. 836, § 1, 5-4-2011) 
Sec. 9-7-4. - Application; denial of same. 
No dealer's permit shall be issued under the following circumstances: 
(1)  The applicant has no permanent place of business, other than a van, mobile home, trailer, or similar nonpermanent structure. 
(2)  No owner, corporate officer, majority stockholder, partner, or managing director of the business entity applying for the license has been a legal resident of the State for a minimum of 90 days preceding the date of application. 
(3)  Any person required to be listed in the application for a dealer's permit has been convicted of, or has entered a plea of guilty to a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude or any felony under the laws of this State or of the jurisdiction in which the verdict or plea was entered. This provision shall not apply to any person who has been convicted of or has entered a plea of guilty to a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude or any felony after ten years have expired from the date of the plea, conviction or completion of sentence, whichever is later. 
(4)  Any person is not eligible to register as a dealer in precious metals or gems by the terms of any law of this State requiring such registration. 
(Code 1990, § 9-7-4) 
Sec. 9-7-5. - Employee or owner application. 
(a)  Persons required to obtain an employee permit by Section 9-7-2 shall complete an employee or owner application which shall state relevant information including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Name; 
(2)  Date of birth; 
(3)  Driver's license, State identification card, or social security number; 
(4)  Race; 
(5)  Sex; 
(6)  Residential address and telephone number; 
(7)  Last previous residential address; 
(8)  Height and weight; 
(9)  Hair and eye color; 
(10)  Name, address, and telephone number of the dealer; and 
(11)  Either a statement that the applicant has never been convicted of, pled guilty to, or been sentenced to probation for any offense other than a minor traffic violation, or a list of all such pleas, convictions, and sentences of probation. 
(b)  The application form shall also provide a place for the applicant's signature. Persons required to be listed in a dealer's application shall also complete an employee or owner application. 
(Code 1990, § 9-7-5) 
Sec. 9-7-6. - Fingerprints. 
A complete set of fingerprints of employee(s) and owner(s) (hereinafter collectively referred to as "applicant") shall be required of each employee and owner as defined by this chapter: 
a.  Authority. This subsection is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2), the Georgia Umbrella Statute entitled Dissemination of Information to Public Agencies, Political Subdivisions, Authorities, and Instrumentalities. 
b.  Fingerprinting required. An individual seeking to receive a precious metals dealer license as an employee and as an owner shall be fingerprinted as a condition of submitting an application for said license. By filing such application, the applicant consents to the City obtaining their criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). 
c.  Access authorized; usage regulations. 
i.  The City is hereby authorized to access national criminal history record information pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2). 
ii.  Access to criminal histories is limited to employees of the City who are certified in security and integrity and whose certification is renewed every three years as required by the Georgia Bureau of Investigation (GBI). 
d.  Authority. This subsection is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2), the Georgia Umbrella Statute entitled "Dissemination of Information to Public Agencies, Political Subdivisions, Authorities, and Instrumentalities." 
e.  Fingerprinting required. An individual seeking to receive a precious metals dealer license as an employee and as an owner shall be fingerprinted as a condition of submitting an application for said license. By filing such application, the applicant consents to the City obtaining their criminal history record information (CHRI) from the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). 
f.  Access authorized; usage regulations. 
i.  The City is hereby authorized to access national criminal history record information pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35(a)(1.2). 
ii.  Access to criminal histories is limited to employees of the City who are certified in security and integrity and whose certification is renewed every three years as required by the Georgia Bureau of Investigation (GBI). 
iii.  Information obtained and handled for any purposes pursuant to this subsection shall comply with all State laws and the Federal Privacy Act. 
iv.  No information given as part of the request for a criminal history and no record obtained pursuant to this section may be entered on any database. 
v.  No information given or obtained pursuant to this section shall be subject to the provisions of the Georgia Open Records Act. 
g.  Administration; fees; procedures. 
i.  Two sets of fingerprints shall be given by the applicant. Fingerprints will be taken by the City Police Department or may be taken by the County Sheriff's Office if the City Police Department is unable to do so. 
ii.  The applicant shall bear the cost of: 
(1)  Fingerprinting if carried out by the County Sheriff;
